Mandates that all Alabamans wear a mask when in an indoor space open to the general public, a vehicle operated by a transportation service, or an outdoor public space where ten or more people are gathered. Exceptions for people under six or who are medically unable to wear a mask. Coded as Mandate2 because although masks are required in both indoor and outdoor spaces, the parameters on the spaces involved are relatively narrow (for instance, masks are only required in outdoor spaces if ten or more people are present). Public Health Emergency. Extended on 20201116 until 20201216: https://gov.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/Disaster-Declaration-11.6.2020.pdf. Extended to 20210115: https://gov.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/12.15.2020-COVID-Disaster-Declaration.pdf.

First issuance is schools staying closed until March 30 (i.e., extending spring break), issued 20200313 https://www.alaskapublic.org/2020/03/13/governor-says-all-k-12-students-in-alaska-to-attend-no-contact-school-until-march-30/ ...all public and private schools closed on 20200320 https://gov.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/03202020-SOA-COVID-19-Health-Mandate-008.pdf, extended to end of the school year. Alaska Smart Start 2020 framework released on 20200520 and updated document on 20200727. Framework details how school districts can choose to reopen and provides guidance for those determined as low, medium and high risk environments https://education.alaska.gov/news/COVID-19/Alaska%20Smart%20Start%202020%20Framework%20Guidance.pdf.  Grants local districts the authority to determine whether to operate in-person, online, or a hybrid contingent on the school district's assessment of the risk level, ending the SchoolClose: https://education.alaska.gov/news/COVID-19/Alaska%20Smart%20Start%202020%20Framework%20Guidance.pdf

All libraries, archives, and museums to be closed March 17-31. Extensions and expansions, including one on 20200409, removed expiry date. 20200422 executive order began easing of restrictions conditional on meeting extensive health safety guidelines https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf
Limited operations required: bars and breweries trucks, self-service dining. Easing as part of Phase II on 20200508. https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Phased-Reopen-Doc.pdf
Limited operations required: restaurants, food trucks, self-service dining. Easing began on 20200424 https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf
(quote) no gatherings of more than 10 people may take place (quote). Mandated for Fairbanks North Star Borough and Kethikan Gateway Borough only. No expiry provided.

Only applicable to Anchorage. Enacted at 10 pm on 20200322, was effectively replaced by the statewide StayAtHome order on 20200328. Expired on 20200401 since order was through 1159pm https://www.muni.org/departments/mayor/pressreleases/documents/eo-03.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateExpiry, old date was 20200331, but was in effect through 1159 pm so recoded to 20200401

PolicyCodingNotes: Issued 20200323, in effect on 20200324. Eased on 20200424 with new mandate that bans gathering no more than 20.

Closure required: hair salons, day spas, nail salons, barber shops, tattoo shops, body piercings, massage therapy, tanning. 20200409 update removed expiry of 20200421. Limited operations allowed starting 20200424 conditional on meeting health and safety mandates: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf  Eased for indoor entertainment centers on 20200508 and for gyms and fitness centers on 20200507.

Mandates 14 day quarantine for all people arriving in Alaska from anywhere else. A 20200424 health order extends this without any expiry https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf  A 20200601 health order extends it to 20200606 https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/06012020-COVID-MANDATE-010.pdf. The order is extended and amended on 20200811 https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/08062020-COVID-MANDATE-010-REVISED.pdf. Eased on 20201015. The requirement for people flying into Alaska without a negative test is now five days (previously 7-14 days). This means that travelers into the state will no longer have to take a second test to leave quarantine. Also, Alaskans will be able to travel out of state for up to 72 hours without requiring a test, previously 24 hours. https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/10152020-COVID-MANDATE-010-REVISED.pdf. Extended on 20201116: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Outbreak-Health-Order-No-6-lnternational-and-Interstate-Travel.pdf. Extended to 20210115: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/Outbreak-Health-Order-No-6-International-and-Interstate-Travel-DD3.pdf.

In effect as of 5 pm on 20200328. The 20200424 order allows non-essential businesses to re-open to in-person services conditional on meeting health and safety mandates https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf

In effect as of 5 pm on 20200328. The 20200424 order indicates the following (quote) Individuals are no longer required to stay home as previously required (quote), effectively ending the order. https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed DateExpiry as 20200409 update removed expiry. Added 20200424 as DateEnded as 20200424 order indicates individuals are no longer required to stay at home

PolicyCodingNotes: Travel between communities banned unless for critical personal or infastructure needs. A 20200409 update to health order removed initial expiry. The 20200424 order eased intra-state restrictions https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed DateExpiry as 20200409 update removed expiry. Added 20200424 as DateEased

PolicyCodingNotes: Highly recommended for all Alaskans: wear a cloth face covering in public settings where other social distancing measures are difficult to maintain. On 20200424, strengthened phrasing, (quote) In all gatherings that include multiple households, cloth face coverings should be worn by all participants (quote): https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/0425-COVID-MANDATE-016-ALL.pdf

Requires patrons to wear cloth face coverings when at retail businesses, personal care services (except for being able to be removed for a short time during necessary services - otherwise, must be worn at all other times including when entering and exiting the shop). On pdf page 30 of the mandate, also includes the following under indoor gatherings: (quote) At gatherings including non-household members, cloth face coverings must be worn, when possible. (quote) Coding to a Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies to very limited settings. Health Mandate 16 is no longer in effect as on 20200522 with Alaska going to Phase 3: https://gov.alaska.gov/newsroom/2020/05/19/governor-announces-phase-three-of-reopen-alaska-responsibly-plan/

(quote) Any family member who is ill with COVID-19 must be immediately isolated in their home or permitted place of residence of isolation (quote). Details how people who exhibit symptoms of COVID-19 must not leave their dwelling within 72 hours of their last fever, and then individuals who have known exposure to indivduals who tested positive for COVID-19 shall self-quarantine for 14 days following the last exposure. Also refers to CDC guidelines https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/index.html?CDC_AA_refVal=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cdc.gov%2Fcoronavirus%2F2019-ncov%2Fhcp%2Fguidance-prevent-spread.html

No gathering larger than 20 people is allowed, which includes the minimum number of necessary personnel to facilitate the event, or 25 percent maximum occupancy (whichever is smaller). Gatherings including non-household members, cloth face coverings must be worn, whenver possible. Also applies to religious gatherings.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Part II of recovery phase includes prohibition on gatherings of 50 or more. Ended 20200522, as as gathering limits became a recommendation https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/05192020-Alaskas-Plan-Forward-Final.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed DateEased and added DateEnded of 20200522, updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: According to Health Mandate 0018: Intrastate Travel Between Communities Located Off The Road System or The Marine Highway System Is Now Permitted, but subject to local travel restrictions. Re-expanded after previous easings, effective 20201121: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Outbreak-Health-Order-No-8-Intrastate-Travel.pdf. Extended to 20210115: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/Outbreak-Health-Order-No-8-Intrastate-Travel-DD3.pdf.
Any proposed large public gatherings such as festivals and concerts need to consult first with public health before scheduling.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) the following workplace policy is being implemented by the Office of the Governor: All employees, contractors, and visitors to State of Alaska facilities must wear a facemask if social distancing of at least six feet or more between individuals cannot be maintained. This applies to entryways, hallways, stairwells, elevators, enclosed parking areas, and personal offices where a six-foot distance cannot be exercised. (quote) Coding to a Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies to very limited settings.

(quote) Any person currently positive with COVID-19 cannot travel to Alaska until they have been released from isolation or cleared for travel by a medical provider or public health agency. (quote) Extended on 20201116: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Outbreak-Health-Order-No-6-lnternational-and-Interstate-Travel.pdf. Extended to 20210115: https://covid19.alaska.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/Outbreak-Health-Order-No-6-International-and-Interstate-Travel-DD3.pdf.

Public Health Emergency declaration. No formal expiry provided, (quote) will be eligible for termination upon the resolution of the outbreak as determined by the Arizona Department of Health Services (quote)

Public school closure. Statewide closure of all schools as of 20200320. Extended to the end of the academic year on 20200330 https://azgovernor.gov/governor/news/2020/03/governor-ducey-superintendent-hoffman-announce-extension-school-closures Extended through 20200817 https://azgovernor.gov/file/35148/download?token=jFLDklga Open for Learning plan announced on 20200723 which eases school closures on public and charters, but does not eliminate them completely (quote) all districts shall begin distance learning beginning August 17 (quote) https://azgovernor.gov/governor/news/2020/07/arizona-open-learning
Limited operations required (take-away, delivery, etc. only if the proper licenses were provided): bars (for places in counties with COVID19), to be enacted on 20200320.
Closure required: movie theaters, indoor gyms, fitness clubs, bars. In effect at close of business on 20200320. Only applicable to counties with confirmed COVID-19
Limited operations required (take-away, delivery, etc only): restaurants (for places in counties with COVID19), to be enacted on 20200320.

Via stay-at-home order, bar operations limited to delivery, takeout etc (conditional on proper licensing) for all counties. Mandate ended on 20200516: https://azgovernor.gov/file/34817/download?token=9X8aggcf

First gathering restriction activated with stay-at-home order. Extended to 20200516 https://azgovernor.gov/file/34712/download?token=aWa7Jw6L. Ended on 20200516 https://azgovernor.gov/file/34817/download?token=9X8aggcf (shall maximize physical distance has now become should) Gatherings of more than 50 people are prohibited from 20200629 Extended gathering restrictions to limit gatherings to 50 people on 20200723 https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo_2020-52_continuation_of_eo_2020-43.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Deleted DateReexpanded1 based on new gathering row.

PolicyCodingNotes: Via stay-at-home order, earlier business closures became applicable to all counties and additional ones occurred (i.e., in-person retail, close contact personal services). Easing began on 20200504, allowing retailers to have curbside pick up https://azgovernor.gov/file/34712/download?token=aWa7Jw6L . Ended mandated business restrictions on 20200516: https://azgovernor.gov/file/34817/download?token=9X8aggcf
Via stay-at-home order, restaurant operations became limited to delivery, takeout etc for all counties. Easing began on 20200511 https://azgovernor.gov/file/34745/download?token=kz_fRE5B
(quote) All indiviudals in the State of Arizona shall limit their time away from their place of residence (quote). Mandate ends on 20200516: https://azgovernor.gov/file/34817/download?token=9X8aggcf

Quarantine on any individuals entering Arizona from New York, New Jersey, or Connecticut as points of travel origin. Quarantine is 14 days long with exceptions for essential service providers. Ends on 20200516: https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo-2020-24.pdf

Allows retailers not classified as essential to operate and offer goods through delivery, window, walk-up, drive-through, drive-up, or appointment if establish and implement protocols to address COVID19. Eases to allow for indoor services on 20200508: https://azgovernor.gov/file/34817/download?token=9X8aggcf

Further eases restrictions on non-essential retail to permit in-person services at stores provided they establish and implement protocols to address COVID-19. Also requires the continuance of limited operations (i.e., delivery and curbside) for indoor malls. Also permits barbers and cosmetologists to reopen at this time. Ends all mandated restrictions starting on 20200516: https://azgovernor.gov/file/34817/download?token=9X8aggcf

Requires protocols for resuming in-person operations for barbers and cosmetologists, including using face coverings for employees and customers. Starting in 20200810, requires more businesses to have masks mandated for bars, restaurants, gyms, etc: https://www.azdhs.gov/documents/preparedness/epidemiology-disease-control/infectious-disease-epidemiology/novel-coronavirus/community/bars-nightclubs-dine-in.pdf

Allows for dine-in services provided dining establishments enact physical distancing policies, limit the number of diners, and follow protocols as directed by CDC and the Arizona Department of Health Services. Ended on 20200516: https://azgovernor.gov/file/34817/download?token=9X8aggcf

(quote) All individuals, when in public areas, should maximize physical distance from others. Social settings where appropriate physical distancing is not practical should be avoided unless precautionary measures are observed and CDC guidelines are followed (quote)

(quote) All vulnerable individuals, including the elderly and individuals with underlying health conditions, are advised to take reasonable steps to continue limiting their time away from their place of residence or property (quote)

Indicates that any jurisdiction (county, city, town) may adopt policies regarding face coverings in public for the purpose of mitigating the spread of COVID-19. Considered a recommendation at present based on the EO and accompanying press release about increasing awareness about face-covering https://azgovernor.gov/governor/news/2020/06/governor-ducey-announces-enhanced-covid-19-action-plan

Bars are required to close for on-premises consumption, but permits them to operate for pick-up, delivery, and drive-thru operations if they have the proper license. Eased on 20200827, as counties start moving beyond red transmission status: https://directorsblog.health.azdhs.gov/positive-news-for-az-counties-in-the-moderate-transmission-level-moving-into-next-phase-of-safely-reopening/

Re-introduces gatherings restrictions and specifies a limit of 50 people, exempting religious gatherings. Extended to 20200810: https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/eo_2020-52_continuation_of_eo_2020-43.pdf Extended beyond 20200810: https://azgovernor.gov/governor/news/2020/08/arizona-department-health-services-phased-reopening-plan-paused-industries Slightly eased on 20201203.Public events of more than 50 remain prohibited unless the city, town or county has determined that adequate safety precautions are document as part of the request.        https://azgovernor.gov/sites/default/files/executive_order_2020-59.pdf

Indoor gyms, fitness clubs, indoor movie theaters, nightclubs, water parks shall cease their activities. Licenses for festivals, fairs, special events are suspended. Began easing on 20200827: https://directorsblog.health.azdhs.gov/positive-news-for-az-counties-in-the-moderate-transmission-level-moving-into-next-phase-of-safely-reopening/
All school districts and charter schools shall develop and implement a policy to require face coverings, such as face masks or face shields, for all staff and students over the age of 5.
As counties move to yellow and green transmission status, bars can re-open for in-person services at 50 capacity (yellow can open if they have a food license, green can irrespective of food license)

Counties classified as yellow and green transmission levels allowing indoor gyms and like venues to re-open (25 pct for yellow, 50 pct for green), and movie theaters, water parks, tubing may re-open at 50 pct capacity with additional mitigation requirements. Nightclubs can re-open at 50 pct if they serve food at yellow level and irrespective of food license at green level
All counties are either at yellow and green transmission status, allowing at least some bars to re-open for in-person services at 50 pct capacity

By 20201001, all counties are at either yellow or green transmission levels, lowing indoor gyms and like venues to re-open (25 pct for yellow, 50 pct for green), and movie theaters, water parks, tubing may re-open at 50 pct capacity with additional mitigation requirements. Nightclubs can re-open at 50 pct if they serve food at yellow level and irrespective of food license at green level
On 20201210, Apache, Navajo, and Yavapai move to the substantial transmission level (red), closing bars.
Apache, Navajo, and Yavapai move to the substantial transmission level (red), closing movie theaters, water parks, tubing, gyms, and nightclubs.

Public Health Emergency. Extended on 20200505. Extended to 20201015 https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_20-45.pdf. Extended another 60 days through 20201213 so coded as 20201214: https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_20-48.pdf. Extended to 20201231: https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_20-51.pdf.

Initial closure in effect 20200317. On 20200406 order that all public schools to remain closed through remainder of academic year https://governor.arkansas.gov/news-media/press-releases/governor-hutchinson-announces-all-schools-to-remain-closed-for-remainder-of
Directive to close casinos. On 20200404 extended with no expiry https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_20-13._.pdf, closure announced in May 7 presser of governor.

Limited operations required: bars. Limited operations can begin on 20200526 https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_bars_and_clubs.pdf Further easing on 20200615 https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_bars_phase_II.pdf Requires ending onsite alcohol consumption at 1100 pm staring on 20201120: https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_Alcoholic_Beverage_Control_on-premise_permitted_locations.pdf

Closure required: gyms, indoor entertainment avenues. Gyms and fitness centers can re-open on 20200504, but only under very strict protocols and guidelines https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/GymFitnessCenterResumeDraft4.29.20.pdf

Limited operations required: restaurants. Limited operations can begin on 20200511 https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/Resume_Restaurant_Dine_In_May_11_directive_FINAL.pdf  Up to 66 pct capacity starting on 20200615: https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive__restaurant_dine-in_modified.pdf Requires ending onsite alcohol consumption at 1100 pm staring on 20201120: https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_Alcoholic_Beverage_Control_on-premise_permitted_locations.pdf

Closure required: Barbers, Body Art Establishments, Body Art Schools, Cosmetology Establishments and Massage Therapy Clinics/Spas, and Medical Spas https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_20-25._._.pdf
No expiry issued yet. Eased on 20200618 https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_20-37.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Travelers from New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, and New Orleans, Lousiana and all international locations are recommended to self-quarantine for 14 days. Ended on 20200615 https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/pdf/directive_business_limitations_phase_II.pdf

Everyone should wear a face covering, or mask, in public. Recommendation issued by Department of Health. Recommendation extended and made more specific on 20200619. On 20200703, This EO allows local ordinances making masks mandatory in conjunction with discussion with the governors office..

(quote) A 14-day self-quarantine is required for travelers entering Arkansas who have visited an international location or an area of high community transmission in the United States in the previous 14 days. (quote) Policy ended on 20200615, no more quarantine requirement for travellers both domestic and international.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateEnded to 20200615 and updated policynotes to include when policy ended

PolicyCodingNotes: Eased gathering restriction to no numerical value. All gatherings (no matter the number) should adhere to rules from the dept of health. All gatherings now subject to rules from Dept of Health, no numerical restriction in place.

Requires (quote) every person in Arkansas to wear a face covering over the mouth and nose in all indoor environments where they are exposed to non­household members and distancing of six (6) feet or more cannot be assured and in all outdoor settings where there is exposure to non­household members, unless there exists ample space of six (6) feet or more to practice physical distancing. (quote) Exemptions are for children younger than 10, individuals whose medical condition or disability prevent them from wearing a face covering, exercisng, at worship or religious services. Technically does not apply to counties where no newly identified cases for 28 straight days, but without further details on these counties, we are currently coding as statewide. Coded as Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly to indoor environments and outdoor settings unless physical distancing is practiced. Extended to 20201015 https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_20-45.pdf. Extended another 60 days through 20201213 so coded as 20201214: https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_20-48.pdf. Extended to 20201231: https://governor.arkansas.gov/images/uploads/executiveOrders/EO_20-51.pdf.
State of Emergency proclamation. No clear expiry provided.
California Department of Public Health issed guidance recommending the cancellation of gatherings of 250 or more. http://www.tcoe.org/GatheringGuidance.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: Local school closures only (according to NGA). From KFF (quote) While the CA governor has not officially mandated the statewide closure of schools, the state's mandatory quarantine order effectively closes all schools. (quote) Not currently coding as school closure mandate since a separate mandate did not occur. On 20200331, superintendent announces that students will not be able to return for the rest of the academic year - distance learning will continue.
(quote) All gatherings should be postponed or cancelled (quote). Coded as recommendation from CDPH
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: Bars, wineries, breweries, and pubs must be closed unless authoritized for take-away sales. Began easing on 20200612, allowing counties that completed advanced Phase 2 attestation to re-open bars, wineries, and tasting rooms.

Gathering restriction without numerical limits instituted with the enactment of the stay-at-home order. Governor does not set numerical limits at the state-level, defers to counties to do this. Houses of worship are required to close for all indoor services, so coding as 0 under InGathLimReligious

Identifies 16 critical sectors to remain open, otherwise all businesses must close. No clear expiry provided. Easing of certain businesses under Stage 2 Reopening: retail (curbside and pick-up), manufacturing, offices, select services (carwash, pet grooming, landscape gardening), outdoor museums and open gallery places. https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID-19/SHO%20Order%205-7-2020.pdf

Limited operations required (take-out, delivery) for restaurants and like establishments. No in-person services. Easing began with Phase 2 attestation processes: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/County_Variance_Attestation_Form.aspx.

Issued/enacted immediatedly. Note shelter-in-place and stay-at-home are being treated as equivalent at present. Considered an eased mandate starting 20200508: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID-19/SHO%20Order%205-7-2020.pdf Further easing of the mandate occurred starting 20200831: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID-19/8-28-20_Order-Plan-Reducing-COVID19-Adjusting-Permitted-Sectors-Signed.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed DateReexpanded1; see curfew based stay at home below

PolicyCodingNotes: Provides guidance around using face coverings - defaults to county policies, some of which are mandates (documentation of this may occur in the future) - but indicates that individuals should wear coverings if they feel comfortable doing so if counties do not have formal recommendations or mandates. Treating as a statewide recommendation

California moves to Stage 2, easing restrictions on lower risk workplaces and allowing resumption of limited in-person services conditional on health and safety requirements: manufacturing, offices, select services (carwash, pet grooming). Permits county discretion on stricter orders. Detailed more here: https://covid19.ca.gov/roadmap/

California moves to Stage 2, easing restrictions on lower risk workplaces and allowing limited outdoor services to resume conditional on health and safety requirements: landscape gardening, outdoor museums and open gallery places. Permits county discretion on stricter orders. Detailed more here: https://covid19.ca.gov/roadmap/

California moves to Stage 2, easing restrictions on lower risk workplaces and allowing limited services via takeaway conditional on health and safety requirements: retail (curbside and pick-up). Permits county discretion on stricter orders. Detailed more here: https://covid19.ca.gov/roadmap/

The following counties have completed attestation as of 20200518, and thus could move more eased restrictions on more types of businesses (in-person retail services and malls): Amador, Butte, Calaveras, Colusa, Del Norte, El Dorado, Glenn, Humbolt, Inyo, Lassen, Mariposa, Modoc, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, San Benito, Shasta, Sierra, Siskiyou, Tehama, Trinity, Tuolumne, Yuba-Sutter. Note that each county has a separate attestation plan and thus could have eased earlier, and thus further reivew is needed to decipher exact timing - this is ongoing work.

The following counties have completed attestation as of 20200518, and thus could move to ease restrictions on restaurants (i.e., dine-in services are permitted): Amador, Butte, Calaveras, Colusa, Del Norte, El Dorado, Glenn, Humbolt, Inyo, Lassen, Mariposa, Modoc, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, San Benito, Shasta, Sierra, Siskiyou, Tehama, Trinity, Tuolumne, Yuba-Sutter. Note that each county has a separate attestation plan and thus could have eased earlier, and thus further reivew is needed to decipher exact timing - this is ongoing work.

Eases restrictions on indoor religious gatherings, permitting houses of worship to re-open to 25 pct or up to 100 attendees, whichever is lower. Public and social gathering restrictions remain without explicit numeric limits, counties set these themselves.

Requires mask use for employees at hair salons and barbershops as they reopen. On 20200618, mandating that people in California must wear a face covering when (quote) engaged in work, whether at the workplace or performing work off-site, when interacting in-person with any member of the public, working in any space visited by members of the public, regardless of whether anyone from the public is present at the time, working in any space where food is prepared or packaged for sale or distribution to others...in any room or enclosed area where other people (except for members of the persons own household or residence) are present when unable to physically distance (quote). Also requires employees to wear masks when driving or operating any public transportation: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/COVID-19/Guidance-for-Face-Coverings_06-18-2020.pdf

Eases restrictions on bars, wineries, tasting rooms, and like venues, allowing them to re-open for counties that have completed advanced Phase 2 attestation: Alpine, Amador, Butte, Calaveras, Colusa, Contra Costa, Del Norte, El Dorado, Fresno, Glenn, Humboldt, Inyo, Kern, Kings, Lake, Lassen, Los Angeles, Madera, Mariposa, Mendocino, Merced, Modoc, Mono, Monterey, Napa, Nevada, Orange, Placer, Plumas, Riverside, Sacramento, San Benito, San Bernardino, San Diego, San Joaquin, San Luis Obispo, Santa Barbara, Santa Cruz, Shasta, Sierra, Siskiyou, Solano, Sonoma, Stanislaus, Tehama, Trinity, Tulare, Tuolumne, Ventura, Yolo, Yuba-Sutter

(quote) People in California must wear face coverings when they are in high-risk situations listed below (quote), inside of, or in line to enter, any indoor public space, obtaining services from the healthcare sector, waiting for or riding in public transportation or in a tax, private vehicle, or ride-sharing vehicle, workplace, operating transportation where others are present, and in outdoor public spaces where maintaining 6 ft or more distance is not feasible. Expands previous recommendation to a mandate. Starting on 2020113, the mandate is as follows (quote) People in California must wear face coverings when they are outside of the home, unless one of the exemptions below applies.(quote): https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/guidance-for-face-coverings.aspx

Contra Costa, Fresno, Glenn, Kern, Kings, Los Angeles, Merced, Orange, Riverside, Sacramento, San Bernardino, San Joaquin, Santa Barbara, Solano, Stanislaus, Tulare, Ventura counties must close wineries and tasting rooms unless they can be modified to operate outside or by pick-up only. Bars must close all operations, even if they operate outdoors. Closures for these 17 counties will last at least three weeks. Note that Imperial and Santa Clara were also included in this closure requirement (total of 19 counties), but they had not been listed under the counties completing advanced Phase 2 attestation: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/County_Variance_Attestation_Form.aspx Since July 1, more counties have been added to the County Monitoring List and thus their restrictions have increased

Contra Costa, Fresno, Glenn, Kern, Kings, Los Angeles, Merced, Orange, Riverside, Sacramento, San Bernardino, San Joaquin, Santa Barbara, Solano, Stanislaus, Tulare, Ventura counties must close movie theaters, family entertainment centers (e.g., bowling alleys, miniature golf, batting cages and arcades), zoos, museums, cardrooms unless they can be modified to operate outside or by pick-up. Closures for these 17 counties will last at least three weeks. Note that Imperial and Santa Clara were also included in this closure requirement (total of 19 counties), but they had not been listed under the counties completing advanced Phase 2 attestation: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/County_Variance_Attestation_Form.aspx On 20200713, gyms/fitness centers and personal care services are also required to close unless modified to oudoor only. More counties are added and removed from the County Monitoring List until 20200831.

Contra Costa, Fresno, Glenn, Kern, Kings, Los Angeles, Merced, Orange, Riverside, Sacramento, San Bernardino, San Joaquin, Santa Barbara, Solano, Stanislaus, Tulare, Ventura counties must close restaurants, wineries, and tasting rooms unless they can be modified to operate outside or by pick-up only. Closures for these 17 counties will last at least three weeks. Note that Imperial and Santa Clara were also included in this closure requirement (total of 19 counties), but they had not been listed under the counties completing advanced Phase 2 attestation: https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/Pages/COVID-19/County_Variance_Attestation_Form.aspx More counties are added and removed from the County Monitoring List to 20200831, which is when the Tier system is introduced and Tier 1 has to have outdoor only
All counties that completed attestation must close bars, brewpubs, pubs, and breweries for all operations (indoor and outdoor). Now statewide bar closure, takeaway only

Counties on the County Monitoring List must close houses of worship for indoor gatherings, so coding as 0 for InGathLimReligious. Also includes Imperial, which has not been approved for Phase 2 attestation. Counties are added and removed from County Monitoring list to 20200828 with the introduction to the Tier system

California Department of Health provides re-opening critieria for K-12, allowing schools to re-open for in-person instruction if they are not on the County Monitoring List and have not been on the County Monitoring List for the last 14 days. Requires school health and safety protocols to be approved by local health authority. Waivers can be applied for only via local health authorities. Applicable to these 26 counties: Alpine, Amador, Butte, Calaveras, Del Norte, El Dorado, Humboldt, Inyo, Kern, Lake, Lassen, Long Beach, Mariposa, Mendocino, Modoc, Mono, Nevada, Plumas, San Francisco, San Mateo, Santa Cruz, Shasta, Sierra, Siskiyou, Tehama, Trinity, Tuolumne, Yolo, Yuba-Sutter. Starting on 20200831, California starts its Tier system and thus counties at Tiers 3-4 can re-open for in-person instruction and those at Tier 2 for at least 2 weeks.

Counties that have been on the County Monitoring List must have distance learning only, and cannot re-open for in-person instruction until the county has been off the County Monitoring List for at least 14 days. These 31 counties are as follows: Alameda, Colusa, Contra Costa, Fresno, Glenn,  Kings, Los Angeles, Madera, Marin, Merced, Monterey, Napa, Orange, Placer, Riverside, Sacramento, San Benito, San Bernardino, San Diego, San Joaquin, San Luis Obispo, Santa Barbara, Santa Clara, Solano, Sonoma, Stanislaus, Sutter, Tulare, Yolo, Yuba, Ventura. Also includes Imperial, for a total of 32 counties, but Imperial has not completed advanced Phase 2 attestation. Starting on 20200831, California starts its Tier system and thus counties at Tier 1 cannot re-open for in-person instruction and Tier 2 counties cannot re-open until they have been at that level for at least 2 weeks.

(quote) Face coverings must be used in accordance with CDPH guidelines unless a person is exempt as explained in the guidelines, particularly in indoor environments, on school buses, and areas where physical distancing alone is not sufficient to prevent disease transmission. (quote) Also details face covering requirements by age/grade. Applies to public and private K-12 schools.

Tier 3 (Moderate) counties can have bars reopen for outdoor services only. Tier 3 (Moderate), 9 counties: Del Norte, Humboldt, Mariposa, Mono, Plumas, Shasta, Siskiyou, Trinity, Tuolumne. Since 20200831, counties have moved from Tier to Tier on what is permitted.

Tier 4 (Minimal) counties can have bars reopen for outdoor services and 50 pct capacity indoors. Tier 4 (Minimal), 2 counties: Alpine, Modoc. Since 20200831, counties have moved from Tier to Tier on what is permitted. Starting 20201124, no counties are at this level
Tier 2 (Substantial) counties can have houses of worship open to indoor services but at a maximum of 100 people or 25 pct (whichever is lower)
Tier 3 (Moderate) counties can have houses of worship open to indoor services but at a maximum of 200 people or 50 pct (whichever is lower)
Tier 4 (Minimal) counties can have houses of worship open to indoor services but at a maximum of 50 pct

With the switch the Tier system, all counties can have retail and malls open to some degree (varying levels of capacity limits) across tiers: Tiers 3 and 4 can have indoors with some modifications and physical distancing, Tier 2 is at up to 50 pct capacity, and Tier 1 is up to 25 pct capacity. The statewide easing of restrictions for indoor services also applies to hair salons and barbershops at this date.

Tier 1 counties can only have the following businesses operate outdoors: gyms/fitness centers, movie theaters, museums, galleries, zoos, and aquariums, additional personal care services (esthetician, skin care, and cosmetology services, electrology, nail salons, body art professonals and tattoo parlors, piercing shops, and massage therapy outside of healthcare settings). Tier 1 (Widespread) and Tier 2 (Substantial) businesses can only be open for outdoor services: family entertainment centers (e.g., kart racing, mini golf, batting cages), cardrooms and satellite wagering. Somewhat eased on 20201020, as the additional personal care services could then operate indoors for Tier 1 counties

Tier 2-4 counties can have the following businesses operate indoors (but at varying levels of capacity by Tier): gyms/fitness centers, movie theaters, museums, galleries, zoos, and aquariumsadditional personal care services (esthetician, skin care, and cosmetology services, electrology, nail salons, body art professonals and tattoo parlors, piercing shops, and massage therapy outside of healthcare settings).

Tehama moves back to Tier 1 (Widespread) from Tier 2 (Substantial). If schools had re-opened already, they may remain open conditional on following health and safety protocols. If not, they are not permitted to re-open until Tehema moves to Tier 2 for at least 2 weeks. Coding as LimitedInPerson under SchoolRestrictLevel. By 20201124, the following counties are at this level: Alameda, Butte, Colusa, Contra Costa, Del Norte, El Dorado, Fresno, Glenn, , Humboldt, Kern, Kings, Lassen, Mendocino, Merced, Napa, Nevada, Orange, Placer, Riverside, Sacramento, San Benito, San Diego, San Joaquin, San Luis Obispo, Santa Barbara, Santa Clara, Santa Cruz, Shasta, Siskiyou, Solano, Stanislaus, Sutter, Trinity, Tehama, Tuolumne, Yolo, Yuba

For private gatherings, no more than 3 households per gathering and (quote) all gatherings must be held outside (quote). Gatherings may be held outside up to 75 pct capacity if there are structures enclosing the outdoor area, but the no more than 3 households gathering in the public place or outdoor space requirement continues. Coding as a 0 for indoor social social gatherings and applying indoor religious gathering limits. (quote) Persons arriving in California from other states or countries, including returning California residents, should practice self-quarantine for 14 days after arrival. (quote) Listing the 50 states plus DC under AppliesTo

Expands prior stay-at-home order, instituting a requirement for Tier 1 (Widespread, Substantial) to that individuals stay at home between the hours of 10 pm to 5 am. For counties that move to Tier 1 after the effective date of the order, the time-based stay-at-home order comes into effect on the second day of Tier 1 status. Initially applies to: Alameda, Butte, Contra Costa, El Dorado, Fresno, Glenn, Imperial, Kern, Kings, Los Angeles, Madera, Mendocino, Merced, Monterey, Napa, Nevada, Orange, Placer, Riverside, Sacramento, San Benito, San Bernardino, San Diego, San Joaquin, San Luis Obispo, Santa Barbara, Santa Clara, Santa Cruz, Shasta, Siskiyou, Solano, Sonoma, Stanislaus, Sutter, Trinity, Tehama, Tulare, Tuolumne, Ventura, Yolo, Yuba
Alpine, Mariposa move back to Tier 3 (Moderate), where counties have bars able to reopen for for outdoor services only. No counties can now have bar services inside (either outdoor or takeaway)

Regional stay-at-home orders go into effect for Southern California and San Joaquin Valley, prohibiting any number of private social gatherings and closing houses of worship for indoor services. Outdoors religious services can still occur with social distancing

Regional stay-at-home orders go into effect for Southern California and San Joaquin Valley, requiring all non-essential businesses to close for in-person services for at least 3 weeks. Applies to the following locations staring 1159 pm on 20201206: Calaveras, Fresno, Imperial, Inyo, Kern, Kings, Los Angeles, Madera, Mariposa, Merced, Mono, Orange, Riverside, San Benito, San Bernardino, San Diego, San Joaquin, San Luis Obispo, Santa Barbara, Stanislaus, Tulare, Tuolumne, Ventura
Regional stay-at-home orders go into effect for Southern California and San Joaquin Valley, closing restaurants for in-person services (takeaway only)

Greater Sacramento region (Alpine, Amador, Butte, Colusa, El Dorado, Nevada, Placer, Plumas, Sacramento, Sierra, Sutter, Yolo, Yuba) goes to regional stay-at-home order, where counties have bars, breweries, and distilleries closed for in-person service. Now a statewide policy.

State of Disaster Emergency declared. Recommendation of canceling or postponing any events with more than 250 people. Issued on 20200313, unclear if any expiry exists

All downhill ski resorts are ordered to close for March 15-22, 2020, so through 20200323. Official expiry of this order is 30 days after 20200314, so 20200413. Extension to 20200523: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20049%20Amending%20and%20Extending%20Ski%20Closures.pdf Ended state-level restrictions on 20200526, permitting re-opening based on compliance with local health authorities https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ieLfhoFx6RU_7tkGElC2QA_88VSfFYHj/view

Limited operations required: bars, taverns, brew pubs, breweries, wineries, tasting rooms, and other places of public accommodation offering alcholic beverages for on-premises consumption (can have delivery/take-out, off-premise consumption only). PolicyCodingNotes: In effect at 1201 am on 20200319. (quote) all mass gatherings shall be limited to no more than ten (10) people. Remains in effect for 30 days, so to 20200418. Expands gathering recommendation to formal restriction. Also explicitly includes faith-based events. Technically issued on 20200320, but in effect on 20200319

All P-12 schools to suspend in-person operations March 23 to April 17, so through 20200417. Expressly includes charter schools, and public and private schools. Official expiry of this is order is 30 days after the 20200318 issuance, so it would be 20200417. Extended in-person closure through the end of the academic year: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20041%20P-12%20Closure%20Extension%20End%20of%20Year.pdf

Closure required: non-essential personal services facilities, off-track betting facilities, source of policy is public health order. 20200426 EO extends closure for now https://drive.google.com/file/d/1l13eSver8iS1fE149gmKHCLoHPgutNvO/view Effective 20200604 these activities may reopen subject to specific guidance and restrictions: playgrounds, outdoor sports facilities, outdoor swimming pools, recreation centers, indoor pools,gyms https://drive.google.com/file/d/12bRFEqXa7GvzNEPIK1lQVsnz4LeRgleA/view Extended to 20200805: https://drive.google.com/file/d/11F0Gd7DfVONN4p4yNa5h6_00xJB34SZm/view Extended to 20200820 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20142%20Safer%20at%20Home%20in%20the%20Vast%2C%20Great%20Outdoors%20-%20Alcohol.pdf On 20200723, amended EO extended this policy to 20200822: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20144%20Amending%20Safer%20at%20Home%20in%20the%20Vast%2C%20Great%20Outdoors.pdf Extended to 20200906 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20154%20Protect%20Our%20Neighbors.pdf Extended to 20201005 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20178-Protect%20Our%20Neighbors.pdf Extended to 20201019:  https://drive.google.com/file/d/1wRxIxSUPE7NSQKf0wnr5P7BB2PAl9h_k/view. Extended to 20201105 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20213%20Safer%20at%20Home.pdf

(quote) I direct all businesses other than those qualified as Critical Businesses to close temporarily (quote). Initial easing of NEBusinessClose began on 20200427 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20044%20Safer%20at%20Home.pdf

(quote) I direct all Coloradans to stay at home, subject to limited exceptions such as obtaining food and other household necessities, going to and from work at critical businesses, seeking medical care, caring for dependents or pets, or caring for a vulnerable person in another location (quote) In effect at 600 am on 20200326 through 20200411, so coded to expire on 20200412.

(quote) All public and private gatherings of any number of people occurring outside a Residence are prohibited, except for the limited purposes expressly permitted in this PHO which include Essential Activities. (quote) Eases on 20200427 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1PWuZ-bhXERZNQ-5RpUZqpsg-0_KNu0La/view

PHO Second Updated Public Health Order 20-24 closes public and private colleges and universities except to facilitate distance learning. They can perform essential functions if social distancing is followed, such as food services, medical and mental health services, security, critical research and housing.

People with symptoms of COVID-19 must self isolate until they recieve a negative test or at least 72 hours after symptoms resolve. Extended to 20200805: https://drive.google.com/file/d/11F0Gd7DfVONN4p4yNa5h6_00xJB34SZm/view Extended to 20200820 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20142%20Safer%20at%20Home%20in%20the%20Vast%2C%20Great%20Outdoors%20-%20Alcohol.pdf On 20200723, amended EO extended this policy to 20200822: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20144%20Amending%20Safer%20at%20Home%20in%20the%20Vast%2C%20Great%20Outdoors.pdf Extended to 20200906 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20154%20Protect%20Our%20Neighbors.pdf Extended to 20200920 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20170%20Safer%20at%20Home%20in%20the%20Vast%2C%20Great%20Outdoors.pdf Changes to a recommendation, thus ending the mandate on 20200915: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1wRxIxSUPE7NSQKf0wnr5P7BB2PAl9h_k/view
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateExpiry and PolicyCodingNotes, added DateEnded

PolicyCodingNotes: Requires workers in Critical Business and Critical Government functions to wear medical or non-medical face cloth while working. As more businesses reopen, more sectors are required to have employees wear masks (e.g., retail, personal services, restaurants, etc). One 20200717, was expanded: (quote) to protect workers, customers, and the community, no owner, operator, or manager of a Public Indoor Space, as such term is defined in Paragraph R of this Executive Order, may provide service to individuals or allow an individual to enter or move within that Public Indoor Space, unless the individual is wearing a face covering as required by this Executive Order (quote).https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20138%20Mask%20Order.pdf Extends to 20201209: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20245%20Mask%20Order.pdf
Eases gathering restrictions, now prohibiting public gatherings of 10 or more people in public spaces and private commercial venues.
Permits non-critical retail to operate and offer goods through delivery, window service, walk-up, drive-through, drive-up, curbside delivery. Eased on 20200501, permitting on-premises services

Starting on 20200427, personal training classes can resume in small groups. Starting on 20200604, gyms can reopen up to 50 pct or 50 people. Other businesses originally grouped together - gymnasiums, movie and performance theaters, opera houses, concert halls and music halls, cigar bars, and casinos - increasingly reopen over time and then for certain counties under COVID19 dial: https://covid19.colorado.gov/data/covid-19-dial/covid-19-dial-dashboard Extended to 20201228: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20265%20Dial.pdf

(quote) Individuals are urged to wear non-medical face coverings that cover the nose and mouth whenever in public (quote). Extended to 20200701: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1km7HpMzcucIqMcdNV9KpZSEhpzCmMK4k/view

(quote) Normal in-person instruction at all P-12 schools in Colorado will be suspended until the scheduled end of the 2019-2020 regular school year. P-12 schools and school districts may use school buildings for providing services to students, educators, and families, including but not limited to: in-person small group instruction, staff professional development, food service, access to internet, devices, or instructional materials, special education services, or mental health supports. P-12 schools and school districts intending to provide these services must work in coordination with their local public health agency and must observe Social Distancing Requirements pursuant to applicable public health orders (quote). Coding as LimitedInPerson under SchoolRestrictLevel as individuals are being allowed back into school buildings for limited in-person instruction and services. On 20200720, Guidance on reopening schools from Public Health department devolved authority on school closures to local districts, thus ending the formal School Closure at state level. (quote) Local public health agencies (LPHAs) may declare the phase for their county/area using the Stay, Safer, and Protect Complete Framework metrics. (quote): https://www.cde.state.co.us/communications/20200720reopeningguidance

Eases restrictions on public and private postsecondary institutions: (quote) Programs and courses at postsecondary institutions that cannot be conducted remotely, generally due to equipment requirements, may be conducted through limited in-person instruction. Institutions that wish to resume providing in-person instruction must inform the Colorado Department of Higher Education and ensure that Social Distancing Requirements are strictly followed. (quote) On 20200618, (quote) Programs and courses at postsecondary institutions may resume in-person classes at 50 pct of the occupancy limit not to exceed 50 people per room. If the room is extra large, the institution may allow up to 100 people indoors within their usable space calculated using the Social Distancing Space Calculator. (quote) Coding as ending the state-level closing of postsecondary institutions, as now institutions are now instructed to work with the Colorado Department of Education for guidelines on in-person instruction: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1DtXFRETS7kAVYYHhVmo9IcfciW5j1BMc/view

(quote) All individuals currently living within the State of Colorado are encouraged to stay at home and avoid unnecessary interactions whenever possible in order to reduce the spread of disease. (quote) Strongly recommends that vulnerable individuals, as defined as individuals 65 years or older, pregnant women, or individuals who have health conditions (chronic lung disease or severe asthma, serious heart conditions, immunocompromised), to stay-at-home: (quote) People at high risk of severe illness from COVID-19 are urged to stay in their residence at all times except as necessary to seek medical care. (quote) Extended to 20201228: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20265%20Dial.pdf

Permits non-critical retail to allow customers onto premises up to 50 pct capacity and in a manner allowing for strict compliance with mandatory social distancing requirements. These include requiring maintaining at least 6 ft separation between individuals. Starting on 202001020, as counties move to Safer at Home Level 3 (Orange Level), capacity is reduced to 25 pct in some counties: https://www.julesburgadvocate.com/2020/10/20/state-raises-logan-county-to-high-risk-on-covid-19-dial-slaps-on-new-restrictions/ Extended to 20201228: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20265%20Dial.pdf

Eases restaurant restrictions, now allowing for outside dining and limited indoor dining (i.e., no more than 50 pct occupancy or no more than 50 people, whichever is less), no more than 8 people to a table, and 6 ft physical distancing        https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ieLfhoFx6RU_7tkGElC2QA_88VSfFYHj/view On 20200618, extra large restaurants can have up to 100 people for occupancy. Starting on 20200915, with COVID19 dial, all levels permit indoor services but at varying levels (and these get updated regularly): https://covid19.colorado.gov/data/covid-19-dial/covid-19-dial-dashboard

Drive-in movie theaters are permitted to re-open, while indoor movie and performance theaters must remain closed. On 20200618, eased as indoor movie and performance theaters are permitted to re-open for indoor services at up to 50 pct capacity, adhering to social distancing, etc. For large indoor performance venues, capacity limits are based on the (quote) Social Distancing Space Calculator (quote) wherein up to 175 can be at outdoor venues and up to 100 people at indoor venues.

Starting June 4, houses of worship can have up to 50 pct capacity or 50 people indoors (whichever is less), and only 6 ft distancing required for outdoor religious gatherings. Gathering limits of no more than 10 continue for non-religious gatherings. Requires mask use by staff, volunteers, and congregants. Starting on 20200915, substate gathering restrictions begin with the COVID19 Dial: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1wRxIxSUPE7NSQKf0wnr5P7BB2PAl9h_k/view

Eases restrictions on bars and like venues, allowing them to re-open under restricted oocupancy, health and safety protocols, etc. (quote) Effective June 18, 2020, bars, taverns, brew pubs, breweries, microbreweries, distillery pubs, wineries, tasting rooms, special licensees, clubs, and other places of public accommodation offering alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption, referred to as Bars, may operate with the lesser of 25 pct of the posted occupancy limit or 50 patrons, whichever is less (quote).

Movie and performance theaters and like venues are permitted to re-open at 50 pct capacity, distancing requirements, etc. With COVID19 dial implementation, these limits remain at 50 pct but total number of people permitted varies by level: 100 for indoor and 175 for outdoor for Safer at Home Level 2, 175 for indoor and 250 for outdoor for Safer at Home Level 1, and 500 for Protect Our Neighbors. Eases to some degree as more counties move to less restrictive levels, but counties are move to stricter ones as wel

Mandates that, at Goverment Offices and Facilities, all employees that interact in close proximity to with other employees or the public and all members of the public must wear medical or non-medical face coverings that cover the nose and mouth, as a condition of ingress or movement within such location. Considered a Mandate1 on PublicMaskLevel coding since it applies to the public in limited settings (government offices and facilities).

Effective July 1, on-premise consumption is no longer allowed and restricted operations are required for bars, taverns, brew pubs, breweries, wineries, tasting rooms, and other places of public accommodation offering alcholic beverages (can have delivery/take-out, off-premise consumption only). Bars that offer food from a licensed retail food establishment are permitted to operate akin to restaurants. Otherwise, bars and like venues have to close to take-away only. On 20200915, with some counties under the Protect Our Neighbors phase with the COVID19 Dial, those locations are permitted to have bars without food licenses to reopen at 50 pct capacity: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1wRxIxSUPE7NSQKf0wnr5P7BB2PAl9h_k/view Extended to 20201129 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1m_tYVWNTMJAuqt3kq9d2_6SNqrL7fLa7/view

Issues statewide mask order, requiring people in Colorado who are 11 years and older to wear a covering over their noses and mouths when entering or moving within any public indoor space, or while using or waiting to use public (buses, light-rail) or non-personal (taxis, car services, ride-shares) transportation services. Exemptions for individuals who cannot wear masks or face coverings due to medical conditions or disabilities, and does not require masks in outdoor spaces (though encourages such use). Includes worship services. In effect at midnight on 20200716, so coded to 20200717. Coded as a Mandate2 under PublicMaskLevel as it covers broadly covers indoor settings and explicitly does not require mask use in outdoor settings. Extended to 20200913 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20164%20Non%20Medical%20Face%20Covering.pdf Extended to 20201012 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20190%20Nonmedical%20Face%20Coverings.pdf Extended to 20201110 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20219%20Nonmedical%20Face%20Coverings.pdf Extended to 20201209: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20245%20Mask%20Order.pdf

Per school reopening guidance, masks are required of school employees and students aged 11 years and older during in-person instruction and indoors. Appears to follow similar requirements as the public mask mandate, and thus will code alongside the public mask mandate extensions. Extended to 20201209: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20245%20Mask%20Order.pdf

Eases bar restrictions for counties in Protect Our Neighbors phase, allowing them to re-open at 50 pct capacity. As of 20200915, this applies to 5 counties: Gilpin, Gunnison, Mesa, Moffat, Rio Blanco. These designations are based on the new COVID19 Dial, which is regularly updated but counties cannot fully move to a new phase until they have been in the same one for at least 2 weeks. https://covid19.colorado.gov/data/covid-19-dial/covid-19-dial-dashboard On 20201026 Mesa moves out of Protect Our Neighbors phase, requiring bars without food licenses to close https://covid19.colorado.gov/press-release/several-counties-moving-to-stricter-levels-on-colorados-covid-dial-to-protect-their Extended to 20201129 https://drive.google.com/file/d/1m_tYVWNTMJAuqt3kq9d2_6SNqrL7fLa7/view Extended to 20201228: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20265%20Dial.pdf

(quote) If an individual has tested positive for COVID-19 and/or has developed symptoms of COVID-19, including early or mild symptoms (such as cough and shortness of breath), they should be in isolation (staying away from others) until they are released by public health. (quote). Extended to 20201129: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1m_tYVWNTMJAuqt3kq9d2_6SNqrL7fLa7/view Extended to 20201228: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20265%20Dial.pdf

Counties in Protect Our Neighbors phase continue to have gathering limits of 500, and up to 500 people for indoor religious gatherings. Outdoor religious gatherings do not have numeric capacity limits, but 6 ft distancing must occur. As of 20200915, this applies to 5 counties: Gilpin, Gunnison, Mesa, Moffat, Rio Blanco. These designations are based on the new COVID19 Dial, which is regularly updated but counties cannot fully move to a new phase until they have been in the same one for at least 2 weeks. https://covid19.colorado.gov/data/covid-19-dial/covid-19-dial-dashboard. Extended to 20201105 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20213%20Safer%20at%20Home.pdf

Counties in Safer at Home Level 2 are permitted to have up to 10 people personal gatherings, and up to 50 people indoors (or 50 pct capacity, whichever is lower) for religious gatherings. Outdoor religious gatherings have no numeric limit but must have 6 ft social distancing. As of 20200915, this applies to 34 counties: Adams, Alamosa, Archuleta, Boulder, Broomfield, Chaffee, Conejos, Costilla, Custer, Denver, Eagle, Garfield, Grand, Jackson, Jefferson, Lake, La Plata, Logan, Montezuma, Montrose, Morgan, Phillips, Pitkin, Prowers, Pueblo, Rio Grande, Routt, Saguache, San Juan, San Miguel, Sedgwick, Summit, Washington, Weld. Easing began on 20200929, with Archuleta, La Plata, Montrose, and Prowers moving to Safer at Home Level 1: https://covid19.colorado.gov/data/covid-19-dial/covid-19-dial-dashboard. Extended to 20201105 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20213%20Safer%20at%20Home.pdf

Counties in Safer at Home Level 1 are permitted to have up to 25 people personal gatherings, and up to 175 people indoors (or 50 pct capacity, whichever is lower) for religious gatherings. Outdoor religious gatherings have no numeric limit but must have 6 ft social distancing. As of 20200915, this applies to 25 counties: Arapahoe, Baca, Bent, Cheyenne, Clear Creek, Crowley, Delta, Dolores, Douglas, Elbert, El Paso, Fremont, Hinsdale, Huerfano, Kiowa, Kit Carson, Larimer, Las Animas, Lincoln, Mineral, Otero, Ouray, Park, Teller, Yuma. Extended to 20201105 https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20213%20Safer%20at%20Home.pdf On 20201013, Routt moves to Safer at Home Level 1: https://covid19.colorado.gov/data/covid-19-dial/covid-19-dial-dashboard

For Safer at Home Levels 2 and 1, the following businesses remain closed: casinos, amusement parks, use of bounce houses and ball pits in any public or commercial venue. Closure of at least some of these businesses continues, though casinos now can re-open at reduced capacity at Levels Blue and Yellow (previously Safer at Home Levels 1 and 2): https://drive.google.com/file/d/1m_tYVWNTMJAuqt3kq9d2_6SNqrL7fLa7/view Extended to 20201228: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20265%20Dial.pdf

Starting October 23, gathering restriction becomes up to 10 people from no more than 2 households statewide. Extended to 20201129: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1m_tYVWNTMJAuqt3kq9d2_6SNqrL7fLa7/view

For Red Level counties, gatherings outside of ones immediate household are prohibited, so coding as 0. Up to 50 people indoors permitted for religious gatherings, no explicit limit for outdoor religious gatherings beyond 6 ft distancing. Starting on 20201120, Adams, Arapahoe, Boulder, Broomfield, Clear Creek, Denver, Douglas, Jefferson, La Plata, Larimer, Logan, Mesa, Morgan, Routt, Summit, Washington at are at Level Red (having moved from a combination of Level Blue, Level Yellow, Level Orange). Extended to 20201228: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20265%20Dial.pdf

Level Red counties can only have the following businesses be open outdoors (no indoor in-person services): smoking lounges, performance theaters and movie theaters, sporting events and practices, receptions, events, non-critical auctions, trade shows, markets, malls, rodeos, fairs, festivals and parades.

Level Red counties must close restaurants and like venues for indoor services, outdoor may occur if tables are limited to household members only and at least 6 ft distancing between tables. No on-premise alcohol sales/consumption between 8 pm and 7 am. As of 20201120, Adams, Arapahoe, Boulder, Broomfield, Clear Creek, Denver, Douglas, Jefferson, La Plata, Larimer, Logan, Mesa, Morgan, Routt, Summit, Washington at are at Level Red (having moved from a combination of Level Blue, Level Yellow, Level Orange). Extended to 20201228: https://www.colorado.gov/governor/sites/default/files/inline-files/D%202020%20265%20Dial.pdf

Extends the following: for all other counties (all levels but Level Green), bars without food licenses to remain closed for in-person services. This category of businesses may remain open for on-premise cconsumption if it is a licensed food establishment and it falls within the corresponding restrictions for a given transmission level, wherein food is served and tables are set with at least 6 ft physical distancing between tables.

Extends gathering restriction of up to 10 people from no more than 2 households for remaining counties, permits up to 50 people indoors for religious gatherings, no explicit limit for outdoor religious gatherings beyond 6 ft distancing. Applicable to Levels Green to Orange.

Levels Orange to Green counties can have restaurants and like venues open for indoor services but at varying levels of capacity (25 pct for Orange, 50 pct for Yellow, Blue, and Green, but different absolute numbers).

Declares a public health emergency and civil preparedness emergency that shall remain in effect through 20200909, so coded to 20200910. Extended to 20210209 https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/News/20200901-Renewed-COVID-19-Emergency-Declarations.pdf
Gatherings of 250 or more are prohibited and shall remain in effect until midnight on 20200430
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Public school school closure issuance, EO 7L extended closure to at least April 20. Extended to the end of the school year on May 5 . On 20200518, extended for summer educational programs for public schools through 20200706. Limited in-person operations for summer schools are allowed as of 20200706, hence coded as an easing. Governor's presser on 20200727 indicated that decisions about school opening would be devolved to county and district level.
LastUpdatedNotes: Deleted DateExpiry, added DateEased and updated PolicyCodingNotes.

PolicyCodingNotes: Limited operations required for bars. Extended to 20200926 https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-9.pdf. Extended to 20201109. https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-9D.pdf Extended to 20210209 https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-9K.pdf
Gatherings of 50 or more are prohibited through April 30, so coded to 20200501.

Closure required: gyms, fitness studios, movie theaters. Eased on 20200520: https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-7PP.pdf?la=en. Eased on 20200616 subject to business health rules extended in order (DECD Sector Rules): https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-7ZZ.pdf. Eased on 20201006 in accordance with Phase III rules: https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/Covid-19-Knowledge-Base/Phase-3-reopen. Extends eased rules on 20201106: https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-9K.pdf. Expanded on 20201120 for team sports and certain businesses, which now must follow DECD rules until 20210209: https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-9M.pdf.

Limited operations required: restaurants  (only can serve for off-premise consumption). Effective 20200520 outdoor dining permitted. The remaining provisions prohibiting indoor dining are extended to 20200620 https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-7PP.pdf?la=en.  https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-7ZZ.pdf. Further eased to allow indoor dining up to 50 pct on 20200616 https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-7ZZ.pdf Expanded on 20201106 https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-9K.pdf

Closure required: shopping malls and other places of public amusement - EO 7F. Order on 20200616 eases: https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-7ZZ.pdf. Eased on 20201006 in accordance with Phase III rules: https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/Covid-19-Knowledge-Base/Phase-3-reopen. Extends eased rules on 20201106: https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-9K.pdf.

Non-essential businesses close at 800 pm on 2020323 (EO 7H). Some businesses are allowed to reopen effective 20200520 pursuant to the Sector Rules. Operations of any indoor gym, fitness center, or similar facility or studio offering inperson fitness, sporting or recreational opportunities or instructions, and all movie theaters, are still prohibited and extended through June 20, 2020. https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-7PP.pdf?la=en.  Restrictions on  betting tracks continue until 20200721: https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-7ZZ.pdf
Being coded as 0 for mandate as the executive order does not explicitly ask people to stay at home. Press release encourages staying at home
Gathering restriction to more no more than 5 people. Excludes religious and spiritual and worship gatherings
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Any person in a public place in Connecticut who is unable to or does not maintain a safe social distance of approximately six feet from every other person shall cover their mouth and nose with a mask or cloth face-covering. Also must use mask or face covering in transportation services. Coded as a Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as this applies to all public places, and does not distinguish between indoor or outdoor settings (and thus is applicable in all public places). Extended for 6 months on 20200814, so coding to 20210212 (182 days later) - this extension also includes a small expansion, requiring documentation for medical exemptions: https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-7NNN.pdf. Extended to 20210209 on 20201109: https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-9L.pdf

Eased gathering restriction of 5 to 10 people for indoor settings. (quote) indoor social and recreational gatherings as described in Executive Order No. 7D, Section 1 are permitted for up to and including ten (10) people (quote). . However, religious gatherings are exempt quote) effective immediately, the 49-person limit on religious, spiritual and worship gatherings is raised for indoor gatherings to 25 percent of capacity of the indoor space or a maximum of 100 people, whichever is smaller, and to 150 people for outdoor gatherings (quote)
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Eases gathering restrictions for both indoor and outdoor gatherings. Restrictions are (quote) amended to permit social and recreational gatherings pursuant to DECD Rules for Gatherings and Venues and Sector Rules for Outdoor Events (quote), and thus permit up to 25 people for indoor private gatherings and 100 for outdoor private gatherings (e.g., weddings, reunions, parties). Religious gatherings indoors are capped at 25 pct capacity or 100 people, and then up to 150 people outdoors. Easing begins on 20201008 with Phase 3: https://portal.ct.gov/Coronavirus/Covid-19-Knowledge-Base/Phase-3-reopen

Travelers entering Connecticut from a state with a positive test rate higher than 10 per 100,000 residents, or higher than a 10 pct test positivity rate over a seven-day rolling average, shall self-quarantine for a period of 14 days. PolicyCodingNotes: Eases gathering restrictions, such that indoor gatherings can be up to 100 people (or 50 pct capacity) in commercial establishment or places of business (only up to 25 for private residences) and 150 for outdoor gatherings. Indoor religious gatherings are limited up to 200 people (or 50 pct capacity), while outdoor religious gatherings have no absolute numeric limit (50 pct capacity and 6 ft spacing). Masks and social distancing required in all gatherings. https://portal.ct.gov/-/media/Office-of-the-Governor/Executive-Orders/Lamont-Executive-Orders/Executive-Order-No-9F.pdf

Expands gathering restrictions as the state returns to Phase II restrictions for gatherings. Indoor gatherings now have a cap of 25 people in commercial establishment or places of business (only up to 10 for private residences) and 50 for outdoor gatherings (10 people for private residences). Religious indoor gatherings are limited to 100 people (or 50 pct capacity) while outdoor religious gatherings have no absolute numeric limit (50 pct capacity and 6 ft spacing).  Masks and social distancing required in all gatherings

Advisory for all Connecticut residents to stay home between the hours of 10 p.m. to 5 a.m. in order to reduce the risk of further viral transmission. High-risk individuals should take extra precautions.

Mandatory face coverings, (quote) All individuals must wear a face covering, except where doing so would inhibit that individuals health or where the individual is under two years of age (quote). Applies to riding public transportation or in other types of vehicles (taxis, private car service, ride sharing), customer of any businesses (including, but not limited to, grocery stores, convenience stores, supermarkets, laundromats, and restaurants, both inside the business and when waiting in line outside), when obstaining services from a healthcare provider, when they are in an outdoor public area if maintaining social distancing is not possible, and when they are in any public area and are feeling sick, coughing, or sneezing. Coded as a PublicMaskLevel Mandate3 as it requires mask wearing in any business and outdoor public spaces. Eighteenth modification of state emergency includes and easing restrictions for houses of worship. These places (quote) may conduct in-person services or activities at which attendance may reach a maximum of 30 pct of stated fire occupancy requirements (quote).

All persons are prohibited from gathering indoors or in partially enclosed spaces in groups of ten (10) or more people until after June 15, 2020. Gatherings up to 250 are permitted in unenclosed outdoor spaces, or tents if protocols are followed, for outdoor events. Lists detailed requirements for hosting an event up to 250 people (i.e., following distancing guidelines, must wear face coverings)

Recommends vulnerable individuals to continue staying home. Does not explicitly require teachers or school staff to wear face coverings in this order. Expands gathering restriction for indoor and outdoor gatherings, prohibiting more than 50 people. (quote) Houses of Worship may continue to offer in-person worship services, provided, however, that the total number of guests permitted in a House of Worship at any one time shall not exceed the lesser of 30 pct of that House of Worship’s stated fire occupancy or 100 guests. (quote). Extended to 20201225 https://governor.delaware.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/24/2020/11/Ninth-Extension-of-State-of-Emergency-11252020.pdf

Expands restrictions for indoor gatherings, prohibiting more than 10 people in both public and private gatherings. Outdoor gatherings remain limited to 50 people. Eases restrictions for religious gatherings, which now have no stated numerical limit, only a capacity limit. (quote) Notwithstanding the indoor gathering occupancy limits set forth in Paragraph N.2, Houses of Worship may continue operations or reopen provided, however, that the total number of guests permitted in a House of Worship at any one time shall not exceed forty percent (40pct) of that House of Worship’s stated fire occupancy. (quote).

Expands recommendation to stay home to all Delawareans, not just vulnerable individuals. (quote) Beginning on Monday, December 14, 2020 and ending on January 11, 2021 unless expressly extended, Delaware residents are advised and strongly encouraged to stay home as often as possible and to only leave home to go to work or school, or for necessary needs such as seeking medical care, going to the grocery store or pharmacy, or picking up food. (quote)
