Issued 20200324, in effect at 10 pm on 20200325 Extended to 20201010 https://mayor.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/mayormb/release_content/attachments/Mayor%27s%20Order%202020-079%20Extension%20of%20the%20Public%20Emergency%20.pdf Extended to 20210101 https://mayor.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/mayormb/release_content/attachments/Mayor%27s%20Order%202020-103.pdf
(quote) All individuals living in Washington, DC, are order to stay at their place of residence, except as specified in this order (quote)

People using ride share programs, taxis, or other private transportation vehicles are required to wear masks or face coverings. Also recommends wearing masks on public transportation. Coded as Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as it is a mandate one specific arena for the public (i.e., ride-share, taxis, and private transportation). On 20200513, expands mandate to cover all types of transportation, but still coded to Mandate1 for only applying to a specific sector: https://coronavirus.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/page_content/attachments/Mayors-Order-2020-066-Extensions-of-Public-Emergency-and-Public-Health.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateExpiry to 20200609, removed DateEased, added Mandate1 to PublicMaskLevel, updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) DOH guidance relating to masks must be followed (quote), thus making the following guidelines for mask use mandatory: masks and face coverings for the general public, indicating that the general public should wear a cloth face covering when taking care of people with suspected or confirmed COVID-19, entering a healthcare providers office, entering a public setting where social distancing is difficult to maintain (e.g., grocery store pharmacy), or if you are having respiratory symptoms. Also expands the mask mandate for wearing face coverings on transportation. Coded as Mandate2. because it does not expressly require masks or facial coverings across all public settings (indoor and outdoor), and due to its less than direct mandate approach (i.e., must follow guidance from DOH) versus expressly mandating masks. On 20200622, eased to a recommendation with Phase 2: https://coronavirus.dc.gov/phasetwo

Establishes eased gathering rule for religious groups. (quote) Places of worship may operate with expanded capacity limits. In no event shall attendance at any service exceed fifty percent (50%) of the capacity of the facility or one hundred (100) persons, whichever is fewer (quote). Also eases the overall restriction for nonreligious gatherings from 10 to 50 - both indoor and outdoor. (quote) The prohibition on large gatherings of more than ten (10) individuals, in force since March 24, 2020 (Mayors Order 2020-053), is repealed and replaced by a prohibition on mass gatherings of over fifty (50) persons (quote) Extended to 20210101 https://mayor.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/mayormb/release_content/attachments/Mayor%27s%20Order%202020-103.pdf

Eases mask policy to a recommendation for the broader public, while still requiring masks to be worn by customers upon entering or waiting in line to enter essential businesses such as grocery stores and pharmacies. Coded to Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies to limited settings.
During Phase 2 of reopening starting on 20200622 school buildings can open under certain guidelines

Mask requirement applies whether in an indoor space, such as the common areas of apartments, condos and cooperatives, or businesses or other establishments open to the public, or public transportation, or in a public outdoor space where maintaining a six-foot social distance is not always possible. Exemptions include for individuals under the age of 2 yeras old, due to medical conditions or disabilities, etc. Coded as Mandate3 as it applies to both indoor and outdoor settings. Extended to 20210101 https://mayor.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/mayormb/release_content/attachments/Mayor%27s%20Order%202020-103.pdf

Quarantine order for entry into DC (quote) All residents and persons traveling to or from high-risk areas within the prior fourteen (14) days for non-essential travel must self-quarantine for fourteen (14) days following their return or arrival to the District (quote). Maryland and Virginia are exempt from high risk area label. As of 20200727, these states are as follows (and will be updated on 20200810): Arkansas, Arizona, Alabama, California, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Iowa, Kansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Mexico, North Carolina, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Washington, Wisconsin https://mayor.dc.gov/release/dc-health-releases-list-high-risk-states As of 20200810 the list of states is as follows: Alabama, Alaska, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Minnesota, Mississippi, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Mexico, North Carolina, North Dakota, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Wisconsin https://mayor.dc.gov/release/dc-health-releases-updated-list-high-risk-states On 20200824 states that were added to the updated list include: Delaware, Hawaii, and South Dakota and states that were removed include Montana and New Mexico https://mayor.dc.gov/release/dc-health-releases-updated-list-high-risk-states-8-24-2020.  Delaware is removed from the list on 20200827: https://mayor.dc.gov/release/dc-health-updates-list-high-risk-states On 20200908 Montana and Ohio are added to the list and Alaska and Arizona are removed https://mayor.dc.gov/release/dc-health-releases-updated-list-high-risk-states-sept8 On 20200921 Alaska, Arizona, Delaware, West Virginia, and Wyoming are added to the list. California, Hawaii, and Ohio are removed. https://mayor.dc.gov/release/dc-health-releases-updated-list-high-risk-states-september-21-2020. On 20201002, Arizona is removed and New Mexico is added to the list. https://mayor.dc.gov/release/dc-health-releases-updated-list-high-risk-states-oct-5-2020  Extended to 20210101 https://mayor.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/mayormb/release_content/attachments/Mayor%27s%20Order%202020-103.pdf. On 20201019, Arizona, Colorado, Connecticut, Massachusetts, Michigan, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and Rhode Island are added to the list: https://mayor.dc.gov/release/dc-health-releases-updated-list-high-risk-states-october-19-2020. On 20201102, California, New Jersey, and Oregon are added to the list: https://mayor.dc.gov/release/dc-health-releases-updated-list-high-risk-states-november-2-2020. On 20201109, eases quarantine restrictions. Instead of self-quarantining for 14 days, travelers from states not considered low-risk can choose to limit daily activities until they obtain a test for COVID-19 within three to five (5) days after their arrival and have received a negative COVID-19 PCR test result. https://mayor.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/mayormb/release_content/attachments/MO-2020-110.pdf. Extended on 20201123. Hawaii is the only state considered low-risk and Maryland and Virginia are exempt https://coronavirus.dc.gov/phasetwo

DC mandates remote education until at least 20201106 on 20200730: https://mayor.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/page_content/attachments/School-Year-20-21-Presentation_07-30-20.pdf   On 20201005 the mayor announces that elementary schools will reopen for Term 2 starting 20201109. Other schools remain closed. https://dcpsreopenstrong.com/ Schools will not reopen for in person instruction on 20201109 https://dcpsreopenstrong.com/updates/changes-to-school-reopening-plans/

Expands gathering restrictions. Indoor gatherings cannot exceed 10 people (from 50), and outdoor gatherings cannot exceed 25 people (from 50). Expands indoor gathering limits for places of worship, which may now operate at the lesser of 50 people (from 100) or 50 pct capacity. Does not specify changes to outdoor gathering limits for places of worship, so remains at 100 people. Eased on 20201217: https://mayor.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/coronavirus/release_content/attachments/Mayor%27s%20Order%202020-126.pdf.

Eases gathering restrictions for houses of worship. Houses of worship may allow the lesser of 25 pct occupancy or 250 people (including worshippers, clergy, and staff) indoors. Continues social gathering limits. Indoor gatherings cannot exceed 10 people, and outdoor gatherings cannot exceed 25 people. Houses of worship not subject to numeric caps outdoors.

Public Health Emergency declared. Extended to 20200905: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-166.pdf. Extended to 20201104: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-213.pdf. Bars, pubs, and any licensee authorized to sell alcholic beverages on premises that derive more than 50 pct of gross revenue from sale of alcoholic beverage must suspend the sale of alcoholic beverages for 30 days, effective 20200317. Such vendors may continue to sell alcoholic beverages in sealed containers for consumption off-premises. Easing began for all Phase 2 counties (all counties except for Miami-Date, Broward, and Palm Beach) on 20200605: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-139.pdf  Reimposes limits for on-premises consumption on 20200626: http://www.myfloridalicense.com/dbpr/os/documents/EO_2020-09.pdf  On 20200925, Phase 3 ends restrictions on bars, pubs, and any licensee authorized to sell alcholic beverages on premises that derive more than 50 pct of gross revenue from sale of alcoholic beverages. Can operate at full capacity. https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-244.pdf

Closure required: nightclubs. Extended closure in Phase 2: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-139.pdf.  On 20200925, Phase 3 ends restrictions on nightclubs, they can operate at full capacity. https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-244.pdf

On 20200317, 50 pct capacity ordered, expanded to full limited operations on 20200320. Began easing restrictions for most counties starting on 20200504 https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-112.pdf. More easing on 20200518 to allow 50 pct occupancy statewide  By 20200914, full state is at Phase 2 eased restrictions (allowing for up to 50 pct indoor capacity for indoor services, bar areas may reopen for seated service, and outdoor seating is fully permissible with appropriate social distancing): https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-223.pdf On 20200925, Phase 3 ends restrictions on restaurants and they can now operate at full capacity. https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-244.pdf

PolicyCodingNotes: Establishes an essential services list wherein by omission, closure of in-person services may be enforced (eg, non-essential retail). Easing begins on 20200504 for in-person retail (conditional on maximum 25 pct capacity and must abided by safety guidelines from CDC) and museums and libraries (conditional on 25 pct capacity maximum and interactive functions or exhibits remain closed) in counties that are not Miami-Dade, Broward and Palm Beach counties https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-112.pdf . On 20200511, Palm Beach county moves to Phase 1 in which (quote) Barbershops, cosmetology salons, and cosmetology specialty salons that adopt appropriate social distancing and precautionary measures (Quote) can reopen. On 2020904 Palm Beach moves to Phase 2, further easing business restrictions. By 20200914, full state is at Phase 2 eased restrictions: https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-223.pdf On 20200925, Phase 3 ends restrictions for in-person reatil, salons, barbershops, and all other businesses. https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-244.pdf

Specific clause for senior citizens to take all measures to limit risk of COVID-19. Ended on 20200504 https://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/orders/2020/EO_20-112.pdf

PolicyCodingNotes: Requires customers to wear a face covering while waiting to enter and while at an essential business or operation (e.g., grocery stores, pharmacies). Coded as a Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as it is applicable to very limited settings.  Completely omitted in the 10th COVID-19 supplementary declaration, effectively ending this order on 20200717: https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/2007090-ATG_Tenth-Supplementary-Proclamation-for-COVID-19-distribution-signed.pdf

Advises everyone to wear a mask or face covering when in public. Recommendation extended to 20200601 https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/2005024-ATG_Seventh-Supplementary-Proclamation-for-COVID-19-distribution-signed-1.pdf  Completely omitted in the 10th COVID-19 supplementary declaration, effectively ending this recommendation on 20200717: https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/2007090-ATG_Tenth-Supplementary-Proclamation-for-COVID-19-distribution-signed.pdf

(quote) Elderly and others at high risk for COVID-19 are urged to stay in their residences to the extent possible, except as necessary to seek medical care. (quote) Completely omitted in the 10th COVID-19 supplementary declaration, effectively ending this recommendation on 20200717: https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/2007090-ATG_Tenth-Supplementary-Proclamation-for-COVID-19-distribution-signed.pdf

Interisland travel quarantine will remain in place through Aug 31 (at least), so coded accordingly. Mandated self-quarantine requirement takes effect on Aug 11. (quote) all persons traveling to the Islands of Kauai, Hawaii, and the Islands comprising the Counties of Maui and Kalawao, in the State of Hawaii shall be subject to mandatory self quarantine. The period of self-quarantine shall begin from the date of entry onto the Island and shall last 14 days or the duration of the person’s presence on the Island, whichever is shorter (quote) Extended to 20210101: https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/2011051-ATG_Fifteenth-Proclamation-Related-to-the-COVID-19-Emergency-distribution-signed.pdf. Reeased on 20201217 to reduce isolation period from 14 days to 10 days and extended to 20210215: https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/2012088-ATG_Seventeenth-Proclamation-Related-to-the-COVID-19-Emergency-distribution-signed.pdf.

(quote) All individuals shall wear face coverings over their noses and mouths when in public settings (quote). Exemptions are for children under the age of 5, individuals who are medically unable to wear a face covering, when eating, or drinking, or when outdoors when at least 6 ft distancing can be mantained. Coded as a Mandate3 under PublicMaskLevel as it broadly applies across settings. Note that individual Hawaiian islands/counties have had mask mandates at this level at various points in time since May 2020 but this is the first statewide mask mandate at Mandate3. Extended to 20210215: https://governor.hawaii.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/2012088-ATG_Seventeenth-Proclamation-Related-to-the-COVID-19-Emergency-distribution-signed.pdf.

Through the end of March, Idahoans are encouraged to avoid social gatherings of more than 10 people.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateEnacted to 20200318 (was 20200401) and added DateExpiry of 20200401, updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict

PolicyCodingNotes: Blaine County put under shelter in place on 20200319
Bars must close in Blaine County per the non-essential business closure
(quote) Gatherings of individuals outside the home are prohibited (quote). Applicable to Blaine County only.

(quote) All businesses with a facility in Blaine County, except Essential Businesses as defined below in Section 8, are required to cease all activities at facilities located in the County except Minimum Basic Operations (quote). Also explicitly closes nightclubs, as well as indoor gyms and recreation facilities, Blaine County.
Limited operations required (takeout and delivery only): restaurants and cafes. Applicable to Blaine County only. In effect at 1159 pm on 2020320 (coded to 20200321)

On 20200323, all public schools are directed to have a (quote) soft closure (quote)(changed 20200331). The soft closure is because school districts are mantaining food services for needy students for pickup and enacting distance learning.  The EO does not have an enact date so is assumed to go into effect immediately. Soft closure extended to end of academic year by Department of Education .  Board of DOE approves framework that provides local districts with critera to make localized decisions about reopened on 20200709: https://boardofed.idaho.gov/resources/board-approves-school-reopening-framework/
Closes bars statewide. Eased as part of Stage 3 on 20200530 https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/stay-healthy-order-stage3.pdf

In effect at 130 pm on 20200325, until 1159 pm 20200415 (coded to 20200416). (quote) Limit all non-essential gatherings of any number of individuals outside the household (quote). Includes faith-based activity, with the exception of funerals as long as they comply with social distancing requirements. On 20200501, mandate became a recommendation, ending the formal gathering restriction: https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/stay-healthy-order-stage1.pdf

In effect at 130 pm on 20200325, until 1159 pm 20200415 (coded to 20200416). All businesses with a facility in the State of Idaho except Essential Businesses are required to cease all activities. Also explicitly closes nightclubs, also closes all indoor gyms and recreation facilities. On 20200501, eases restrictions on the operations of in-person businesses in their physical locations unless they were exempted: https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/stay-healthy-order-stage1.pdf On 20200516, eases restrictions on indoor gyms and fitness centers, as well as personal care services: https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/stay-healthy-order-stage2.pdf On 20200530, indoor movie theaters can reopen: https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/stay-healthy-order-stage3.pdf On 20200611, ends all mandated restrictions: https://rebound.idaho.gov/stage-4-stay-healthy-guidelines/
LastUpdatedNotes: Added FullClose to BusinessRestrictLevel and updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: Limited operations (drive-thru, carry-out,delivery still permitted) as of non-essential business closure. Continues to have restrictions under Stay Healthy Order https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/stay-healthy-order-stage1.pdf

In effect at 130 pm on 20200325. Expiry is currently 1159 pm on 20200415, extended to 20200430 on 20200415. Ended on 20200501 https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/stay-healthy-order-stage1.pdf
Department of Public Health recommendation on the use of cloth face coverings. Additional extensions are issued alongside shifts to new stages

The amendment the stay-at-home order to include this travel restriction (Section 7) was included on 20200415. (Quote) Persons entering the state of Idaho are required to self-quarantine for 14 days. (Quote). Quarantine continued on 20200501 without expiry https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/stay-healthy-order-stage1.pdf. Ended the mandate, went to a recommendation on 20200516: https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/stay-healthy-order-stage2.pdf

(quote) Persons who have tested positive for COVID-19, are presumptively diagnosed with COVID-19, or are exhibiting symptoms identified in the CDC screening guidance shall not enter the state of Idaho unless doing so under medical orders for the purposes of medical care, are being transported by emergency personnel, are being driven directly to a medical provider for purposes of medical care, or are a resident of the state of Idaho. (quote) Ends on 20200516, replaces with recommendation: https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/stay-healthy-order-stage2.pdf

(quote) Intrastate travel is prohibited, including but not limited to, travel on scooter, motorcycle, automobile, or public transit, except for those purposes defined in Section 8. People must use public transit only for purposes of performing Essential Activities or to travel to and from work to operate Essential Businesses or maintain Essential Governmental Functions (quote)

(quote) gatherings, both public and private, should be avoided (quote) as part of stage 1. Eased on 20200516 with introduction of gathering recommendation of 10: https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/stay-healthy-order-stage2.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed numeric limits for religious gatherings, updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: Recommends that vulnerable individuals (per CDC definitions) continue to self-isolate via staying at home. Ended on 20200530: https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/stay-healthy-order-stage3.pdf

Recommendation that gathering or more than 10 people, both private and public, should be avoided. Eased on 20200530 https://coronavirus.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/stay-healthy-order-stage3.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed numeric limits for religious gatherings, updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) individuals arriving in Idaho from another country or from an area outside of Idaho with substantial community spread are strongly encouraged to self-quarantine (quote). Ended as part of transition to Stage 4 on 20200611:  https://rebound.idaho.gov/stage-4-stay-healthy-guidelines/

Restaurants are permitted to re-open upon their plans being approved by local public health districts. No explicit capacity limits are provided so leaving those variables blank. Per Stage 2 order,  All businesses resuming in-person services must adhere to sanitation and distancing requirements (at least 6 feet between individuals) and businesses are required to development and implement measures to ensure this kind of physical distancing. Reopening guidance: https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/Protocols_RestaurantsD1026-01.pdf Ends on 20200611 when it goes to recommended guidelines: https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/stage4-protocols-restaurants.pdf

(quote) persons who have tested positive for COVID-19, are presumptively diagnosed...should not enter Idaho (quote). Ended travel recommendation on 20200611: https://rebound.idaho.gov/stage-4-stay-healthy-guidelines/

Eases restrictions on bars, allowing them to reopen as part of Stage 3. No explicit capacity limits are provided so leaving those variables blank. All patrons must be seated. Per Stage 3 order,  All businesses resuming in-person services must adhere to sanitation and distancing requirements (at least 6 feet between individuals) and businesses are required to development and implement measures to ensure this kind of physical distancing. Specific guidelines for bar and like venue reopening are here: https://rebound.idaho.gov/wp-content/uploads/Protocols_BarsBreweriesD1026-03.pdf Ended on 20200611: https://rebound.idaho.gov/stage-4-stay-healthy-guidelines/

Eases gathering recommendation to up to 50, Idaho remains in stage 3. Not mandated (quote) Gatherings of more than 50 people, both public and private, should be avoided. People participating in gatherings of 50 or fewer people, while permitted, should adhere to the Social Distancing and Sanitation Requirements in Section 7. (quote) Ended state movement to Stage 4 on 20200611: https://rebound.idaho.gov/stage-4-stay-healthy-guidelines/
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed numeric limits for religious gatherings, updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: Idaho moves back to Stage 3 and implements gathering restrictions. Indoor limit is 50 individuals and outdoor capacity limit is 25 pct of max occupancy. Gatherings for political expression and religious activities are exempt.
(quote) Gatherings of more than 10 people, both public and private, are prohibited. (quote) This is applies both indoors and outdoors, but religious gateherings are exempt.

(quote) People at increased risk for severe illness should self-isolate. Because of the risk of the rapid spread of the virus, and the need to protect all citizens of the State ofldaho, this Order strongly encourages individuals at increased risk anywhere in Idaho to stay at home (quote)

Detailed guidelines and protocols for resuming in-person instruction under Phase 3 (and beyond). (quote) All individuals in school buildings, including all public and nonpublic schools that serve students in prekindergarten through grade 12, must wear face coverings at all times unless they are younger than 2 years of age; have trouble breathing; or are unconscious, incapacitated, or otherwise unable to remove the cover without assistance (quote). Also must adhere to Phase 3 restrictions on gatherings (e.g., no more than 10 people in a single gathering), symptom screenings and temperature checks, and schoolwide cleaning and disinfection.

In Stage 2, (quote) when outside of homes or residences, individuals are strongly encouraged to wear face coverings (quote). In addition, in both stages, individuals riding on public transportation are strongly encouraged to wear face coverings.
Eases restrictions, lifting the limits on religious gatherings but still requires at least 6 ft social distancing, sanitation, etc. Otherwise, no more than 25 people social gatherings

Requires all employees and staff at restaurants as well as personal care services to wear face coverings as they are permitted to re-open. Also requires bars and gyms/fitness centers to have employees wear face coverings as they reopen

Eases restrictions on restaurants (including social clubs and wineries), can start in-person dining if they follow the following protocols: no more than 50 percent capacity, bar areas remain closed, social distancing and sanitation, all employees and staff wear face coverings. Applicable to all Indiana counties that are not Lake, Marion, and Cass (still in stage 1)

PolicyCodingNotes: For all counties but Elkhart (which remains in Stage 4), Stage 4.5 allows for the resumption of fairs, festivals, parades and other places of public amusement. For outdoor venues, events must ensure social distancing can be maintained and sanitation measures are in place. For indoor venues, maximum of 50 pct occupancy in addition to social distancing measures. Face coverings strongly recommended. Also youth overnight camps may open conditional on screenings, recommended face coverings

Requires wearing individuals 8 years old and older to wear a mask or other face covering in public indoor spaces (inclusive of commercial entities), public transportation and vehicle services (inclusive of taxis and ride shares), and outdoor public spaces when social distancing from others is not possible.Makes exemptions for private offices, private workspaces, and meetings where 6 ft of social distancing can be achieved, as well as children under the age of 2 years, individuals with with a medical condition or disability preventing the wearing of a face covering, when engaging in sports, attending/engaged in a religious service where social distancing is occuring of at least 6 ft. Coded as a Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly to indoor and outdoor settings. Formal EO was signed on 20200724, so coding that date to the DateIssued versus the date announced (20200722). Applies to the following counties: Adair, Adams, Appanoose, Audubon, Boone, Buchanan, Buena Vista, Butler, Calhoun, Carroll, Cass, Cedar, Cerro Gordo, Cherokee, Chickasaw, Clarke, Clay, Clayton, Clinton, Crawford, Davis, Decatur, Delaware, Dickinson, Emmet, Floyd, Franklin, Fremont, Greene, Grundy, Guthrie, Hamilton, Hancock, Hardin, Harrison, Howard, Humboldt, Ida, Jackson, Jefferson, Jones, Keokuk, Kossuth, Lee, Lucas, Lyon, Madison, Mahaska, Marion, Mills, Mitchell, Monona, Monroe, Montgomery, O'Brien, Osceola, Page, Palo Alto, Plymouth, Pocahontas, Pottawattamie, Ringgold, Sac, Shelby, Sioux, Story, Taylor, Union, Van Buren, Wapello, Warren, Wayne, Webster, Winnebago, Winneshiek, Worth, Wright

Eases previous restrictions for remaining 22 counties, joining the statewide eased restrictions on malls and other retail establishments (i.e., up to 50 pct capacity). Note that for the 22 counties, fitness centers and gyms can only re-open for one person at a time and other businesses do not appear to be open yet. Joining this policies at present since retail accounts for the vast majority of these types of businesses - will ease this entry as needed as more restrictions are reduced. From the prior entry: allows re-opening of fitness centers, malls, libraries, race tracks, and other retail establishments if they follow requirements laid out in the EO (e.g., 50 percent capacity, adherence to social distancing, and hygiene and public health measures). Further eased on 20200615, no longer having capacity limits but must maintain physical distancing. Eases restrictions on close-contact personal care services (eg, salons, barbershops, tattoo establishments, massage therapy) conditional on being at no more than 50 percent capacity, being appointment only, practicing social distancing, other safety protocols recommended by department of public health. Further eased on 20200615, no longer having capacity limits but must maintain physical distancing. Extended to 20201211: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.11.16.pdf. Eases restaurant restrictions for 22 counties, joining the rest of the state with the same eased restaurant restrictions: restaurants to serve food for on-premises consumption if venues comply with the following: limit number of customers to 50 percent capacity, no group of customers can be more than 6 people and have to be at least 6 ft apart, no self-service food, and public health measures by the Iowa DOH. Further eased on 20200612, removing capacity limits but still requiring at least 6 ft distancing between groups, only seated service: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.06.10.pdf Extended to 20201201: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.11.10.pdf Extended to 20201211, though requiring restaurants to close from 10 pm to 6 am: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.11.16.pdf. Extended to 20201217 and requires no on-site food or drink service between 10pm and 4am: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.12.09.pdf. Extends restaurant restrictions, allowing them to reopen for normal business hours. Must follow physical distance (at least 6 ft) between each group and individual dining and broader social distancing, hygiene, and public health measures. Maximum group size of 8 per group. Masks are required for patrons when not seated. https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.12.16.pdf

Eases restrictions on movie theaters, allowing them to resume if at 50 percent capacity, social distancing, no self service of food or beverages. Also eases restrictions on pools for lap siwmming and swimming lessons if they follow social distancing, hygiene practices, and public health measures. Beyond these limited purposes, (quote) all swimming pools and spas, wading pools, ater slides, wave pools, spray pads, and bath houses...shall continue to be closed (quote). On 20200612, further eases restrictions, removing capacity limits but still requiring at least 6 ft of distancing: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.06.10.pdf Extended to 20201211: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.11.16.pdf. Extended to 20201217: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.12.09.pdf.

Starting on 20200916, only Johnson and Story continue to have bar closures, constituting an easing: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.09.15.pdf

Strongly encourages Iowans two years and older to wear a mask when in public settings, especially when it is not possible to remain six feet away from others.  Extended to 20201116: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.10.16.pdf.

Prohibits gatherings more than 25 people indoors and more than 100 people outdoors unless masks are worn by all people 2 and older and as long as 6 ft distancing is adhered to. Coding as an expansion of the previous gathering restriction, where only 6 ft distancing was required

Requires all people above the age of 2 years old to wear masks in gatherings more than 25 indoors and more than 100 outdoors (including outdoor spectator gatherings). Coded as a Mandate1 as it is limited to very specific settings (certain types of gatherings) and not broadly across indoor settings. Continues to encourage mask use more broadly, but not mandated

Indoor gatherings of more than 15 people and outdoor gatherings of more than 30 people are prohibited. Does not apply to individuals who live in the same household and spiritual or religious gatherings. Extended to 20201217: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.12.09.pdf.

(quote) all people two or older must wear a mask or other face covering when inside an indoor space that is open to the public and within six feet of individuals who are not members of their household for 15 minutes or longer (quote) Exemptions are for individuals who are medically unable to wear a mask, when eating/drinking, when participating in spiritual and religious services, etc. Also explicitly requires masks inside all Iowa state buildings. Coding as a Mandate2 under PublicMaskLevel as it applies across indoor settings. Note that the clause for more than 15 minutes makes this policy very low on the Mandate2 spectrum. Extended to 20210109: https://governor.iowa.gov/sites/default/files/documents/Public%20Health%20Proclamation%20-%202020.12.09.pdf.
Eases gathering restrictions. Gatherings of more than 10 may be held if the gathering complies with social distancing and other hygiene rules. Does not apply to religious gatherings.

PolicyCodingNotes: All businesses or organizations in Kansas must require employees to wear a mask or face covering when employees are working in any space visited by customers or members of the public, space where food is prepared or packaged for sale, working in or walking through common areas, in a room or any enclosed area where 6 ft distancing is not possible. Exceptions involve individuals with medical conditions, mental health conditions, or disabilities that prevent wearing a mask, where wearing a face covering could be a risk to their work per work safety guidelines for the sector.

Any person in Kansas shall cover their mouth and nose with a mask or other face covering when they are in the following: inside or in line to enter any indoor public space, obtaining services from the healthcare sector, waiting for or riding on public transportation or other modes of transportation (taxi, private car service, ride-sharing), outdoors in public spaces and unable to maintain a 6 ft distance between individuals. Exceptions involve individuals with medical conditions, mental health conditions, or disabilities that prevent wearing a mask, children under 5 (especially 2 and younger), people who are deaf or are hard of hearing, when seated at a restaurant, more listed in section 3. Coded as Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it requires mask use in across indoor and outdoor settings. Note that due to legislative action in June, counties had an opt-out option of the statewide mandate. As of July 8, about 80 out of 105 counties appeared to have opted out of compliance: https://www.aarp.org/health/healthy-living/info-2020/states-mask-mandates-coronavirus.html#Kansas Effective 20201125, governor aims to close county opt-out option: https://governor.kansas.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/EO-20-68-Face-Coverings-protocol-Executed-1.pdf
All students, faculty, staff and visitors to public or private K-12 schools must wear face coverings. Exemptions are made for children under the age of 5 years old, while eating, etc.
Declares State of Emergency. No explicit expiry provided.

Limited operations required (carry-out, delivery, drive thru only): bars. Bars are allowed to resume in-person services under health and safety requirements on 20200629

Limited operations required (carry-out, delivery, drive thru only): restaurants. Restaurants are allowed to resume in-person services under health and safety requirements on 20200522 https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/s1l356ZwRf6ZDTmKJBQo_5-22-2020,%20CHFS%20Order%20-%20Restaurants%20and%20Public-Facing%20Businesses.pdf

(quote) all public-facing businesses that encourage public congregation or, that by the nature of the service to the public, cannot comply with CDC guidelines concerning social distancing, shall cease all in-person operations (quote). Includes entertainment, hospitality and recreational facilities, community and recreation centers, gyms and exercise facilities, hair salons, nail salons, spas, concert venues, theaters, and sporting event facilities. Began easing on 20200522: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/RPrsUnlyQzql2yUygXmc_CHFS%20Order%20-%20Public-Facing%20Businesses.pdf

Gov. Beshear suspended all charitable gaming licenses, closing bingo halls temporarily, to protect patrons at those establishments after having previously issued new guidance on closing public-facing businesses.
Bans mass gatherings, does not clearly define mass gathering.

All in-person retail businesses that are not life-sustaining are order to close. Easing began on 20200520: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/g92cg1QISZiIbF4QwHDj_Executive%20Order%20and%20CHFS%20Order_May.pdf

(quote) Only life-sustaining businesses may remain open (quote). No clear expiry. Easing started on 20200511: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/1bt2tc4ATVGSBYI5W2YR_Executive%20Order%202020-323%20-%20Healthy%20at%20Work%20Reopening.pdf
Encourages (quote) all Kentuckians to remain Healthy at Home (quote)
Residents are instructed not to travel outside of state, and must self-quarantine for 14 days upon return. In effect till emergency declaration expires.
Residents are instructed not to travel outside of state except for essential business, and must self-quarantine for 14 days upon return. In effect till emergency declaration expires.
Residents of any other state may not travel into Kentucky except for in specific cases. In effect for duration of emergency

From Governor website on 20200404: ​In an added measure, Gov. Beshear said Kentucky is adopting on a voluntary basis the new guidance from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommending that people wear cloth masks in some situations. Gov. Beshear also stressed that wearing a cloth mask is a measure to be added to social distancing, not to replace it
Persons who have tested positive for COVID19, are presumptively diagnosed, or are exhibiting symptoms shall not enter the Commonwealth of Kentucky.

Eases restrictions on the following non-life sustaining businesses, conditional on their implementation and adherence to the states Healthy at Work guidelines: manufacturing distribution and supply chain businesses, vehicle and vessel dealerships, horse racing tracks (though no spectators), pet care and grooming services, photography businesses, office-based businesses at 50 percent capacity
In-person retail services are permitted to re-open, with a maximum of 33 pct capacity, required 6 ft distancing, etc.
Gatherings of up to ten people are allowed, religious organizations may have in-person gatherings of more than 10 and no more than 33 pct capacity
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Eases restaurant restrictions to allow for up to 33 percent maximum occupancy, at least 6 ft distancing, and detailed list of recommendations (eg, disposable menus, contactless methods of payment, entry and exit flows) and cleaning requirements. On 20200629, permits capacity up to 50 pct: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/FdYgPMSpRzG2iJHfbOle_6-29-2020%20CHFS%20Order%20-%20June%2029%20Healthy%20at%20Work%20Reopening.pdf On 20200728 must reduce indoor capacity to 25 pct: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/GlXFnrapT8Wp96HaFGBf_2020-7-27%20-%20Healthy%20At%20Work%20Reqs%20-%20Restaurants%20-%20Down%20to%2025-%20capacity%20-%20Final%20Version%204.0.pdf On 20200811, permits indoor capacity to increase to 50 pct: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/djRonZRbOeEIqGET6XBA_8-11-2020%20CHFS%20Order%20re%20Bars%20and%20Restaurants.pdf

Requires mask use by specific sectors as they re-open: personal care services (salons, barber shops, nail salons, tattoo parlors, tanning salons, etc). Recommends that customers wear face coverings, but does not explicitly require them. Adds more businesses to mask use requirements at businesses as more reopen, while the public mask mandate explicitly defers to the business guidance documents here: https://govstatus.egov.com/ky-healthy-at-work

Eases restrictions on the following close-contact personal care services: cosmetology businesses, hair salons and barbershops, massage therapy businesses, nail salons, tanning salons, and tattoo parlors. Requires a maximum of 33 pct capacity, customers are separated by at least 6 ft, etc. Eased on 20200625, allowing up to 50 pct capacity: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/tQ4d7UOzTdKJAJlLkkhh_CHFS%20Order%20-%20Public-Facing%20Businesses.pdf

Eases restrictions on previously closed businesses, allowing for in-person services if they comply with the minimum requirements set forth by Healthy at Work Kentucky: educational and cultural venues (aquariums, distilleries, libraries, museums, wineries, and limited outdoor programs), horse shows, casinos. For indoor venues, no more than 33 pct capacity is permitted, 6 ft distancing is required, etc.

Eases bar restrictions. Effective June 29 bars are allowed to offer service on-premises for up to 50 percent maximum occupancy, at least 6 ft distancing, and detailed list of recommendations (eg, disposable menus, contactless methods of payment, entry and exit flows) and cleaning requirements

Allows gatherings up to 50 people at a time, easing the previous gathering restrictions.Starting June 10, places of worship were permitted to resume in-person services up to 50 pct of capacity, which excludes them from the 50 person gathering restriction (also the May 9 order clearly exempts places of worship from these gathering restrictions): https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/r00brFxTl2TJkofBUZUh_Healthy%20at%20Work%20Reqs%20-%20Places%20of%20Worship%20-%20Final%20Version%202.0%20Final.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed numeric limits from religious gathering variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Eases restrictions on venues and event space, permitting the following to reopen at a maximum of 50 pct capacity, requiring at least 6 ft distancing between individuals: convention centers, hotel ballrooms and conference centers, music and concert halls, professional and amateur sporting/athletic stadiums and arenas, wedding venues, fairs, festivals, carnivals, and any other commercially operated events organized for more than 50 persons occurring at indoor and/or outdoor venues and event spaces. On 20201120, expands restrictions, limiting to no more than 25 people: https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20201118_Executive-Order_2020-968_State-of-Emergency.pdf

(quote) People in Kentucky must cover their nose and mouth with a face covering when they are in the following situations that represent a high risk of COVID-19 transmision (quote). Lists while inside or waiting in line to enter many businesses or indoor public space where it is difficult to physical distance, while waiting for or riding on public transportation or other vehicles (eg taxi, private car service, ride sharing), and in outdoor public spaces where physical distancing of 6 ft is not possible. Exemptions for children 5 years and younger, for individuals where wearing a mask would be unsafe (e.g., impairments, medical conditions), among others. In effect for 30 days after 5 pm on 20200710. Coded to Mandate3 as it applies to both indoor and outdoor settings. Extended to 20201007 https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20200904_Executive-Order_2020-750_Face-Coverings.pdf. Extended to 20201105 https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20201006_Executive-Order_2020-856_Reneweal_Face-Coverings.pdf Extended to 20201204: https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20201104_Executive-Order_2020-931_Face-Coverings.pdf Extended to 20210102: https://governor.ky.gov/attachments/20201203_Executive-Order_2020-996_Face-coverings.pdf

Imposes restriction on gatherings to no more than 10, increasing the restriction (it had been 50 previously). Previous restrictions on places of worship continue (no more than 50 pct capacity), so re-imposed restrictions do not include numeric limits on religious gatherings: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/r00brFxTl2TJkofBUZUh_Healthy%20at%20Work%20Reqs%20-%20Places%20of%20Worship%20-%20Final%20Version%202.0%20Final.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed numeric limits from religious gathering variables

PolicyCodingNotes: The advisory recommends a 14-day self-quarantine for travelers who went to any of eight states reporting positive testing rate equal to or greater than 15 percent-for COVID-19 testing. The advisory also includes one state quickly approaching a positive testing rate of 15 percent and one U.S. Territory. They include Alabama, Arizona, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Nevada, South Carolina and Texas, Mississippi and Puerto Rico. On 20200824 removes Arkansas, Kansas, Missouri, Florida from the quarantine advisory and adds South Carolina https://kentucky.gov/Pages/Activity-stream.aspx?n=GovernorBeshear&prId=328.   As of 20200923, they include South Dakota, Kansas, Iowa and Wisconsin, Idaho. The list appears to be updated daily but not reported consistently via any government sources, and thus they cannot be tracked in an ongoing manner.https://govstatus.egov.com/kycovid19
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated list of states in PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: All bars must cease in-person operations for onsite consumption, permitting the sale of alcoholic beverages by delivery, to-go, or carryout. This order was announced on 20200727, but formally issued and signed on 20200728. In effect for 14 days. Eased on 20200811 https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/djRonZRbOeEIqGET6XBA_8-11-2020%20CHFS%20Order%20re%20Bars%20and%20Restaurants.pdf
Bars may resume in-person operations for onsite consumption effective August 11, 2020. Bars must limit in-person services indoors to 50 pct of capacity and must close at 11 pm for onsite services.
(quote) The use of cloth face coverings (masks) should be required by all students and staff at all times while in the building or on the bus, unless medically waivered (quote)

Stay at home recommendation, coded as 0 for mandate. (quote) We need everybody to wear your masks and follow red zone reduction recommendations and school recommendations. It is a must if you want to lessen the impact in your community (quote). Red zone recommendations include (quote) Avoid non-essential activities outside of your home (quote)

Expands bar restrictions. Bars are no longer allowed to provide indoor service. Outdoor service is allowed (quote) provided that all customers are seated at tables, table size is limited to a maximum of 8 people from a maximum of 2 households, and tables are spaced a minimum of 6 feet apart. (quote)
Expands restriction on indoor gatherings to no more than 8 people (from 10) from no more than 2 households. Does not specify changes to outdoor gathering lmiits so kept at 10 people.

Expands restaurant restrictions. Restaurants are no longer allowed to provide indoor service. Outdoor service is allowed (quote) provided that all customers are seated at tables, table size is limited to a maximum of 8 people from a maximum of 2 households, and tables are spaced a minimum of 6 feet apart. (quote)

Requires that all public and private K-12 schools cease in-person instruction and transition to remote instruction beginning November 23. Will require that grades 6-12 remain remote until at least January 4, 2021 and may permit resumption on in-person instruction for K-5 from December 7 to January 4 if the school is not located in a red zone county

Public Health Emergency. Extended to 20200807: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/96-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana-Phase-2.pdf Extended to 20200828 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/102-JBE-2020-Renewal-of-state-of-emergency-for-covid-19.pdf. (quote) In an effort to reduce and limit the spread of COVID-19 in Louisiana, and to preserve the health and safety of all members of the public, all gatherings of 250 people or more between Friday, March 13,2020 and Monday, April 13, 2020 shall be postponed or cancelled (quote)

Public school closure, expiry date originally 20200413. Extended to the end of the year https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/modified/52-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-COVID-19-Extension-to-May-15.pdf While school districts can choose when to reopen, the state board of education has dictated a series of standards districts must meet before they reopen on 20200625. https://www.louisianabelieves.com/newsroom/news-releases/2020/06/25/louisiana-department-of-education-releases-2020-2021-school-reopening-guidance-in-concert-with-louisiana-department-of-health-and-resilient-louisiana-commission#:~:text=%2D%2D%20In%20partnership%20with%20the,the%20spread%20of%20COVID%2D19.
LastUpdatedNotes: Deleted DateReexpande1 and DateReeased1, updated BusinessRestrictLevel

PolicyCodingNotes: Bars shall cease operations completely, with an initial expiry of 20200413. Began easing on 20200605, allowing up to 25 pct capacity: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/74-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana-Phase-2.pdf
All gatherings of 50 people or more shall be postponed or cancelled. Issued on the 16th, into effect at midnight on the 17th.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Closure required: gyms, movie theaters, casinos. On 20200515, easing begins, permitting 25 pct capacity for gyms and fitness centers, casinos: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/58-JBE-2020.pdf

Limited operations required (only can do take-out, drive-thru, delivery): restaurants, cafes, coffee shops. Expiry date originally 20200413. On 20200402, order extends expiry to 20200430 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/41-JBE-2020-Stay-At-Home-Extended.pdf Eased on 20200501 to allow for outdoor service.

(quote) In an effort to reduce and limit the spread of COVID-19 in Louisiana, and to preserve the health and safety of all members of the public, all gatherings of 10 people or more shall be postponed or cancelled. (quote) Ended on 20200515 when mandate moved to recommendation: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/58-JBE-2020.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Requires more non-essential businesse to close, but not a full non-essential business closure policy. Expressly closes the following businesses as well: places of public amusement (including  amusement rides, carnivals, amusement parks, water parks, trampoline parks, aquariums, zoos, museums, arcades, fairs, pool halls, childrens play centers, playgrounds, theme parks, any theaters, concert and music halls, adult entertainment venues, racetracks), all personal care and grooming businesses, and all malls. Eases on 20200515 to permit malls and barbershops and salons to reopen to in-person services. Some portion of these businesses remain closed to 20201223: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/168-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-Renewing-COVID-19.pdf

Requires non-essential businesses (e.g., retail) to operate at no more than 10 people in a single room, adhere to at least 6 ft distancing. Eased on 20200515 to allow for 25 pct capacity: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/58-JBE-2020.pdf Further eased to 50 pct on 20200605: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/74-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana-Phase-2.pdf Further eases to 75 pct capacity on 20200911: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/117-JBE-2020-COVID-19-Public-Health-Emergency-Phase-3-of-Resilient-LA.pdf Expands limits to no more than 50 pct capacity on 20201125: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/168-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-Renewing-COVID-19.pdf

(quote) General stay-at-home order (quote). Effective at 5 pm on 20200323, expiry date originally 20200413. A 20200402 order extends expiry to 20200430 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/41-JBE-2020-Stay-At-Home-Extended.pdf. Mandates ends, moves to an advisory on 20200515 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/58-JBE-2020.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateExpiry to 20200515 and DateEnded to 20200515, removed DateEased

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) Everyone in Louisiana should wear masks when in public (quote) - in press release about extended stayathome order. Extended to 20200724 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/83-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana-Phase-2.pdf

Regulation for businesses and restaurants that reopen found in Section 2E - (quote) All businesses shall require that any owner or employee having interaction or contact with the public shall wear a mask or a face covering. (quote) Extended to 20201223 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/168-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-Renewing-COVID-19.pdf

Eases restaurant restrictions. (quote) Any establishment affected by this order may continue take out through curbside delivery and delivery services, however, in no circumstance shall the food or beverages purchased be consumed inside the premises. Restaurants, cafes, and coffee shops shall be allowed to have outdoor dining provided that the outdoor seating does not exceed 25 pct of the outdoor seating area in a configuration approved by the State Fire Marshal. (quote) Eased on 20200515 to allow for indoor services: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/58-JBE-2020.pdf

(quote) all individuals should avoid groups of any size that do not allow for strict social distancing (quote). No longer a required gathering restriction. Extended to 20200724 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/83-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana-Phase-2.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: Eases restrictions on a subset of businesses, allowing them to have in-person services under particular protocols (e.g., no more than 25 pct capacity, social distancing, mask wearing): beauty shops, salons, and barber shops, shopping malls, casinos, racetracks, and video poker, gyms and fitness centers. Capacity limits continued to decrease, to 50 pct on 20200605 and 75 pct on 2020091. Reexpanded restrictions on 202001125, reducing capacity limits to 50 pct for a number of these businesses

Further eases restrictions on restaurants, cafes, and coffee shops, allowing all establishments to have dine-in service if they remain at no more than 25 percent capacity, strict social distncing, wearing facial coverings, and waiting areas are closed. Easing on 20200605 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/74-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana-Phase-2.pdf Extended to 20200724 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/83-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana-Phase-2.pdf Extended to 20200807: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/96-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana-Phase-2.pdf Extended to 20200828 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/101-JBE-2020-covid-19-Public-Health-Emergency-Renewal-of-Phase-2.pdf Further eased on 20200911 and extended to 20201009 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/117-JBE-2020-COVID-19-Public-Health-Emergency-Phase-3-of-Resilient-LA.pdf. Replaces mandate with advisory for Phase 1, (quote) all individuals within the state of louisiana should stay at home as much as possible to avoid unnecessary exposure to COVID-19 (quote). Further emphasizes this for individuals who are higher risk of severe illness from COVID-19, (quote) stay at home, unless travelling outside the home for an essential activity (quote). Eased to only apply for vulnerable populations on 20200605 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/74-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana-Phase-2.pdf

Eases bar restrictions to allow bars without food service permits to open at 25 pct total occupancy. All establishments shall maintain moderate social distancing between themselves and the public, and shall wear coverings when interacting with the public

Enacts stay-at-home advisory for only vulernable populations for Phase 2 (quote) All individuals who are at higher risk of severe illness from COVID-19 should stay at home, unless travelling outside the home for an essential activity (quote) Extended to 20200807: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/96-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana-Phase-2.pdf Extended to 20200828 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/101-JBE-2020-covid-19-Public-Health-Emergency-Renewal-of-Phase-2.pdf Extended to 20201009 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/117-JBE-2020-COVID-19-Public-Health-Emergency-Phase-3-of-Resilient-LA.pdf. The required minimum health and safety standards for reopening schools state that while inside the school facility, all adults and students in grades 3 through 12 must wear a face covering to the greatest extent possible and practical within the local community context.
At large indoor gatherings there shall be a crowd limit of 250 persons.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Closes all bars to in-person services. Take out via drive-thru or curbside delivery is permitted. Eased on 20200911, allowing bars to reopen for limited services: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/117-JBE-2020-COVID-19-Public-Health-Emergency-Phase-3-of-Resilient-LA.pd

Limits gatherings to no more than 50 people in a single indoor space, and to no more than 50 people in a single outdoor space where people cannot maintain strict social distancing. Extended to 20200807: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/96-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana-Phase-2.pdf Extended to 20200828 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/101-JBE-2020-covid-19-Public-Health-Emergency-Renewal-of-Phase-2.pdf

(quote) Every individual in Louisiana shall wear a face covering over the nose and mouth when inside a commercial establishment or any other building or space open to the public, whether indoor or outdoor. This shall include public or commercial modes of transportation (quote). Exemptions are for children under the age of 8 years (though 2-7 year-olds are encouraged to wear mask coverings), individuals who will be able to maintain strict social distancing outside of their immediate households, individuals with a medical condition that prevents the wearing of a face mask. Coding to Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it requires mask use for indoor and outdoor settings, with the latter only exempted if strict social distancing can occur (at least 6 ft distance) Extended to 20200807: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/96-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana-Phase-2.pdf Extended to 20200828 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/101-JBE-2020-covid-19-Public-Health-Emergency-Renewal-of-Phase-2.pdf Extended to 20201009 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/117-JBE-2020-COVID-19-Public-Health-Emergency-Phase-3-of-Resilient-LA.pdf. Extended to 20201106 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/135-JBE-2020-Renewal-of-SOE.pdf.  Extended to 20201204: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/158-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-Renewing-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana.pdf.  Extended to 20201223: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/168-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-Renewing-COVID-19.pdf.

Eases bar restrictions under the following conditions, if the bar is located in a parish with positivity rate lower than 5 pct for 2 consecutive weeks, it may reopen at maximum 25 pct occupancy or 50 patrons, whichever is less, service of alcohol must end by 10 pm (closed by 11 pm) and all patrons must be seated at tables. If these conditions are not met, all bars are to remain closed to in-person services. Take out via drive-thru or curbside delivery is permitted.

Eases gathering restriction to no more than 250 people in a single indoor space, and to no more than 250 people in a single outdoor space where people cannot maintain strict social distancing. Church and faith-based services shall not be limited by the crowd size restrictions of section E, see section D4. Extended to 20201106 https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/135-JBE-2020-Renewal-of-SOE.pdf.  Extended to 20201204: https://gov.louisiana.gov/assets/Proclamations/2020/158-JBE-2020-State-of-Emergency-Renewing-COVID-19-Resilient-Louisiana.pdf.

All bars shall be closed by 11pm. Therefore, the hours of permissible operation shall be 8am to 11pm. Extends eased requirements allowing bars to reopen at maximum 25 pct occupancy or 50 patrons, whichever is less, if the bar is located in a parish with positivity rate lower than 5pct for 2 consecutive weeks. All patrons must be seated at tables. If these conditions are not met, all bars are to remain closed to in-person services, irrespective of food service permit. Take out via drive-thru or curbside delivery is permitted.

Expands gathering restrictions to 25 pct capacity (from 50 pct) or no more than 75 people (from 250) in a single indoor space, and to 25 pct capacity (from 50 pct) or no more than 150 people (from 250) in a single outdoor space where people cannot maintain strict social distancing. Church and faith-based services shall not be limited by the crowd size restrictions of section E, see section D4. They may continue operating at up to 75 pct of total occupancy.
Recommends suspending or postponing non-essential, large indoor gatherings of 250 attendees or more
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

Schools in Maine will be categorized into red, yellow and green.Green is low levels of transmission in community and in person instruction can be adopted if schools also follow Required Health and Safety Measures for All Schools in the plan https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/Framework%20for%20Returning%20to%20Classroom%20Instruction%20UPDATE%207-17.pdf Plan was updated on 20200729 https://www.maine.gov/doe/sites/maine.gov.doe/files/inline-files/Framework%20for%20Returning%20to%20Classroom%20Instruction%20UPDATE%207-30.pdf  Ended on 20200729 for all counties at a green case level (all counties at the time): https://mainedoenews.net/2020/07/31/media-release-mills-administration-releases-guidance-to-assist-schools-with-fall-plans/

Anyone entering Maine must self quarantine regardless of point of origin or residency. Extended to 20200601 https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/An%20Order%20to%20Stay%20Safer%20at%20Home.pdf Slightly eases the travel quarantine to no longer apply to New Hampshire and Vermont, or to Maine residents returning from travel to New Hampshire and Vermont. Quaratine requirements otherwise remain in place  https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/EO-57.pdf. On 20201104, expands travel quarantine restrictions, requiring visitors from Connecticut, New York and New Jersey to complete a 14-day quarantine requirement or negative COVID-19 testing: https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/news/cases-rising-maine-nationwide-mills-administration-announces-measures-prevent-spread-deadly. On 20201113, expands travel qurantine restrictions. Expands travel quarantine restrictions. Massachusetts is no longer exempt from Maine’s quarantine or negative test requirement. People traveling to Maine from Massachusetts must either quarantine for 14 days or receive a negative COVID-19 test with a sample taken no longer than 72 hours from arrival in Maine. https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/news/ahead-holiday-season-mills-administration-announces-massachusetts-no-longer-exempt-quarantine

Visitors are instructed not to travel to Maine if they are displaying symptoms of COVID-19, and are advised not to travel to Maine if they are traveling from cities and regions identified as COVID-19 hotspots, including the cities of Detroit, Chicago, New York. Residents of New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut should refrain from travel in compliance with CDC travel guidance. Extended to 20200601 on 20200429 https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/An%20Order%20to%20Stay%20Safer%20at%20Home.pdf. On 20201104, expands travel quarantine restrictions, requiring visitors from Connecticut, New York and New Jersey to complete a 14-day quarantine requirement or negative COVID-19 testing: https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/news/cases-rising-maine-nationwide-mills-administration-announces-measures-prevent-spread-deadly.

Individuals must wear cloth face coverings in public settings where other physical distancing measures are difficult to maintain. Public settings are defined as indoor spaces accessible to the public (e.g., grocery stores, retail stroes, retail stores, pharmacies, healthcare facilities), outdoor spaces (e.g., playgrounds, busy parking lots, and other areas such as lines for take-out service where the public typically gathers in a small area), public transportation (eg, taxi, ride-sharing, ferry, bus, train, and any semi-enclosed transit stop or waiting area). Exemptions are for children under the age of 2, anyone who cannot wear a mask due to a condition, medical or other types of physical or mental conditions. Coding as Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it explicitly requires mask use in both indoor and outdoor settings. On 20200531, clarified that masks were required for large gatherings, including those outside: https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/An%20Order%20to%20Further%20Implement%20the%20Restarting%20Plan.pdf. On 20201104, clarifies that masks are required in all public spaces regardless of ability to maintain physical distance: https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/An%20Order%20to%20Revise%20Indoor%20Gathering%20Limits%2C%20Strengthen%20Face%20Covering%20Requirements%20and%20Delegate%20Certain%20Authority.pdf.

The stay-at-home mandate is (quote) eased to the extent that people may access the increased business and personal activities that are being reopened. Until further notice, persons who are over age 60 or who have a medically compromised condition are strongly urged to limit their movement and activities that expose them to persons other than immediate household members, and to avoid large gatherings, especially those occurring indoors or in otherwise confined settings (quote)
Gathering restriction on more than 50 people. Eased on 20200801: https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/EO%206%20-%20fy20-21.pdf

Eases outdoor gathering restrictions. (quote) The limit on the number of persons for outdoor gatherings is 5 people per 1,000 sq. ft of occupiable outdoor space or not more than 100 persons whichever is less. The limit on the number of persons for indoor gatherings remains at 50 persons as set forth in Executive Order 55 FY 19/20.(quote) Eased on 20201013 https://www.maine.gov/governor/mills/sites/maine.gov.governor.mills/files/inline-files/An%20Order%20to%20Implement%20Phase%20Four%20of%20the%20Restarting%20Maines%20Economy%20Plan.pdf.

Eases indoor gathering restrictions for seated indoor activities, where the limit is increased to either 50 percent capacity of permitted occupancy or 100 people, whichever is less. For non-seated indoor activities, such as physical activity in gyms, the limit remains at 50. (quote) The limit on the number of persons for outdoor gatherings is 5 people per 1,000 sq. ft of occupiable outdoor space or not more than 100 persons whichever is less. (quote)
Expands indoor gathering restrictions to a maximum of 50 people, regardless of capacity. Outdoor gathering restrictions remains at 100 people.

(quote) All Non-Essential Businesses are hereby closed to the general public (quote). Expands to prior business closures, and explicitly calls out the following: golf courses, social and fraternal clubs, personal care services (e.g., tattoo parlors, tanning salons, barber shops, beauty salons). First eased on 20200507, permitting outdoor businesses to resume, specifically golf courses and driving ranges, as well as outdoor archery and shooting ranges, marinas and watercraft rental businesses and campgrounds: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Gatherings-FIFTH-AMENDED-5.6.20.pdf
Effective at 8 pm 20200330. No clear expiry date. Ended on 20200515 https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Gatherings-SIXTH-AMENDED-5.13.20.pdf

All retail and foodservice establishments shall require staff to wear face coverings while working in areas open to the general public, while interacting with customers, and areas in which interactions with other staff are likely. Continues to require more businesses to have staff or employees wear masks as they re-open for in-person services. On 20200731, with the expanded public mask mandate, it is also required that all individuals are required to wear masks or face coverings in work in any area where interactions with others are likely and where food is prepared or packaged: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Gatherings-10th-AMENDED-7.29.20.pdf

Effective at 7 am on 20200418. Requirements are for riders and operators on public transport (including but without limitation to taxi services and ride services, car services), customers 9 years and older at retail restablishments and food services establishment (including but without limitation: grocery stores and similar venues, pharmacies, stores that sell supplies for household consumption or use, alcoholic beverage stores, laudromats). Coded as a Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel as it covers multiple sectors but is limited to indoors.

Eases restrictions of businesses previously closed under the non-essential business closure, specifically golf courses and driving ranges, as well as outdoor archery and shooting ranges, marinas and watercraft rental businesses and campgrounds. Coded as OutdoorOnly under BusinessRestrictLevel

Extends gathering restrictions for more than 10 people for social, community, recreational, leisure and sporting events. Starting May 15, places of worship may reopen to up to 50 pct capacity. Religious gatherings are no longer included in the 10 person gathering prohibition, so coding as easing. Mandate ended on 20200610: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Gatherings-NINTH-AMENDED-6.10.20.pdf

Eases restrictions on having in-person services conditional on continued restrictions: retail establishments (ie, no more than 50 percent capacity), beauty salons and barbers (have to wear masks, on appointment basis only, no more than 50 percent capacity), horse boarding and riding facilities. On 20200904, further eases restrictions to allow for up to 75 capacity: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Gatherings-12th-AMENDED-9.1.20.pdf. On 20201120, expands restrictions on retail establishments (now can be up to 50 pct capacity). Extends eased restrictions on salons, barbers, horse boarding and riding facilities. https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Order-20-11-17-01.pdf

Eases restrictions on bars, permitting them to reopen for on-premises consumption in outdoor seating areas. Patrons must be seated at least 6 ft away from each other, groups no larger than 6 unless they are members of the same household. Eased to allow for indoor services at 50 pct on 20200612: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Gatherings-NINTH-AMENDED-6.10.20.pdf

Eases restrictions on restaurants and other foodservice establishments, permitting them to reopen for on-premises consumption in outdoor seating areas. Patrons must be seated at least 6 ft away from each other, groups no larger than 6 unless they are members of the same household.
Recommends Marylanders to avoid large gatherings and crowded places, ending gathering formal gathering restrictions.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: Further eases bar restrictions, permitting indoor in-person services up to 50 pct capacity. Customers can only be served seated, cleaning and disinfecting procedures in place. On 20200612, eased to up to 75 pct capacity indoors: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Gatherings-13th-AMENDED-9.18.20.pdf On 20201110, reduces to 50 pct capacity indoors: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/EO-11.10.20.pdf. Effective 20201120, all bars must close between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m., except for the purposes of carryout and delivery. https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Order-20-11-17-01.pdf

Further eases restaurant and like venue restrictions, permitting indoor in-person services up to 50 pct capacity. Customers can only be served seated, no buffets, cleaning and disinfecting procedures in place. On 20200921, increased capacity limits up to 75 pct: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Gatherings-13th-AMENDED-9.18.20.pdf On 202001110, decreased capacity limits to 50 pct: https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/EO-11.10.20.pdf. Effective 20201120, all restaurants must close between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m., except for the purposes of carryout and delivery. https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Order-20-11-17-01.pdf

Eases restrictions on previously closed businesss, allowing the following to re-open at 50 pct capacity indoors: shopping centers with closed pedestrian concourses, indoor recreation establishments (eg bingo halls, bowling alleys, skating rinks), social and fraternal clubs. Also permits the opening of fitness centers, health clubs, gyms, aquatic centers, casinos, racetracks, and betting facilities.
Maryland Department of Health and State Department of Education requires school staff to wear cloth face coverings in the school building and school grounds, and while on the school bus.

Out of state travel and public travel advisory PHO. Advises Maryland residents who travel to states with positive rates of more than 10 percent to quarantine and get tested. Out of state travellers should also get tested and quarantine in their residence or hotel. No clear expiry provided, or clear process by which Maryland will be updating state lists for the advisory. Subsequently we are not tracking the states this to applies to at present.

All persons in Maryland over the age of 5 years are required to wear a face covreing when they are in or on any public trnasportation, indoors at any location (inclusive of religious facilities), outdoors and unable to consistently maintain at least 6 ft. Additional exemptions are for individuals with a disability or medical condition. Coded as a Mandate 3 for PublicMaskLevel as it broadly applies across indoor and outdoor settings.

(quote) All Marylanders should refrain from attending public and private indoor gatherings of more than 25 individuals in one location and should practice physical distancing to the extent possible (quote). Effective 20201120, religious facilities can operate up to 50 pct capacity (previously 75 pct) https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Order-20-11-17-01.pdf
No expiry date provided
