Source is Public Health Advisory - NEBusiness closure advises people to stay home, but not mandate: (quote) due to evolving spread of COVID-19 in Massachusetts, Governor Baker has directed the Department of Public Health to issue a stay at home advisory outlining self-isolation and social distancing protocols. Residents are advised to stay home and avoid unnecessary travel and other unnecessary activities during this two-week time period. (quote) Currently not coding as formal stay-at-home/shelter in place. Further eased to focus on vulnerable populations and individuals aged 65+ in 20200518 order: https://www.mass.gov/doc/may-18-2020-re-opening-massachusetts-order/download

People arriving in MA are (quote) instructed (quote) to self quarantine for 14 days, no expiry date provided. Gov language and press release references CDC and dept of state guidance. Easing began on 20200801, such that All travellers, both residents and non residents, entering MA must quarantine for 14 days and produce a Massachusetts travel form. Only travellers from lower risk states are not subject to this order. These states are Connecticut, Hawaii, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Rhode Island and Vermont. https://www.mass.gov/doc/july-24-2020-travel-order-pdf/download Effective Friday, August 7, Rhode Island is no longer listed as a lower-risk state. The low-risk states are now Connecticut, Hawaii, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, and Vermont. https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order#lower-risk-states- Effective August 14, Hawaii  is no longer listed as a lower-risk state. The low-risk states are now Connecticut, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, and Vermont.  https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order#lower-risk-states- Effective August 29, Colorado, Delaware, Pennsylavnia and West Virginia are added to the list of lower-risk states. All travellers, both residents and non residents, entering MA must quarantine for 14 days and produce a Massachusetts travel form. Only travellers from lower risk states are not subject to this order. These states are now Colorado, Connecticut, Delaware, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Vermont and West Virginia https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order#lower-risk-states- Effective September 5, Oregon, Washington and Wyoming are added to the list of lower-risk states https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order  Effective September 12, 2020 Delaware, Pennsylvania, and West Virginia were removed from the list of lower-risk states, and New Mexico was added to the list of lower-risk states. These states are now Colorado, Connecticut, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, Oregon, Vermont, Washington, and Wyoming. https://boston.cbslocal.com/2020/09/11/massachusetts-removes-delaware-pennsylvania-west-virginia-lower-risk/ Effective September 19, 2020 Wyoming was removed from the list of lower-risk states. These states are now Colorado, Connecticut, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, Oregon, Vermont, and Washington.  Effective September 26, 2020 Oregon was removed from the list of lower-risk states. These states are now Colorado, Connecticut, Maine, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York,  Vermont, and Washington.  https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order#lower-risk-states-. Effective October 3, 2020, Washington D.C. was added and Colorado, New Jersey, and New Mexico were removed from the list of lower-risk states. These states are now Connecticut, District of Columbia, Maine, New Hampshire, New York, and Vermont. https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order#lower-risk-states-. Effective 20201017, California, Hawaii, New Jersey, and Washington were added to list of lower-risk states. These states are now California, Connecticut, District of Columbia, Hawaii, Maine, New Hampshire, New York, Vermont and Washington. https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order. Effective 20201031, Connecticut and New Jersey were removed from list of lower-risk states https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order Effective 20201107, California is removed from the low risk list https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order Effective 20201114, District of Columbia, New York, Washington State are removed as low-risk states: https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order. Effective 20201120, Maine and New Hampshire are removed as low-risk states: https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order. Effective 20201128, Vermont is removed as a low-risk state: https://www.mass.gov/info-details/covid-19-travel-order

(quote) Effective Wednesday, May 6, 2020, any person over age two who is in a place open to the public in the Commonwealth, whether indoor or outdoor, and is unable to or does not maintain a distance of approximately six feet from every other person shall cover their mouth and nose with a mask or cloth face covering, except where a person is unable to wear a mask or face covering due to a medical condition or the person is otherwise exempted by Department of Public Health guidance. (quote). Also emphasizes the requirement for persons to wear masks or face coverings at all times when inside grocery stores, pharmacies, and other retail stores, as well as all transportation services. Coded as Mandate3 under PublicMaskLevel as it explicitly requires masks or the equivalent in indoor and outdoor public areas. Extended on 20201102: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-55/download.

For outdoor gatherings, no more than 100 people or 25 pct of capacity. The following outdoor activities remain prohibited: festivals, runs, races, organized athletic events with crowds (see Section 2b). Applicable to all locations except for Boston on 20200706, which be in effect on 20200713. Except in businesses that are reopened under Phase III, no indoor gatherings of more than 25 allowed, easing previous gathering restrictions. No more than 8 people per 1000 sq ft, or 25 in any enclosed space. Applicable to all locations except for Boston on 20200706, which be in effect on 20200713
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Creates more restrictive gathering rules, but exempts religious gatherings (both indoor and outdoor) from the rules. Indoor gatherings limited to 8 per 1000sq ft or no more than 25. Outdoor gatherings can be no more than 50, or 25pct occupancy. In any group of more than 10, masks and distancing are required. Effective 1201 on Aug 11, in effect until end of emergency. Effective 20201005, Communities designate as (quote) Lower Risk Communities, as defined in COVID-19 ORder No. 51 (quote) can have up to 100 people in outdoor gatherings: https://www.mass.gov/info-details/community-level-covid-19-data-reporting At the state level, gathering limits remain the same (25 for indoor, 50 for outdoor): https://www.mass.gov/doc/governors-covid-19-order-52/download. Eased on 20201005 https://www.mass.gov/doc/governors-covid-19-order-52/download. Extends restrictions for communities not designated as Lower Risk and expands restrictions for private gatherings, which are now limited to 10 indoors and 25 outdoors. on 20201102: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-54/download.

Eases gathering restriction at the substate level. Communities designated as (quote) Lower Risk Communities, as defined in COVID-19 ORder No. 51 (quote) can have up to 100 people in outdoor gatherings: https://www.mass.gov/info-details/community-level-covid-19-data-reporting Indoor gathering restrictions remain up to 25 people. In non-Lower Risk Communities up to 50 people gatherings outdoors can occur. Social distancing of at least 6 ft, mask use, etc. required in all gatherings. Extended on 20201102 and expands restrictions for private gatherings, which are now limited to 10 indoors and 25 outdoors.: https://www.mass.gov/doc/covid-19-order-54/download.
Somewhat expands stay-at-home advisory, now applying to all Massachusetts residents but between the hours of 10 pm and 5 am.

Slightly expands gathering restrictions at the state-level, prohibiting any gatherings after 9.30 pm. Gatherings statewide are limited to up to 25 people indoors and 50 outdoors. No more exceptions for communities (sub-county) designated as lower risk. Extends restrictions for private gatherings, which are  limited to 10 indoors and 25 outdoors.

Expanded to state of emergency and state of disaster on 20200401. Extended to 20200620 https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/MIEOG/2020/05/22/file_attachments/1458384/EO%202020-99%20Emergency%20declaration.pdf Extended to 20200717. Extended to 20200812:  https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/MIEOG/2020/07/14/file_attachments/1495465/EO%202020-151%20Emerg%20declaration.pdf Extended to 20201002 https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/MIEOG/2020/09/03/file_attachments/1536731/EO%202020-177%20Emergency%20declaration.pdf  Extended to 20201028: https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-540837--,00.html Ended on 20201002 with Michigan Supreme Court striking down emergency orders: https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/Clerks/Recent%20Opinions/20-21%20Term%20Opinions/In%20re%20Certified%20Questions-OP.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Added DateEnded of 20201002 and updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: Gatherings of more than 250 people are prohibited throughout the state.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Schools are to remain closed through 20200405, so coded to 20200406. Easing begins on 20200615, with some extracurricular activities being permitted to resume: https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-531786--,00.html
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed DateEnded, added NoInPerson under SchoolRestrictLevel

PolicyCodingNotes: Limited operations required (take-out, delivery, off-site consumption only): bars, taverns, brew pubs and like venues. Easing began for Regions 6 and 8 on 20200522: https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-529476--,00.html Became statewide on 20200608: https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-530620--,00.html

Closure required: theaters, cinemas, and indoor and outdoor performance venues, libraries and museums, gymnasiums, fitness centers, recreation centers, indoor sports facilities, indoor exercise facilities, exercise studios, and spas, casinos and racetracks, hookah bars, cigar bars, and vaping lounges, other places of amusement (e.g., amusement park, arcade, bingo hall, bowling alley, indoor climbing facility, skating rink, trampoline park)

Limited operations required (take-out, delivery, off-site consumption): restaurants. Allows for easing of restaurant restrictions starting on 20200522 in Regions 6 and 8: https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-529476--,00.html Extended to 20200613 https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/MIEOG/2020/05/22/file_attachments/1458387/EO%202020-100%20Emerg%20order%20-%20amendments.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateExpiry, added BusinessRestrictLevel, and updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: Expands gathering restriction to a limit of no more than 50
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Expands required business closures to include non-essential personal care services (i.e., hair, nail, tanning, massage, traditional spa, tattoo, body art, and piercing services, and similar personal care services that require individuals to be within six feet of each other).
(quote) This order must be construed broadly to prohibit in-person work that is not necessary to sustain or protect life (quote), and thus coding as a non-essential business closure.

(quote) Subject to the same exceptions, all public and private gatherings of any number of people occurring among persons not part of a single household are prohibited (quote). Easing began on 20200518 for Regions 6 and 8, allowing up to 10 people in a gathering https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-529476--,00.html
Issued on 20200323. to be enacted on 20200324. Ends on 20200601 https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-530620--,00.html

People with positive tests must stay in their homes for seven days, people with symptoms must stay in their homes until three days after symptoms resolve, people with contact with those with symptoms or positive tests must stay in their homes for 14 days. In effect until the emergency declaration ends.  Extended on 20200807: 
https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/MIEOG/2020/08/07/file_attachments/1513961/EO%202020-166%20Emerg%20order%20-%20worker%20protections%20-%20reissue.pdf Ended on 20201002 with Michigan Supreme court ruling: https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/Clerks/Recent%20Opinions/20-21%20Term%20Opinions/In%20re%20Certified%20Questions-OP.pdf

(quote) All businesses and operations whose workers perform in-person work must, at a minimum, provide non-medical grade face coverings to their workers (quote). Requires individuals who can medically tolerate a face covering must wear one when in any enclosed public place, so applies to employees and business staff. Ended as part of the Michigan Supreme Court ruling on 20201002: https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/Clerks/Recent%20Opinions/20-21%20Term%20Opinions/In%20re%20Certified%20Questions-OP.pdf

Any individual able to medically tolerate a face covering must wear a covering over his or her nose and mouth—such as a homemade mask, scarf, bandana, or handkerchief — when in any enclosed public space. Coded as a Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel as it requires face coverings for all enclosed spaces, implying this is only applicable to indoor and like settings.

Starting 20200507, permits the following industries to resume operations: workers who perform work that is traditionally and primarily performed outdoors, including but not limited to forestry workers, outdoor power equipment technicians, parking enforcement workers, and similar workers. Also permits construction industry and real estate industry to resume in-person services, as well as (quote) workers necessary to the manufacture of goods that support workplace modification to forestall the spread of COVID-19 infections (quote). All re-opening sectors must adhere to social distancing requirements (i.e., at least 6 ft distancing), limited number of people on-premises (e.g., no more than 4 people at at time for real estate functions). Ended with Michigan Supreme court decision on 20201002: https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/Clerks/Recent%20Opinions/20-21%20Term%20Opinions/In%20re%20Certified%20Questions-OP.pdf

For Regions 6 and 8, indivduals may gather in groups of 10 or fewer. Region 6: Manistee, Wexford, Missaukee, Roscommon, Benzie, Grand Traverse, Kalkaska, Crawford, Leelanau, Antrim, Otsego, Montmorency, Alpena, Charlevoix, Cheboygan, Presque Isle, and Emmet counties. Region 8: Gogebic, Ontonagon, Houghton, Keweenaw, Iron, Baraga, Dickinson, Marquette, Menominee, Delta, Alger, Schoolcraft, Luce, Mackinac, and Chippewa counties.

For Regions 6 and 8, bars and like venues may re-open to in-person services conditional on following business health and safety protcols. Per EO 2020-91, capacity is limited to no more than 50 pct, requires at least 6 ft distancing between parties or groups, no self-service options, close waiting areas.

For Regions 6 and 8, restaurants may re-open to in-person services conditional on following business health and safety protcols. Per EO 2020-91, capacity is limited to no more than 50 pct, requires at least 6 ft distancing between parties or groups, no self-service options, close waiting areas.
Gathering restrictions for up to no more than 10 people are effective statewide immediately

Eases gathering restrictions to the following: (quote) Indoor social gatherings and events among persons not part of a single household are permitted, but may not exceed 10 people....Outdoor social gatherings and events among persons not part of a single household are permitted, but only to the extent that the gathering or event does not exceed 100 people and people not part of the same household maintain six feet of distance from one another (quote)
Eased bar restrictions are now statewide: capacity is limited to no more than 50 pct, requires at least 6 ft distancing between parties or groups, no self-service options, close waiting areas.

Eased restaurant restrictions are now statewide: capacity is limited to no more than 50 pct, requires at least 6 ft distancing between parties or groups, no self-service options, close waiting areas. Ended on 20201002 with Michigan Supreme Court ruling: https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/Clerks/Recent%20Opinions/20-21%20Term%20Opinions/In%20re%20Certified%20Questions-OP.pdf

Statewide, eases restrictions on the following indoor businesses, with maximum of 25 pct capacity or maximum of 250 people, and requires physical distancing (6 ft between people and parties): arcade, bowling alley, cinema, climbing facility, convention center, performance space, meeting hall, night club, sports arena, theater, or similar venue. Also eases restrictions on outdoor businesses, conditional on opening for a maximum of 25 pct capacity or 500 people, whichever smaller, and requires social distancing (6 ft between people and parties: concert space, race track, sports arena, stadium, or similar venue. Allows outdoor recreational facilities to re-open. Ended with Michigan Supreme court decision on 20201002: https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/Clerks/Recent%20Opinions/20-21%20Term%20Opinions/In%20re%20Certified%20Questions-OP.pdf
Eases indoor gathering restrictions for Regions 6 and 8, allowing for up to 50 people gatherings indoors and 250 people gatherings outdoors if they following distancing guidelines

For Regions 6 and 8, eases restrictions on non-essential personal care services (can reopen but only at 25 pct capacity, follow health and safety protocols), including hair, nail, tanning, massage, traditional spa, tattoo, body art, and piercing services.

Allows for all regions to have eased restrictions on businesses: non-essential personal care services, including hair, nail, tanning, massage, traditional spa, tattoo, body art, and piercing services may re-open at 25 percent capacity, physical distancing, and following business safety protocols. Ended with Michigan Supreme court decision on 20201002: https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/Clerks/Recent%20Opinions/20-21%20Term%20Opinions/In%20re%20Certified%20Questions-OP.pdf

(quote)  K-12 school sports activities and other in-person extracurricular school activities may resume (quote), requiring the same gathering restrictions applied for a given region. Ends on 20200630, devolving to local authorities: https://www.michigan.gov/documents/whitmer/MI_Safe_Schools_Roadmap_FINAL_695392_7.pdf

Requires that facial coverings or masks be always worn by staff except for meals, and that pre K-12 students must always wear facial coverings in hallways and common areas. Also requires masks to be worn in classrooms by all students in grades 6 to 12. Ended on 20201002 with Supreme Court ruling: https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/Clerks/Recent%20Opinions/20-21%20Term%20Opinions/In%20re%20Certified%20Questions-OP.pdf

Closes bars for indoor services in regions that are Phase 4 of the Michign Safe Start Plan (all regions but Regions 6 and 8). Outdoor service may remain at bars and like venues, but only for seated customers at socially distanced tables. Also clarifies that capcaity should be at no more than 50 pct (was not clearly provided in previous EOs), patrons must wear face coverings unless seated, distancing between tables, etc.

Any individual who leaves their home or place of residence must wear a face covering over their nose and mouth when in any indoor public space, when outdoors and unable to consistently maintain a distance of six feet or more from individuals who are not members of their household, and when waiting for or riding on public transportation, while in a taxi or ridesharing vehicle, or when using a private car service as a means of hired transportation. Makes exemptions for children under 5 years old, individuals who cannot medically tolerate a face covering, during exercise, etc. Coded as a Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it explicitly requires masks or face coverings in any indoor or outdoor space when unable to maintain physical distancing in public. On 20200717, order is extended and clarifies that this mandate is not required when at a polling place for purposes for voting, as well as when when engaging in religious worship while at a house of religious worship (though strongly encouraged to wear face coverings during religious services, per CDC): https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/MIEOG/2020/07/17/file_attachments/1498115/EO%202020-153%20Emerg%20order%20-%20Masks%20-%20re-issue.pdf Starting on 20200811, all staff, visitors, and children over 2 required to wear face masks in childcare facilities https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/MIEOG/2020/08/06/file_attachments/1512889/EO%202020-164%20Emerg%20order%20-%20masks%20and%20camps.pdf. Ended on 20201002 after Michigan Supreme Court overturns governor's EO's. https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/Clerks/Recent%20Opinions/20-21%20Term%20Opinions/In%20re%20Certified%20Questions-OP.pdf

Closes bars for indoor services in all regions, making the closure of indoor bar service statewide. Outdoor service may remain at bars and like venues, but only for seated customers at socially distanced tables. Also clarifies that capcaity should be at no more than 50 pct (was not clearly provided in previous EOs), patrons must wear face coverings unless seated, distancing between tables, etc. Ends on 20201002 with Michigan Supreme court decision: https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/Clerks/Recent%20Opinions/20-21%20Term%20Opinions/In%20re%20Certified%20Questions-OP.pdf

Statewide, indoor gatherings and events cannot exceed 10 people, and for regions that are not Region 6 and 8, outdoor gatherings cannot exceed 100 people. Exemptions for continue for professional sports leagues and teams (allowing them to resume operations without live audiences) and for polling places. Starting on 20201009, eased gatherings: https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-540568--,00.html

Statewide, indoor gatherings and events cannot exceed 10 people, though outdoor gatherings cannot exceed 250 people still in Regions 6 and 8. Exemptions for continue for professional sports leagues and teams (allowing them to resume operations without live audiences) and for polling places. Starting on 20201009, eased gatherings: https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-540568--,00.html

In all regions, effective September 9, 2020 indoor gymnasiums, fitness centers, recreation centers, sports facilities, exercise facilities, exercise studios, and the like may reopen. Requires at least 6 ft distancing between individuals at all times, no steam rooms or saunas allowed to open. It appears that a 25 pct capacity limit is likely for these re-opened venues per EO capacity limits

Statewide, social gatherings are limited up to 10 people indoors and 100 people outdoors at residential venues. Different absolute and relative capacity limits apply to non-residential venues (up to 20 pct capacity for non-residential indoor gatherings outside of Regions 6 and 8, up to 25 pct capacity for Regions 6 and 8), and up to no more than 500 people at non-residential indoor gatherings. For outdoors, the capacity limits are 30 pct, or no more than 1000 people (whichever is less). Supreme court ruling ended this policy on 20201002: https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/Clerks/Recent%20Opinions/20-21%20Term%20Opinions/In%20re%20Certified%20Questions-OP.pdf

Statewide, social gatherings are limited up to 10 people indoors and 100 people outdoors at residential venues. Different absolute and relative capacity limits apply to non-residential venues (up to 20 pct capacity for non-residential indoor gatherings outside of Region 6 up to 25 pct capacity for Region 6), and up to no more than 500 people at non-residential indoor gatherings. For outdoors, the capacity limits are 30 pct, or no more than 1000 people (whichever is less)

For non-residential venues (i.e., businesses) outside of Region 6, indoor gatherings from more than 10 up to 500 can occur only up to 20 pct capacity where there is fixed seating capacity and up to 20 persons per 1,000 sq ft in each room in venues without fixed seating. No capacity limits for 10 people indoors. For outdoors, capacity limits are actived from 100 to 1,000 persons such that 30 pct of capacity with fixed seating and 30 persons per 1,000 sq ft without fixed seating. No capacity limits for up to 100 people. While these restrictions are framed as gathering restrictions, they apply to (quote) non-residential venues (quote) that are not airports, bus stations, factory floor, restaurants, shopping malls, public pools, or workplace.

(quote) Businesses, goverment offices, schools, and other operations must not allow indoor gatherings of any kind unless they require individuals to wear a face covering (quote). Within the gathering section of the MDHHS order, indoor and outdoor gatherings are only permitted outside of residences if each person wears a face covering. Exceptions include children younger than 5 yeras old, if an individual cannot medically tolerate a face covering, while eating or drinking seated at a food service establishment, while exercising outdoors, etc. Coded as a Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it broadly applies to indoor and outdoor settings. Extended on 20201029 https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455-543708--,00.html Extended to 20201209: https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455-545136--,00.html. Extended to 20201221: https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455-545136--,00.html.

MDHHS orders requirements for school health and safety under Phase 4 of the MI Safe Start Plan, requiring all students in grades K on up to wear masks at school and requiring school districts and nonpublic schools to report on confirmed COVID-19 infections to Michigan Department of Health and Human Services. This applicable to all locations except for those in Region 6, where mask use is recommended

Requires no more than 15 pct total occupancy at non-tribal casinos, no more than 25 pct total occupancy at the following types of businesses: recreational sports and exercise facilities, such as gymnasiums, fitness centers, recreation centers, exercise studios, bowling centers, roller rinks, ice rinks, and trampoline parks. Also requires no more than 25 pct bather capacity limits for indoor pools and no more than 50 pct bather capacity limits for outdoor pools.

Business mask requirement: (quote) Except as provided elsewhere in this order, a person responsible for a business, store, office, government office, school, organized event, or other operation, or an agent of such person, must prohibit gatherings of any kind unless the person requires individuals in such gatherings (including employees) to wear a face mask, and denies entry or service to all persons refusing to wear face masks while gathered. Extended to 20201209: https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455-545136--,00.html. Extended to 20201221: https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455-545136--,00.html.

With Region 6 moving to Phase 4, school mask mandate is now statewide: requiring all staff and children in schools to wear masks if the child is at least 5 years older in classrooms, hallways, buses, etc. Extended to 20201209: https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455-545136--,00.html. Extended to 20201221: https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455-545136--,00.html.

Bars are only permitted to have outdoor services with at least 6 ft distancing between parties/tables and no more than 6 people to a table. Extended to 20201221: https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455-545136--,00.html.

Expands gathering restrictions such that indoor gatherings are prohibited except for up to 10 people at residential venues from no more than 2 households, and outdoor gatherings can occur up to 25 people comprised of no more than 3 households. Non-residential venues cannot have indoor gatherings and outdoor gatherings are permitted in non-residential venues up to 25 people at a venue or no more than 20 pct capacity. Extended to 20201221: https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455-545136--,00.html.

Requires the following to close: casinos, bowling centers, roller rinks, ice rinks, and trampoline parks, Entertainment venues, including: auditoriums, arenas, banquet halls, cinema, conference centers, concert halls, performance venues, sporting venues, stadiums, and theaters. Recreational facilities and places of public amusement, including: amusement parks, arcades, bingo halls, night clubs, strip clubs, water parks. Extended to 20201221: https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455-545136--,00.html.

Requires no more than 25 pct capacity limits at all exercise facilities: gymnasiums, fitness centers, exercise studios, pools. Requirements of at least 12 ft distancing between workout stations, no group fitness classes permitted. Extended to 20201221: https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455-545136--,00.html.

Restaurants are only permitted to have outdoor dining with at least 6 ft distancing between tables and no more than 6 people at a table. Previous orders permitted up to 50 pct capacity indoors but these were not coded as new policies as the threshold for a new closure is up to 25 pct capacity. Extended to 20201221: https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455-545136--,00.html.

Limited in-person instruction can occur for grades 9-12, but otherwise in-person instruction, sprots, and extracurricular activities are prohibited (quote) except for in-person instruction of pupils who are English Language Learners or participants in special education services (quote). For students PreK to grade 8, in-person instruction is permitted but all sports and extracurricular activities are prohibited. Extended to 20201221: https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/0,9753,7-406-98178_98455-545136--,00.html.

Peace time emergency declared, extended on 20200413. Extends emergency declaration through 20201215 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-97%20Final_tcm1055-453622.pdf. PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) Event organizers cancelling or postponing gatherings with 250 or more people, including concerts, conferences, professional and amateur performances or sporting events (quote).

Public and charter schools from pre K-12 are to be closed to students beginning 20200318 through 20200327. Tribal and private schools are encouraged to follow the order as well. Expiry is then coded to 20200328. Extended to at least 20200630: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-41%20Final_tcm1055-430418.pdf Eased on 20200514: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-57%20Final_tcm1055-437633.pdf

Limited operations required (to-go, delivery, off-site consumption required):  bars. Extended to 20200518 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-48%20Final_tcm1055-430499.pdf. Eased on 20200601 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-63%20Final_tcm1055-433759.pdf

Closure required: hookah bars, cigar bars, and vaping lounges, theaters, cinemas, indoor and outdoor performance venues, and museums, gymnasiums, fitness centers, recreation centers, indoor sports facilities, indoor exercise facilities, exercise studios, and spas, amusement parks, arcades, bingo halls, bowling alleys, indoor climbing facilities, skating rinks, trampoline parks, and other similar recreational or entertainment facilities, country clubs, golf clubs, boating or yacht clubs, sports or athletic clubs, and dining clubs. On 20200318, clarifies that spas are tanning salons, tattoo and body art parlors, massage therapy establishments, nail salons, esthetician salons, and barber shops and similar establishments: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/Filed%20EO-20-08_Clarifying%20Public%20Accommodations_tcm1055-423784.pdf Last businesses under this closure were allowed to re-open on 20200609: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-74%20Final_tcm1055-437539.pdf
Limited operations required (to-go, delivery, off-site consumption required): restaurants. Extended to 20200518 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-48%20Final_tcm1055-430499.pdf

With the stay-at-home order, requires sectors where employees can work from home to do so and lists exemptions for critical sectors. This is not coded as a non-essential business closure due to not requiring all non-essential businesses to close and phrasing to businesses that reflect more of a recommendation to close in-person operations (e.g., [quote] Workers should be encouraged to work remotely when possible and focus on core business activities. Inperson, non-mandatory activities should be delayed until the resumption of normal operations [quote]) and imposing the requirement on individuals to work from home rather than businesses to shutter operations. Office-based work, non-critical manufacturing, recreation outlets, non-essential retail and supply stores are by default required to close. Easing began on 20200418, permitting outdoor recreational services to re-open: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-38%20Final%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-429089.pdf
Initial gathering restriction coded with stay-at-home order (without specific numeric limits)

(quote) All persons currently living within the State of Minnesota are ordered to stay at home or in their place of residence except to engage in the Activities and Critical sector work set for below (quote). Ended on 20200518: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-56%20Final_tcm1055-433768.pdf

Eases restrictions to permit limited outdoor recreational facilities to re-open, conditional on no indoor facilities being re-opened: all state parks, public and private marinas, public and private golf courses and driving ranges, off-highway vehicle, snowmobiles, and watercraft repair shops, facilities, and showrooms, bait shops, outdoor shooting ranges and game farms

Permits some non-critical businesses to resume in-person operations (i.e., employees can be onsite): industrial and manufacturing businesses (excludes customer-facing retail) and office-based businseses for which their work does not primarily involve customer-facing retail. Requires following of COVID-19 preparedness protocols before workers can return to work. In effect through the peacetime emergency declaration. Extended to 20210111 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-103%20Final%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-458627.pdf

Eases business restrictions for non-critical businesses to include retail businessses. Businesses in this category include retail stores sell goods that can be picked up outside, without entering the place of business, with limited interaction between employees and customers. Salons and barbershops are included only to conduct retail product sales (no in-person services allowed). Eases in 20200518 to allow indoor services: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-56%20Final_tcm1055-433768.pdf

Strongly encourages all Minnesotans to wear cloth face coverings at all times when they leave their homes and travel to any public setting. Extends to 20200601 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-56%20Final_tcm1055-431921.pdfhttps://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-56%20Final_tcm1055-431921.pdf Extended on 20200605 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-74%20Final_tcm1055-434913.pdf
All gatherings of more than 10 people are prohibited. Eases gathering restrictions for places of worship on 20200526 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-62_tcm1055-433307.pdf

Eases prior restrictions, allowing outdoor recreation facilities to re-open indoor facilities conditional on following all capacity restrictions (i.e., no more than 50 pct of normal occupant capacity), requirements to maintain at least 6 ft distancing, etc. Applicable to the following businesses: all state parks, public and private marinas, public and private golf courses and driving ranges, off-highway vehicle, snowmobiles, and watercraft repair shops, facilities, and showrooms, bait shops, outdoor shooting ranges and game farms, ski areas. Also permits outdoor recreational equipment rentals, dispersed or single campsites, outdoor competitions, etc. Starting 20200609, removes 50 pct capacity limit: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-74%20Final_tcm1055-437539.pdf

Further eases restrictions on retail businesses, permitting in-person services and sales conditional strictly following DEED plan guidance, limit capacity to no more than 50 pct, and ensure maintaining at least 6 ft distancing between workers and customers. Further eased on 20200609 to remove 50 pct capacity limit: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-74%20Final_tcm1055-437539.pdf. Extended to 20210111 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-103%20Final%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-458627.pdf

All persons who are at risk of severe illness from COVID-19 are strongly urged to stay at home. Extended to 20201219: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-99%20Final%20%28002%29_tcm1055-454278.pdf. Extended to 20210111 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-103%20Final%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-458627.pdf

A school district or charter school may safely open its building for a hybrid model of in-school learning and distance learning this summer for students eligible for summer learning or extended learning year services. (quote)  The Summer Learning Period begins after the end of each school districts and charter schools respective 2019-2020 school year calendars and ends before their respective 2020-2021 school year calendars. Ended on 20200730: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-82%20Final%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-442391.pdf

Eases restrictions on gatherings of 10 or more for places of worship, funeral homes, and other venues that offer gathering space for weddings, funerals, or planned services of worship. Indoor settings cannot have more than 25 percent normal capacity with a maximum of 250 people with adherence to physical distancing. Outdoor settings must not exceed 250 individuals. Extended on 20200605 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-74%20Final_tcm1055-434913.pdf Eased on 20200605 and effective on 20200609 groups of less than 25 people can gather outside https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-74%20Final_tcm1055-434913.pdf

Eases bar restrictions to allow outdoor service. Restrictions on in-door service is still in place. Must ensure 6 feet can be maintained between tables, not to exceed 50 people. Eased on 20200609 to permit indoor services: https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-74%20Final_tcm1055-437539.pdf

Requires some sectors to have employees and staff wearing masks or face coverings, including personal care services, restaurants and bars (and like venues) (quote) Workers, customers, and clients must follow face-covering requirements (quote) On 20200722, expands to apply more broadly across sectors: Mandates that employees working in outdoor situations where social distancing cannot be maintained must wear masks and requires individuals to wear face coverings in indoor businesses. Expands previous business mask requirements where only specific sectors were required https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-81%20Final%20Filed_tcm1055-441323.pdf. On 20201219, expands business mask requirements, requiring patrons of excercise facilities to wear face coverings at all times https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-103%20Final%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-458627.pdf
Eases restaurant restrictions to allow outdoor service. Restrictions on in-door service is still in place. Must ensure 6 feet can be maintained between tables, not to exceed 50 people.

Eases bar restrictions to allow indoor service at 50 pct capacity up to 250 people. On 20201113, expands bar restrictions. Occupancy must not exceed 50 pct or 150 people (was previously 250 people) provided that physical distancing of 6 feet is maintained between parties seated at different tables. (quote) For establishments that offer outdoor seating, the combined total occupancy of all indoor and outdoor spaces must not exceed 150 people. All establishments must close and remain closed each day for on premises consumption between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 4:00 a.m. (quote) https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-96%20Final_tcm1055-453621.pdf

Extends gathering restrictions of more than 10 persons indoors, eases to 25 for outdoor gatherings. Extends eased restrictions on gatherings of 10 or more for places of worship, funeral homes, and other venues that offer gathering space for weddings, funerals, or planned services of worship. Indoor settings cannot have more than 25 percent normal capacity with a maximum of 250 people with adherence to physical distancing. Outdoor settings must not exceed 250 individuals.

Eases restrictions on previously closed businesses, permitting them to re-open only in accordance with the Stay Safe Minnesota guidelines (i.e., 25 pct capacity for gyms, personal fitness and yoga studios, indoor and outdoor entertainment venues like theaters and concert halls, indoor entertainment venues such as bowling alleys, arcades, museums, arcades. Original Stay Safe Minnesota guidance is no longer available but original 25 pct capacity requirements are listed in news article: https://ccxmedia.org/news/mn-governor-walz-announces-re-opening-of-indoor-dining-gyms-entertainment-venues/

Eases restaurant restrictions to allow indoor service at 50 pct capacity up to 250 people. On 20201113, expands restaurant restrictions. Occupancy must not exceed 50 pct or 150 people (was previously 250 people) provided that physical distancing of 6 feet is maintained between parties seated at different tables. (quote) For establishments that offer outdoor seating, the combined total occupancy of all indoor and outdoor spaces must not exceed 150 people. All establishments must close and remain closed each day for on premises consumption between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 4:00 a.m. (quote) https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-96%20Final_tcm1055-453621.pdf

Minnesotans are required to wear a face covering (quote) in an indoor business or public indoor space, including when waiting outdoors to enter an indoor business or public indoor space, and when riding on public transportation, in a taxi, in a ride-sharing vehicle, or in a vehicle that is being used for business purposes (quote). Strongly encourages the use of face coverings in indoor and outdoor social gatherings, when riding in a private vehicle with others who are not in the same household, when participating in sporting events, and when outdoors in a public business or outdoor space where physical distancing is not possible. Coded as a Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel as it covers multiple sectors but is limited to indoors. Coded to going into effect on 20200725. Extended to 20210111 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-103%20Final%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-458627.pdf

Kindergarten through grade 12 schools must comply with face covering and face shield guidance available at https://www.health.state.mn.us/diseases/coronavirus/schools/k12planguide.pdf. (quote) In general, unless the individual is exempt under paragraph 8.a or .c of this Executive Order or is under the age of two, all students, staff, and other persons present indoors in school buildings and district offices or riding on school transportation vehicles are required to wear a face covering. (quote) Extended to 20210111 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-103%20Final%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-458627.pdf

Expands gathering restrictions. (quote) All social gatherings of more than 10 people and all social gatherings involving members of more than 3 households (regardless of the size of the gathering) people are prohibited. (quote)
Expands bar restrictions, closing on-premises services and requiring takeaway, delivery, drive-through only

Expands prior gathering restriction, (quote) Except as specifically permitted in this Executive Order, social gatherings are prohibited. Social gatherings are groups of individuals, who are not members of the same household, congregated together for a common or coordinated social, community, or leisure purpose—even if social distancing can be maintained (quote) Religious gatherings are limited to no more than 50 pct indoors (maximum of 250 people) and no more than 250 people outdoors (no capacity limit)

Expands restrictions on the following, limiting activities and use only to outdoor services for outdoor recreational establishments. Applicable to the following businesses: all state parks, public and private marinas, public and private golf courses and driving ranges, off-highway vehicle, snowmobiles, and watercraft repair shops, facilities, and showrooms, bait shops, outdoor shooting ranges and game farms, ski areas. Also permits outdoor recreational equipment rentals, dispersed or single campsites, outdoor competitions, etc. Extended to 20210111 https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-103%20Final%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-458627.pdf

Requires closure of the following: gymnasiums, fitness centers, recreation centers, indoor sports facilities, indoor climbing facilities, trampoline parks, indoor and outdoor exercise facilities, martial arts facilities, and dance and exercise studios, venues providing indoor events and entertainment such as theaters, cinemas, concert halls, festivals, fairs, vendor fairs, museums, performance venues, stadiums, arcades, and bowling alleys, venues providing outdoor events and entertainment such as paintball, go-karts, mini-golf, performance venues, festivals, fairs, vendor fairs, and amusement parks. Also requires closure of racetracks. On 20201219, extends closures for venues providing indoor events and entertainment such as theaters, cinemas, concert halls, festivals, fairs, vendor fairs, museums, performance venues, stadiums, arcades, and bowling alleys. https://mn.gov/governor/assets/EO%2020-103%20Final%20Signed%20and%20Filed_tcm1055-458627.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Added DateEased, updated DateExpiry and PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: Expands restaurant and like venues restrictions, closing on-premises services and requiring takeaway, delivery, drive-through only

Eases bars restrictions to allow outdoor service. Must ensure 6 feet can be maintained between tables, not to exceed 50 pct capacity with a maximum of 100 people in total at establishments, and workers and customers must follow face covering requirements set forth by DEED. All establishments must close and remain closed each day for outdoor on-premises consumption between the hours of 10:00 pm and 4:00 am.

Eases gathering restrictions. (quote) Indoor social gatherings involving not more than two households, up to a maximum of 10 people, are permitted as long as members of different households maintain at least six feet of separation from each other.... Outdoor social gatherings involving not more than three households, up to a maximum of 15 people, are permitted as long as members of different households maintain at least six feet of separation from each other (quote).

Eases restrictions on gymnasiums, fitness centers, recreation centers, indoor sports facilities, indoor climbing facilities, indoor and outdoor exercise facilities, martial arts facilities, and dance and exercise studios, and venues providing outdoor events, such as paintball, go-karts, mini-golf, performance venues, festivals, fairs, vendor fairs, and amusement parks, allowing for individual exercise with the following guidelines: cannot exceed 25 pct occupancy, with a max of 100 people.

Eases restaurant restrictions to allow outdoor service. Must ensure 6 feet can be maintained between tables, not to exceed 50 pct capacity with a maximum of 100 people in total at establishments, and workers and customers must follow face covering requirements set forth by DEED. All establishments must close and remain closed each day for outdoor on-premises consumption between the hours of 10:00 pm and 4:00 am.

LastUpdatedNotes: Removed DateExpiry, as this is not being updated

PolicyCodingNotes: Public school closure. Extended to the end of the school year on 20200414 and re-emphasized with 20200422 issuance https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1476.pdf  Began easing of in-person school activities on 20200525 (https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1487.pdf), with in-person instruction to be able to resume on 20200601.

Bars shall suspend dine-in services unless able to reduce capacity to allow no more than 10 people to be gathered in a single place. Drive-thru, carryout, and delivery are allowed and highly encouraged. In effect 20200324 until 20200417.

(quote) residents shall avoid social and non-essential gatherings in groups of more than 10 people (quote). Expressly includes religious entities under essential services exempt from 10 person gathering limit, conditional on CDC and Mississippi Department of Health recommendations. In effect 20200324 until 20200417.
Non-essential businesses can operate conditional on having no more than 10 people in a single space at the same time where individuals are in close proximity to each other.

Restaurants and other dining establishments shall suspend dine-in services unless able to reduce capacity to allow no more than 10 people to be gathered in a single place. Drive-thru, carryout, and delivery are allowed and highly encouraged. In effect 20200324 until 20200417.
Bars and like venues must cease in-person operations, permitting takeaway, drive-thru, etc. for Lauderdale only

All non-essential business operations are to cease within Lauderdale county. Businesses also expressly indicated to close: fitness and exercise gyms, dance studios, clubs, tattoo parlors, spas, salons, barber shops, othe personal care or grooming businesses, amusement parks, museums, playgrounds, movie theaters, bowling alleys, and social clubs. In effect at 10 pm on 20200331 and be in effect until 1159 pm 20200414, so coded to 20200415 expiry.
Restaurants and like venues must cease in-person operations, permitting takeaway, drive-thru, etc. in Lauderdale only
Individuals in Lauderdale County are ordered to stay at home or place of residence. In effect at 10 pm on 20200331 and be in effect until 1159 pm 20200414, so coded to 20200415 expiry.

Statewide, enacts restrictions on bars such that they can only operate for take-away, delivery, curbside etc. No on-premises consumption. Started easing on 20200507: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1478.pdf

State-wide mandate of (quote) all business entities shall cease operation except for Minimum Operations (quote) in Section D. Other businesses expressly indicated to close:  fitness and exercise gyms, dance studios, clubs, tattoo parlors, spas, salons, barber shops, other personal care or grooming businesses, all places of amusement and recreation including amusement parks, museums, all parks including beaches, lakes, reservoirs, playgrounds, movie theaters, bowling alleys, and social clubs. In effect at 5 pm on 20200403 at 5 pm until 8 am on 20200420.
Statewide, enacts restrictions on restaurants such that they can only operate for take-away, delivery, curbside etc. No on-premises consumption.

State-wide mandate, (quote) all individuals currently living in the State of Mississippi are ordered to stay at home or in their place of residence (quote) In effect at 5 pm on 20200403 at 5 pm until 8 am on 20200420. Ends on 20200427: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1477.pdf

Eases restrictions on non-essential retail, allowing them to re-open for drive-thru, curbside, or delivery services if business health safety standards are adhered to (i.e., social distancing requirements, no gatherings more than 10 people, regular and proper handwashing, following whatever other guidance MSDH and CDC may have implemented

Eases closures and restrictions on beaches, state park lakes, state lakes and reservoirs, allowing them to re-open conditional maintaining at least 6 ft distancing among groups, no gatherings of more than 10 people, etc.

Further eases retail business restrictions, allowing for in-person services for as long as they limit customers to no more than 50 pct capacity, frequent cleaning of high contact surfaces. Encouraged to have hand sanitizer available upon entry. On 20200914, eases to allow for up to 75 pct capacity: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1522.pdf. Extended to 20210115 https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1535.pdf

Encourages individuals to stay at home unless engaging in essential activities. Does not renew this portion of the order, ending the statewide recommendation on 20200601: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1492.pdf

All vulnerable individuals (i.e., elderly individuals 65 and older) and individuals with serious underlying health conditions are encouraged to continue sheltering in place. Extended to 20200629 https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1496.pdf Extended to 20200720 https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1505.pdfhttps://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1505.pdf Extended to 20200930 https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1522.pdf Ended on 20200930: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1525.pdf

Allows the reopening of bars provided they undergone thorough cleaning and close by 10 pm and only allow 50 pct capacity, as well as screening of employees and customers. All parties must be seated at least 6 ft from each other, no more than 6 customers at the table, and shared bar areas must remain closed. No live music permitted.

Restaurant and bar employees must wear appropriate PPE, including (quote) every employee who comes into direct contact with customers shall be provided a cloth mask and required to wear that mask while on duty. (quote) Expands sectors where employees must wear a mask over time, particularly for specific counties where mask mandates were imposed until the statewide mask mandate. Eased on 2020930, where while some businesses still required employees to wear masks, more broadly they were encouraged to do so: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1525.pdf. Extended to 20210115 https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1535.pdf

Further eases restrictions on parks and other outdoor recreational activities, including swimming pools, allowing there to be up to 10 person gatherings indoors and up to 20 person gatherings outdoors conditional adhering to at least 6 ft distancing between each individual. On 20200610, further eases gathering restrictions: 20 for indoor settings and 50 for outdoor settings where social distancing is not possible. Provides higher limits for settings where social distancing is possible, permitting up to 50 people indoors and 100 people outdoors if at least 6 ft distancing can occur. https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1492.pdf. Extended to 20210115 https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1535.pdf

Allows the reopening of restaurants provided they undergone thorough cleaning and close by 10 pm and only allow 50 pct capacity, as well as screening of employees and customers. All parties must be seated at least 6 ft from each other, no more than 6 customers at the table, and shared bar areas must remain closed. No live music permitted.

Eases restrictions on gyms and fitness centers, allowing for limited in-person services. Gyms may only operate at up to 30 pct maximum capacity, 6 ft distancing among individuals at all times, common areas must be closed. Requires closure to the public by 10 pm. On 20200615, eases restrictions to up to 50 pct capacity but still appearas to need to close by 10 pm: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1496.pdf

Requires individuals to wear face coverings outdoors when attending public events, retail businesses in Attala, Leake, Scott, Jasper, Neshoba, Newton, and Lauderdale Counties only. Coded as a Mandate2 as it is applicable to many indoor settings as well as some outdoor settings. More counties added over time

Extends restaurant restrictions, though allows restaurants that do not serve alcohol have 24-hour per day in-house dining while those that serve alcohol have to close in-house dining to the public no later than 10 pm. Continues prior eased restrictions: maximum of 50 pct capacity, as well as screening of employees and customers. All parties must be seated at least 6 ft from each other, no more than 6 customers at the table, and shared bar areas must remain closed. No live music permitted. Removes 10 pm closing for alcohol-serving locations on 20200615: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1496.pdf Eases on 20200914, allowing up to 75 pct capacity: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1522.pdf. Exteneded to 20210115 https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1535.pdf

Eases restrictions on in-person school closures, allowing for weight rooms and training facilities for use by students if they follow the gym safety and health protocols. Outdoor practices also may resume. Allowed in-person instruction to resume on 20200601: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1492.pdf

Gathering restriction to no more than 20 for indoor settings where social distancing is not possible. Extended to 20200629 https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1496.pdf Extended to 20200720 https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1505.pdfhttps://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1505.pdf

Allows bars to stay open beyond 10 pm. Maintains limit of 50 pct capacity and health safety requirements. Eased on 20200914 to permit 75 pct capacity: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1522.pdf . Extended to 20201211: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1530.pdf. Exteneded to 20210115 https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1535.pdf

Eases restrictions on outdoor and indoor arenas, permitting them to reopen if they do not operate more than 25 pct capacity, and follow business health and safety protocols. Somewhat expanded on 20201211, reducing capacity limits for indoor arenas to 10 pct, extended to 20210115 https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1535.pdf

Social gatherings shall be limited to a maximum of 10 participants indoors and 20 participants outdoors (when social distancing not happening) for the following counties: Claiborne, De Soto, Grenada, Harrison, Hinds, Jackson, Jefferson, Madison, Quitman, Rankin, Sunflower, Washington, Wayne. On 20200720, added Bolivar, Covington, Forrest, Humphreys, Panola, Sharkey, Simpson, Tallahatchie, Tate and Walthall to this restriction: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1509.pdf

All indoor gatherings are limited to a maximum of 10 individuals statewide. This limitation does not apply to religious entities, students in classrooms. Counties had been gradually added to a 10 person gathering restriction since 20200710.
All persons residing in Mississippi must immediately home-isolate on first knowledge of infection, and must remain in the home or appropriate residential location for 14 days from onset of illness.

The start of the 2020-21 academic year for public schools in Bolivar, Coahoma, Forrest, George, Hinds, Panola, Sunflower, and Washington Counties for grades 7 thorugh 12 shall be delayed until Monday August 17 2020.

(quote) Every person in Mississippi shall wear a face covering, covering the nose and mouth, while inside a school building or classroom, or when outdoors on a school campus whenever it is not possible to maintain a minimum of six feet of social distancing from another person not in the same household (quote). Exceptions are also noted in the EO. Extended to 20210115 https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1535.pdf

Every person in Mississippi shall wear a face covering while inside a business, school, or other building or space open to the public, or when in an outdoor public space whenever it is not possible to maintain a minimum of six feet of social distancing. Exemptions include persons who cannot wear a face covering due to conditions that would cause trouble breathing, while eating and drinking, children under the age of 6. Coded as a Mandate3 under PublicMaskLevel as it broadly applies to indoor and outdoor settings. Extended to 20200930 https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1522.pdf Ended on 20200930, replaced with a recommendation: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1525.pdf

When social distancing is not possible, all indoor gatherings are limited to a maximum of 10 individuals statewide, and 50 outside. When social distancing is possible, all indoor gatherings are limited to a maximum of 20 individuals statewide, and 100 outside. This limitation does not apply to religious entities, students in classrooms.

Eases gym and fitness center restrictions, permitting them to be open up to 75 pct capacity. Removes time restrictions, permitting them to be open 24 hours a day. Extended to 20210115 https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1535.pdf

Eases gathering restrictions. When social distancing is not possible, all indoor gatherings are limited to a maximum of 20 individuals statewide, and 100 outside. This limitation does not apply to religious entities, students in classrooms. Effective 20201111, applies to all counties except Benton, Carroll, Covington, DeSoto, Forrest, Harrison, Humphreys, Jackson, Lamar, Lauderdale, Leflore, Lee, Marshall, Rankin, Yalobusha https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1530.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateExpiry to 20201211 and updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) all persons in Mississippi are strongly encouraged to follow the CDC and Mississippi DoH guidelines...wearing a face covering, covering the nose and mouth, while in public spaces wheenver it is not possible to maintain a minimum of 6 ft of social distancing from persons not in the same household (quote). Effective 20201111, applies to all counties except Benton, Carroll, Covington, DeSoto, Forrest, Harrison, Humphreys, Jackson, Lamar, Lauderdale, Leflore, Lee, Marshall, Rankin, Yalobusha https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1530.pdf. Extended to 20210115 https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1535.pdf.

Social gatherings shall be limited to a maximum of 10 individuals indoors and 50 individuals outdoors when social distancing is not possible for the following counties: Chickasaw, Claiborne, DeSoto, Forrest, Itawamba, Jackson, Lamar, Lee, and Neshoba. This limitation does not apply to religious entities, students in classrooms. Expanded on 20201028 to include Benton, Carroll, Harrison, Jones, Leake, Madison, and Marshall conuties: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1528.pdf. Effective 20201111, Benton, Carroll, Covington, DeSoto, Forrest, Harrison, Humphreys, Jackson, Lamar, Lauderdale, Leflore, Lee, Marshall, Rankin, Yalobusha counties are under this gathering restriction https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1530.pdf. Effective 20201118, adds Hinds, Itawamba, Madison, Montegomery, Pontotoc, Tate and Winston counties to this restriction https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1531.pdf. Effective 20201125, adds Alcorn, Attala, Bolivar, Chickasaw, Choctaw, Jefferson Davis, Jones, Lafayette, Lawrence, Lincoln, Lowndes, Neshoba, Panola, Perry, Prentiss, Stone, Tippah, Tishomingo, Union counties to this restriction https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1532.pdf

Requires individuals in Chickasaw, Claiborne, DeSoto, Forrest, Itawamba, Jackson, Lamar, Lee, and Neshoba counties to wear a face covering. Coded as Mandate2 because requires individuals to wear a mask (quote) when inside a business, school, building or other indoor space (quote) when social distancing is not possible. Expanded on 20201028 to include Benton, Carroll, Harrison, Jones, Leake, Madison, and Marshall conuties: https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1528.pdf. Effective 20201111, Benton, Carroll, Covington, DeSoto, Forrest, Harrison, Humphreys, Jackson, Lamar, Lauderdale, Leflore, Lee, Marshall, Rankin, Yalobusha counties are under this mask mandate https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1530.pdf. Effective 20201118, adds Hinds, Itawamba, Madison, Montegomery, Pontotoc, Tate and Winston counties to this restriction https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1531.pdf. Effective 20201125, adds Alcorn, Attala, Bolivar, Chickasaw, Choctaw, Jefferson Davis, Jones, Lafayette, Lawrence, Lincoln, Lowndes, Neshoba, Panola, Perry, Prentiss, Stone, Tippah, Tishomingo, Union counties to this restriction https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1532.pdf. Extended to 20210115 https://www.sos.ms.gov/content/executiveorders/ExecutiveOrders/1535.pdf

Gathering restriction is now statewide. When social distancing is not possible, all gatherings are limited to a maximum of 10 individuals indoors and 50 outdoors. This limitation does not apply to religious entities, students in classrooms.

PolicyCodingNotes: All schools to close on 20200324, closure is supposed to be through end of the academic year (order regarding this goes through 202000601). Order on 20200528 indicates summer school and other on-campus activities may proceed under guidelines set forth by the Department of Elementary and Secondary education, so coded as easing https://health.mo.gov/living/healthcondiseases/communicable/novel-coronavirus/pdf/economic-reopening61-15.pdf Ended at the state-level on 20200714: https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/kctv5.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/9/83/983c5b34-94a7-11ea-8c80-c7d0392bf8a2/5ebb2ff4452e0.pdf.pdf

Requires the closure of coin-operated amusement device and slot machines for public use (essentially casinos). Expires with Executive Order 20-02, the State of Emergency declaration. Closure is extended with emergency declaration declaration to 20200615 https://www.sos.mo.gov/CMSImages/Library/Reference/Orders/2020/20-09.pdf Ended on 20200616 https://governor.mo.gov/show-me-strong-recovery-plan-guidance-and-frequently-asked-questions

(quote) Any entity that does not employ individuals to perform essential worker functions....shall adhere to the limitations on social gatherings and social distancing set forth in sections 4 and 5 of this Order. Entities that do not employ individuals to perform essential worker functions may request a waiver from the limitation on social gatherings, as set forth in section 4 of this Order, from the Director of the Department of Economic Development, on a form prescribed by the Director. For offices and workplaces that remain open, individuals shall practice good hygiene and, where feasible, work from home in order to achieve optimum isolation from COVID-19. (quote) Coding as NEBusinessClose of with a BusinessRestrictLevel of IndoorAllowed and InGathLim of 10 and OutGathLim of 10. Essential retail have capacity limits of either 25 pct or 10 pct capacity per their building codes. However, since this limits are expressly applied to essential businesses, these capacity limits are not applied to this entry. Eased on 20200504: https://health.mo.gov/living/healthcondiseases/communicable/novel-coronavirus/pdf/economic-reopening.pdf Ended on 20200616: https://governor.mo.gov/show-me-strong-recovery-plan-guidance-and-frequently-asked-questions

In effect at 1201 AM on 20200406, expires 1159 PM on 20200424. (quote) Individuals currently residing within the State of Missouri shall avoid leaving their homes or place of residence (quote). Extension through 20200504 https://health.mo.gov/living/healthcondiseases/communicable/novel-coronavirus/pdf/stay-at-home-order-extended.pdf  Ended stay at home order as of 20200504 https://health.mo.gov/living/healthcondiseases/communicable/novel-coronavirus/pdf/economic-reopening.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Added DateEnded of 20200504. On 20200429, updated DateExpiry to 20200504

PolicyCodingNotes: Recommends that individuals in the State of Missouri to wear a cloth facing covering in public settings

Eases restrictions on bars, allowing them to provide in-person services as long as social distancing meaures and precautionary public health measures are adhered to (eg, at least 6 ft between tables, lack of communical seating, having no more than 10 people at a single table). Ends on 20200616: https://governor.mo.gov/show-me-strong-recovery-plan-guidance-and-frequently-asked-questions

(quote) In accordance with the guidelines from the President and the Centers for Disease Control andPrevention (CDC), every person and business in the State of Missouri shall abide by social distancing requirements, including maintaining six feet of space between individuals....This provision shall apply in all situations, including, but not limited to, when customers are standing in line or individuals are using shared indoor or outdoor spaces (quote). Coded as a gathering restriction without numeric limits. On 20200616, ends all restrictions: https://governor.mo.gov/show-me-strong-recovery-plan-guidance-and-frequently-asked-questions

Eases restrictions specifically for businesses engaged in retail sales to the public (no longer distinguishing between essential v. non-essential retail), now permitting up to 25 pct capacity if the building has a sq footage less than 10,000 sq ft or up to 10 pct capacity if a buliding is 10,000 sq ft or more. Also requires social distancing, etc. (quote) This provision shall apply in all situations, including, but not limited to, when customers are standing in line or individuals are using shared indoor or outdoor spaces. (quote) Ended on 20200616: https://governor.mo.gov/show-me-strong-recovery-plan-guidance-and-frequently-asked-questions

Eases restrictions on restaurants, allowing them to provide dining-in services as long as social distancing meaures and precautionary public health measures are adhered to (eg, at least 6 ft between tables, lack of communical seating, having no more than 10 people at a single table). Ended on 20200616 https://governor.mo.gov/show-me-strong-recovery-plan-guidance-and-frequently-asked-questions

Extends school closure through the end of the 2019-2020 academic year, but indicates that summer school and other on-campus activities may proceed under guidelines set forth by the Department of Elementary and Secondary education.
