PolicyCodingNotes: All non-residential public schools to close effective immediately, through 20200327, hence SchoolRestrictLevel is NoInPerson. On 20200324, closure extended to 20200410 http://governor.mt.gov/Portals/16/Closure%20Extensions%20and%20Social%20Distancing.pdf?ver=2020-03-24-164313-497  Devovles control to local school districts as of 20200507, allowing schools to make their own reopening decisions.  https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/04-22-20%20Directive%20and%20Appx%20-%20Reopening%20Phase%20One.pdf?ver=2020-04-22-124954-977

Limited operations required (delivery, window service, drive through): bars, taverns, breweries, distilleries, wineries, and alcoholic beverage service businesses. In effect at 8 pm on 20200320, Initial expiry is 20200327 at 1159 pm, so 20200328. On 20200324, order extended this through 20200410 http://governor.mt.gov/Portals/16/Closure%20Extensions%20and%20Social%20Distancing.pdf?ver=2020-03-24-164313-497. Easing begins on 20200504 https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/04-22-20%20Directive%20and%20Appx%20-%20Reopening%20Phase%20One.pdf?ver=2020-04-22-124954-977

Closure required: casinos, fitness centers, entertainment venues, indoor facilities in ski areas, bowling alleys, music halls. In effect at 8 pm on 20200320. Initial expiry is 20200327 at 1159 pm, so 20200328. At least some easing of these businesses (eg, casinos) can start 20200504 https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/04-22-20%20Directive%20and%20Appx%20-%20Reopening%20Phase%20One.pdf?ver=2020-04-22-124954-977 More easing on 20200508 Effective May 15, 2020, the following businesses can become operational during Phase I under strict physical distancing and reduced capacity protocols in accordance with the Phase One Directive and the Guidance attached to this Directive: Gyms and fitness studios, Pools at gyms, Theaters, including movie theaters, Museums https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/Phase%20One%20Expansion%20Plus%20Guidance.pdf?ver=2020-05-08-150423-113 Further easing moving into Phase 2 on 20200601 allowing most places to open at 75 pct capacity https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/Phase%20Two%20Directive%20with%20Appendices.pdf?ver=2020-05-19-145442-350

Limited operations required (delivery, window service, drive through): restaurants, food establishments. In effect at 8 pm on 20200320, Initial expiry is 20200327 at 1159 pm, so 20200328. On 20200324, order extended this through 20200410 http://governor.mt.gov/Portals/16/Closure%20Extensions%20and%20Social%20Distancing.pdf?ver=2020-03-24-164313-497. Easing begins on 20200504 https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/04-22-20%20Directive%20and%20Appx%20-%20Reopening%20Phase%20One.pdf?ver=2020-04-22-124954-977

Non-essential social and recreational gatherings greater than 10 are prohibited immediately. As of 20200328 expands the gathering restriction https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/Stay%20at%20Home%20Directive.pdf?ver=2020-03-26-173332-177

Non-essential social and recreational gatherings of any number of people are prohibited immediately. As of 20200426, ends gathering restrictions https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/04-22-20%20Directive%20and%20Appx%20-%20Reopening%20Phase%20One.pdf?ver=2020-04-22-124954-977

(quote) All businesses and operations in the State, except Esssential Businesses and Operations as defined below, are required to cease all activities (quote). In effect at 1201 am 20200328, initial expiry is through 20200410. Started easing NEBusinessClose on 20200427 https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/04-22-20%20Directive%20and%20Appx%20-%20Reopening%20Phase%20One.pdf?ver=2020-04-22-124954-977 Further easing moving into Phase 2 on 20200601 https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/Phase%20Two%20Directive%20with%20Appendices.pdf?ver=2020-05-19-145442-350

In effect at 1201 am 20200328, initial expiry is through 20200410. Policy ended on 20200426 https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/04-22-20%20Directive%20and%20Appx%20-%20Reopening%20Phase%20One.pdf?ver=2020-04-22-124954-977

Any person coming to Montana must self-quarantine for 14 days, anyone who has already arrived must self-quarantine for the remainder of the 14 day period. As of 20200601, quarantine mandate ends https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/Phase%20Two%20Directive%20with%20Appendices.pdf?ver=2020-05-19-145442-350

Eases the previous gathering restriction to a recommendation. (quote) All individuals should avoid gathering in groups of more than 10 people in circumsntances that do not readily allow for appropriate physical distancing (quote). Eased on 20200601 http://governor.mt.gov/Portals/16/Directive%20on%20Bars%20and%20Restaurants.pdf?ver=2020-03-20-101314-940

Recommends that all vulnerable individuals should continue to follow stay-at-home guidance, with vulnerable individuals being those over 65, with serious underlying health conditions (e.g., high blood pressure, chronic lung disease, obesity, asthma) or individuals whose immune systems are compromised. Extended on 20200601 https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/Phase%20Two%20Directive%20with%20Appendices.pdf?ver=2020-05-19-145442-350

Eases previous business closures, with businesses eligible for re-opening are main street and retail businesses if they adhere to re-opening guidelines. Physical distancing of 6 ft must be maintained between customers and this may require a reduction in capacity, a reduction of seating in service or waiting areas, management of waiting areas and lines or systems that reduce amount of contact time. Health assessments of employees must be conducted at beginning of each shift. Outdoor recreation (such as public lands, fishing sites, parks) can also become operational if sites adhere to strict physical distancing between groups and exercise frequent sanitation. Personal care services may also reopen under the re-opening guidelines.

Eases restrictions on bars, taverns, breweries, distilleries, wineries, and alcoholic beverage service businesses, allowing them to be operational for in-person services if they follow strict physical distancing and reduced capacity protocols (50 pct), as well as closing operations strictly by 1130 pm and expansions for delivery as possible. Tables must be limited to 6 people. Sitting or standing at bars not allowed. Self-service buffets and drink refills not allowed. Further easing on 20200601 as Phase Two allows them to operate at 75 pct capacity: https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/Phase%20Two%20Directive%20with%20Appendices.pdf?ver=2020-05-19-145442-350 On 20201120, re-expands restrictions, requiring no more than 50 pct capacity and closure by 10 pm: https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/2020-11-17_Directive%20on%20Group%20Size%20and%20Capacity%20-%20FINAL.pdf?ver=2020-11-17-150044-130

Easing restrictions for casinos to open, conditional on following Phase One general and specific guidelines under the EO, including a 50 pct limit on normal operating capacity. On 20200601 further eases to 75 pct capacity as part of Phase Two: https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/Phase%20Two%20Directive%20with%20Appendices.pdf?ver=2020-05-19-145442-350 On 20201120, re-expands restrictions, reducing capacity to 50 pct https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/2020-11-17_Directive%20on%20Group%20Size%20and%20Capacity%20-%20FINAL.pdf?ver=2020-11-17-150044-130

Eases restraurant restrictions, allowing them to re-open if they follow strict physical distancing and reduced capacity protocols (50 pct of normal operating capacity), as well as closing operations strictly by 1130 pm and expansions for delivery as possible. Tables must be limited to 6 people. Sitting or standing at bars not allowed. Self-service buffets and drink refills not allowed. Eased on 20200601, permitting up to 75 pct: https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/Phase%20Two%20Directive%20with%20Appendices.pdf?ver=2020-05-19-145442-350 On 20201120, re-expands restrictions, requiring no more than 50 pct capacity and closure by 10 pm: https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/2020-11-17_Directive%20on%20Group%20Size%20and%20Capacity%20-%20FINAL.pdf?ver=2020-11-17-150044-130  On 20201120, re-expands restrictions, requiring no more than 50 pct capacity and closure by 10 pm: https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/2020-11-17_Directive%20on%20Group%20Size%20and%20Capacity%20-%20FINAL.pdf?ver=2020-11-17-150044-130

Recommends that individuals wear masks while in public. (quote) Strongly consider using non-medical face coverings while in public, especially in circumstances that do not readily allow for appropriate physical distancing (e.g., grocery/retail stores, pharmacies, public transportation). (quote)
(quote) Effective June 1, avoid gathering in groups of more than 50 people in circumstances that do not readily allow for appropriate physical distancing (quote). Coded as a gathering recommendation

Requires that all public-facing employees, contractors, and volunteers to wear a face covering at all businesses, government offices, or other persons responsible for indoor spaces open to the public. Exemptions are for those seeking to communicate with someone who is hearing impaired, persons giving speeches or performances.

(quote)  all businesses, government offices, or other persons responsible for indoor spaces open to the public shall require and take reasonable measures to ensure that all employees, contractors, volunteers, customers, or other members of the public wear a face covering that covers their mouth and nose at all times while entering or remaining in any indoor spaces open to the public (quote). For all outdoor gatherings of 50 or more people, individuals are required to wear face coverings when it is not possible to maintain at least 6 ft of physical distance. Exemptions for children under 5, for individuals for whom wearing a mask is not medically possible, during exercise, etc. Technically only applies to counties with 4 or more confirmed active cases of COVID-19 (stongly encourages counties with 3 or fewer confirmed active cases to wear masks), but these locations are not clearly listed - subsequently, treating this as a statewide mandate. Coding as a Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel as its requirements for outdoor settings are very limited.

Mandates the use of face coverings at all public and private K-12 schools per the July 15 mask mandate such that indoor school spaces are considered indoor spaces open to the public and school-related outdoor activities are considered organied outdoor activities. From the July 15 order: (quote) all businesses, government offices, or other persons responsible for indoor spaces open to the public shall require and take reasonable measures to ensure that all employees, contractors, volunteers, customers, or other members of the public wear a face covering that covers their mouth and nose at all times while entering or remaining in any indoor spaces open to the public (quote). For all outdoor gatherings of 50 or more people, individuals are required to wear face coverings when it is not possible to maintain at least 6 ft of physical distance. Exemptions for children under 5, for individuals for whom wearing a mask is not medically possible, during exercise, etc. Technically only applies to counties with 4 or more confirmed active cases of COVID-19 (strongly encourages counties with 3 or fewer confirmed active cases to wear masks), but these locations are not clearly listed - subsequently, treating this as a statewide mandate.

Expands gathering restrictions, (quote) Any public gatherings or events where it is not possible to practice social distancing or where social distancing is not being practiced must be strictly limited to 25 people or fewer (quote). Exempts houses of worship, wherein social distancing should occur for all in-person services
State of Emergency declaration. Does not appear to include formal expiry.

PolicyCodingNotes: Strongly recommends limiting all gatherings, especially those gatherings of more than 50 people. Not a formal restriction.

Schools for all counties are closed for in-person instruction as of 20200401 until 20200531. Eases restrictions on school-based activities starting on 20200601, allowing school-based sports team practices http://dhhs.ne.gov/Documents/COVID-19-Outline-of-Changes-to-Upcoming-DHMs-Phase-II.pdf. Extended to 20200801 https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-new-directed-health-measures-effective-june-22nd-proclaims-%E2%80%9Cdairy-month On 20200720 Dept of Education released the Launch Nebraska Plan which discusses reopening procedures for schools and category based policies for schools to follow https://www.launchne.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/PlanningASafeReturn.pdf.

Bar and tavern restrictions applied to all counties starting on 20200403. Easing began for a subset of counties on 20200504, but only allowing alcohol to be sold with meals (and thus restrictions remain for non-food serving venues) http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/COVID-19-Directed-Health-Measures.asp. Extended to 20200914: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Phase-3-and-Phase-4-Directed-Health-Measures-Extended-Until-Sept.-13.aspx All regional health departments move to Phase 4 on 20200914, ending restrictions: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/DHHS-Friday-COVID-19-Update-09112020.aspx

Individuals with symptoms or diagnosed with COVID-19 must self-quarantine at home for 14 days. Extended to 20200914: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Phase-3-and-Phase-4-Directed-Health-Measures-Extended-Until-Sept.-13.aspx Extended to 20201101 with latest set of directed health measures: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/DHHS-Friday-COVID-19-Update-09112020.aspx Extends to 20201201: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Documents/SHHD-DHM-October.pdf Eased to reduce time of isolation on 20201203, but also extended to 20210101: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Documents/SHHD-DHM-December.pdf

PolicyCodingNotes: Gather restrictions expanded to all counties on 20200403. Somewhat eased on 20200504 as religious services became exempt from gathering limits: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/COVID-19-Directed-Health-Measures.aspx

Restaurant restrictions applied to all counties starting on 20200403. Easing began for a subset of counties on 20200504 http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/COVID-19-Directed-Health-Measures.asp. Extended to 20200914: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Phase-3-and-Phase-4-Directed-Health-Measures-Extended-Until-Sept.-13.aspx All regional health departments move to Phase 4 on 20200914, ending restrictions: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/DHHS-Friday-COVID-19-Update-09112020.aspx
Recommends that Nebraskans (quote) Wear a cloth face covering in public (grocery stores, pharmacies etc.) when you can't stay 6 feet away from others.(quote)

In-person services must cease for all beauty/nail salons, barber shops, massage therapy, gentlemans clubs, bottle clubs, indoor movie theatres, indoor theatres, tattoo parlors. Shared at a 20200409 press release, signed on 20200410, so the latter is coded as the enact date. Easing for a subset of businesses in a subset of counties began on 20200504 http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/COVID-19-Directed-Health-Measures.aspx Extended to 20200914: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Phase-3-and-Phase-4-Directed-Health-Measures-Extended-Until-Sept.-13.aspx All regional health departments move to Phase 4 on 20200914, ending restrictions: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/DHHS-Friday-COVID-19-Update-09112020.aspx

Under the 19 regional directed health measures, gathering restrictions of 10 or more continue to at least 20200531. Religious services, including weddings or funerals are allowed but must maintain social distancing (6 ft apart) among parties of individuals. Easing began on 20200601, when 17 out of 19 regional health districts moved to the next phase http://dhhs.ne.gov/Documents/COVID-19-Outline-of-Changes-to-Upcoming-DHMs-Phase-II.pdf

Gathering restrictions to 25 people or 25 percent of applicable occupancy (whichever is greater) in 17 of 19 regional health districts (does not apply to Central and Dakota County). Also exempts religious services. Began easing for 17 out of 19 health regions on 20200622 but the remaining two regions went to this gathering restriction, extending to 20200801 https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-new-directed-health-measures-effective-june-22nd-proclaims-%E2%80%9Cdairy-month.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) Every individual who enters the State of Nebraska as the final destination from any international point of origin, and individuals who reside or resided with an individual who enters the State of Nebraska as the final destination from any international point of origin, shall home-quarantine (quote) Extended to 20200914: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Phase-3-and-Phase-4-Directed-Health-Measures-Extended-Until-Sept.-13.aspx Omitted from new set of directed health measures, now state recommendations are the policy: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/COVID-19-Traveler-Recommendations.aspx

For 17 of 19 regional health districts (does not apply to Central and Dakota County) that move to Phase 3, gathering restriction eased to 50 pct for an indoor facility occupancy, or 75 pct of outdoor facility occpancy. No gathering more than 10,000 people

Dakota County and Central regional health district (Merrick, Hall, Hamilton counties) move to Phase 3, bringing gathering restrictions statewide: 50 pct for an indoor facility occupancy, or 75 pct of outdoor facility occpancy. No gathering more than 10,000 people. On 20200724 and 20200801, regional health districts moved to Phase 4, easing their gathering restrictions: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Southwest-Nebraska-Public-Health-Department-Prepares-to-Move-to-Next-DHM-Phase.aspx Extended to 20200914: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Phase-3-and-Phase-4-Directed-Health-Measures-Extended-Until-Sept.-13.aspx
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateExpiry to 20200914, added DateEased of 20200724

PolicyCodingNotes: Loup Basin health department region moves to Phase 4, where indoor gatherings are now limited to 75 pct rated occupancy (previously 50 pct under Phase 3), and full occupancy for outdoor facilities. On 20200801, North Central and Southwest move to Phase 4, joining Loup basin with these gathering restrictions http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Southwest-Nebraska-Public-Health-Department-Prepares-to-Move-to-Next-DHM-Phase.aspx

All regional health departments move to Phase 4, where indoor gatherings are now limited to 75 pct rated occupancy (previously 50 pct under Phase 3), and full occupancy for outdoor facilities. No absolute numeric limits.

(quote) Nebraskans returning home from international travel (excluding healthcare workers, commuters, and other unique groups as defined below) should self-quarantine and self-monitor for 14 days upon return/arrival (quote). Note that these recommendations have been in place since June 1 but it was only in the latest set of directed health measures where explicit requirements on travel-based quarantines were excluded.

Expands gathering restriction in all regional health department areas, a maximum of 50 pct occupancy (not to exceed 10,000) indoors and maximum 10,000 for outdoors. Extends to 20210101: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Gov-Ricketts-Urges-Continued-Precautions-to-Slow-the-Spread-of-Coronavirus.aspx.

At personal care services (salons, barber shops, massage therapy services, and tattoo parlors/body art facilities), both workers and patrons are required to wear masks at all times. Exemptions include when service are performed on faces, but 6 ft distancing must occur with all other customers and the provider must wear a face covering. Also requires that employees wear masks in the following settings: (quote) For beauty/nail salons, barbershops, massage therapy offices or centers, bowling alleys, pool halls, body art or tattoo establishments, and any other indoor businesses where staff and patrons are within six ( 6) feet of each other for fifteen (15) consecutive minutes or more: Such businesses shall require the use of masks, or other item sufficient to cover an individuals mouth and nose, for all staff, practitioners and patrons (quote) Extends to 20210101: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Gov-Ricketts-Urges-Continued-Precautions-to-Slow-the-Spread-of-Coronavirus.aspx. Eased on 20201212, masks are now recommended not required:https://governor.nebraska.gov/press/gov-ricketts-announces-new-directed-health-measures-take-effect-saturday.

Indoor carnivals, fairs, and dances are prohibited. Coding as a business closure. Note that many other businesses have requirements now for 6 ft distancing between parties (gyms/fitness centers, health spas, gentlemen and bottle clubs, personal care services like salons, barber shops, massage therapy, tattoo parlors) but this does not trigger a business closure under the current coding system (has to be a maximum of 25 pct capacity or less than 10 people on premises at a time) Extends to 20210101: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Gov-Ricketts-Urges-Continued-Precautions-to-Slow-the-Spread-of-Coronavirus.aspx.

For restaurants, bars, taverns, bowling alleys, private clubs, bottle clubs, and gentleman clubs, (quote) Individuals who are participating in games, including but not limited to: pool, darts, shuffleboard, air hockey, pinball or video/arcade games, must be required to wear a mask, except when those individuals are eating or drinking. (quote) In addition, (quote) For beauty/nail salons, barbershops, massage therapy offices or centers, bowling alleys, pool halls, body art or tattoo establishments, and any other indoor businesses where staff and patrons are within six ( 6) feet of each other for fifteen (15) consecutive minutes or more: Such businesses shall require the use of masks, or other item sufficient to cover an individuals mouth and nose, for all staff, practitioners and patrons, except for those patrons receiving services directly to their face. Patrons may remove their mask only while receiving services directly to their face (quote). Coding as a Mandate1 under PublicMaskLevel as it does not broadly apply across indoor settings, providing exemptions for indoor setting where 6 ft distancing can be maintained for at least 15 minutes. DPM: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Documents/SHHD-DHM-November9.pdf Extends to 20210101: http://dhhs.ne.gov/Pages/Gov-Ricketts-Urges-Continued-Precautions-to-Slow-the-Spread-of-Coronavirus.aspx.

Eases statewide mask requirement at businesses as Nebraska moves from orange phase to yellow phase. Masks are now recommended, rather than required, for establishments such as childcare centers, personal care services (salons, barber shops, massage therapy services, and tattoo parlors/body art facilities), and recreation centers (bowling alleys, pool halls).

Eases statewide gathering restrictions as Nebraska moves from orange phase to yellow phase. Indoor gatherings may be held at up to 50 pct capacity with parties of 8 and outdoor gathering may be held at 100 pct capacity with parties of 8. Religious gatherings have no restrictions but safety guidance remains and is recommended. District health deparments may implement stricter policies.

State of emergency declared. Extended through 20200630, so coded to 20200701. https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Directive-021-Phase-Two-Reopening-Plan.pdf Extended without expiry on 20200731: http://gov.nv.gov/News/Emergency_Orders/2020/2020-07-31_-_COVID-19_Declaration_of_Emergency_Directive_029/

Recommendation is only included in press script, and only emphasizes high-risk populations and (quote) older adult or Nevadan with an underlying serious or long-term medical condition, please take additional actions to reduce your risk of getting sick with this disease. I strongly urge you...(quote)
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: All schools (public, private, charter) for K-12 closed effective 20200316, until order is rescinded. Cannot open earlier than 20200406. Extended to no earlier than 20200416 on 20200320 http://gov.nv.gov/uploadedFiles/govnewnvgov/Content/News/Emergency_Orders/2020/2020-03-20%20-%20COVID-19%20Declaration%20of%20Emergency%20Declaration%20Directive%20005.pdf Extended.   to no earlier than 20200430 on 20200414 https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Directive-014-Signed.pdf.  On 20200421, school closure extended from 20200430 until the end of the school year. Ended for in-person instruction on 20200610 as authority granted to local school districts. https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/2020-06-09.Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-022.pdf On 20200728 schools were directed to observe transmission rates in their community when deciding to adopt distanced, hybrid or in person reopening. Guidance was provided on social distancing, positive case scenario and athletic practice for students https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/2020-07-28.Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-028.pdf

Recommendation expressed through press release script, but not codified in an order. (quote) All gatherings should be postponed or canceled. This is not the time for sleepovers, playdates, concerts, theater outings, or athletic events. (quote)
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: Verbally ordered on 20200317, formal issuance on 20200318 and goes into effect at 1159 pm on 20200318 for closing casinos (quote) Nevada general public shall cease gathering at gaming establishments, and all gaming devices, machines, tables, games, and any equipment related to gaming activity shall cease operations (quote). Eased on 20200604, as part of Phase 2: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Directive-021-Phase-Two-Reopening-Plan.pdf. Extended to 20200801 https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-026-re-Phase-2-Extension.6-29-20-1.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Deleted DateExpiry based on latest extension with no expiry.

PolicyCodingNotes: Goes into effect immediately, through 20200430. Public gathering directive was signed on 20200324 also banning groups more than 10

Closes all non-essential businesses that promote recreational social gatherings, which pertains to bars and like venues. Began easing on 20200529: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Directive-021-Phase-Two-Reopening-Plan.pdf. Extended to 20200801: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-026-re-Phase-2-Extension.6-29-20-1.pdf On 20200710, requires bars and like venues not licensed to sell food to close for all in-person services in counties with Elevated Disease Transmission Risk (Clark, Elko, Humboldt, Lander, Lyon, Nye, Washoe): https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Emergency-Directive-027.pdf. On 20201124, expands statewide bar restrictions under the Nevada Statewide Pause. Allows indoor and outdoor service for breweries, distilleries, and wineries not licensed to sell food, allowing them to operate at a maximum of 25 pct capacity (from 50 pct), no more than 4 people per table, tables have to spaced at least 6 ft, face coverings must be worn at all times, and reservations required at establishments that sell food. https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/NV-Statewide-Pause-Guidance-Matrix.pdf. Extended to 20210116: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/12.13-GOV-REMARKS_final.pdf.

In effect on 20200320 at 1159 pm, coded to 20200321. Closure required: social gathering venues and businesses (recreation centers, clubhouses, nightclubs, movie theaters, massage parlors, adult entertainment establishments, brothels, and live entertainment venues), as well as businesses that promote extended periods of public interaction (fitness establishments and aesthteic services). In effect through 20200416 Extended to 20200801 https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-026-re-Phase-2-Extension.6-29-20-1.pdf. On 20201124, extends closure of night clubs, day clubs, brothels, adult entertainment facilities. Allows a maximum occupancy of 25 pct (from 50 pct) and adherence to safety measures. Applies to gyms, fitness centers, gaming venues, arcades, racetracks, bowling alleys, amusement and theme parks, libraries, museums, galleries, and zoos. Allows a maximum occupancy of 50 pct. Applies to retail, indoor malls, aestheticians and salons, body art or piercing establishments, and community and recreation centers.  https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/NV-Statewide-Pause-Guidance-Matrix.pdf. Extended to 20210116: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/12.13-GOV-REMARKS_final.pdf.

In effect on 20200320 at 1159 pm, coded to 20200321. Limited operations required (onsite dining must cease): restaurants and food establishments.  In effect through 20200416. Extends easing of restaurant operations (which allowed them to utilize tables and serve food within the bar area) quote (Directive 021, Phase 2 of the Nevada United: Roadmap to Recovery plan, is hereby extended to July 31st at 11.59pm) https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-026-re-Phase-2-Extension.6-29-20-1.pdf On 20200710, re-imposes some restrictions for counties designated as Elevated Disease Transmission Risk (Clark, Elko, Humboldt, Lander, Lyon, Nye, Washoe), requiring bar areas and bar tops to close: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Emergency-Directive-027.pdf. On 20201124, expands statewide restaurant restrictions under the Nevada Statewide Pause. Allows indoor and outdoor service for restaurants and like venues, allowing them to operate at a maximum of 25 pct capacity (from 50 pct), no more than 4 people per table, tables have to spaced at least 6 ft, face coverings must be worn at all times, and reservations are required. https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/NV-Statewide-Pause-Guidance-Matrix.pdf. Extended to 20210116: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/12.13-GOV-REMARKS_final.pdf.

More stringent restriction than the 20200319 issuance, governor indicates escalating penalties for not complying. On 20200408, also applies the 10+ ban to places of worship, so expanded. Eased on 20200529 with the introduction of gathering restrictions of up to 50: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Directive-021-Phase-Two-Reopening-Plan.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Deleted DateExpiry based on latest extension with no expiry.

PolicyCodingNotes: Individuals may leave to access essential services on behalf of themselves, pets, or members of households. Exemptions for outdoor activity as long as individuals do not congregate beyond members of their household. Exemption for individuals experiencing homelessness. Eased to strong recommendation, effective 20200509 : http://gov.nv.gov/News/Emergency_Orders/2020/2020-05-07_-_COVID-19_Declaration_of_Emergency_Directive_018_-_Phase_One_Reopening/  Recommendation extended to 20200701 https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Directive-021-Phase-Two-Reopening-Plan.pdf

Eased restrictions start on 20200501, allowing golf courses and tennis to resume: http://gov.nv.gov/News/Emergency_Orders/2020/2020-04-29_-_COVID-19_Declaration_of_Emergency_Directive_016_(Attachments)/  Extended to 20200801: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-026-re-Phase-2-Extension.6-29-20-1.pdf

PolicyCodingNotes: See section 6 - (quote) persons testing positive for COVID-19 shall stay at home and self-quarantine for a minimum of two weeks, except as necessary to care for themselves or seek medical care (quote)
LastUpdatedNotes: Deleted DateExpiry based on latest extension with no expiry.

PolicyCodingNotes: (Quote) Nevada public should utilize face coverings in public spaces (Quote)
All vulnerable people are strongly encouraged to stay home

(quote) Recognizing that COVID-19 is still present in Nevada and highly contagious, Nevadans are advised that they are safer at home and should avoid interpersonal contact with persons not residing in their households to the extent practicable.(quote)

Gatherings of more than 50 people prohibited. Extended without expiry on 20200731: http://gov.nv.gov/News/Emergency_Orders/2020/2020-07-31_-_COVID-19_Declaration_of_Emergency_Directive_029/ Eased on 20201001: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Declaration-of-Emergency-Directive-033.pdf.

(quote) Individuals not exempted by this Directive...shall be required to cover their nose and mouth with a mask or face covering when in a public space (quote). Exempts children 9 years and younger, individuals who cannot wear a face covering due to a medical condition or disability, etc. Coded as Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies to public spaces broadly.

Bars, pubs, taverns, breweries, distilleries, and wineries not licensed to serve food must close for in-person service (take-out, curbside, and home delivery is permitted) in counties designated with Elevated Disease Transmission. As of 20200710, this applies to 7 counties: Clark, Elko, Humboldt, Lander, Lyon, Nye, Washoe. As of 20200804 this applies to Clark, Elko, Nye and Washoe. As of 20200821 this applies to  Clark, Elko, and Washoe. As of 20200827 this applies to Elko. As of 20200921 this applies to no more counties, but it remains on the books - coding it as easing.

Restaurants and food establishments, as well as bars and like venues licensed to serve food, must operate under Phase One conditions (maximum of 50 pct capacity, tables have to spaced at least 6 ft, no bar tops or bar areas open, buffets and self-serving dining facilities must remain closed) in counties designated with Elevated Disease Transmission. As of 20200710, this applies to 7 counties: Clark, Elko, Humboldt, Lander, Lyon, Nye, Washoe.

Eases gathering restrictions. Section 10 of Directive 021 is terminated, public gatherings are now restricted to the lesser of 250 persons, or 50 pct of the listed fire code capacity. Section 11 of Directive 021 is also terminated, houses of worship may now conduct indoor services so that occupancy shall not exceed the lesser of 50 pct capacity or 250 persons. Expanded for all counties other than Washoe (Carson City, Churchill, Clark, Douglas, Elko, Esmeralda, Eureka, Humboldt, Lander, Lincoln, Lyon, Mineral, Nye, Pershing, Storey, White Pine) on 20201105: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/11.5.20-Task-Force-Press-Release.pdf.

Expands gathering restrictions for Washoe County. (quote) Public gatherings in Washoe County are to be limited to 50 people or less for all indoor and outdoor events. (quote) Religious gatherings and places of worship are unspecified.

Statewide gathering restrictions under three week Nevade Statewide Pause. Public gatherings are restricted to the lesser of 50 persons (from 250), or 25 pct of the listed fire code capacity (from 25 pct). Places of worship are limited to gatherings of 50 people if capacity is fewer than 200 persons. Private gatherings are limited to 10 people from no more than 2 households, both indoors and outdoors. Extended to 20210116: https://nvhealthresponse.nv.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/12.13-GOV-REMARKS_final.pdf.

Expands gathering restrictions for places of worship. Faith gatherings and houses of worship are limited to 25 pct capacity. Coded as an expansion because although it no longer specifies absolute limits, it previously allowed for up to 50 people when capacity is 200 people and otherwise 25 pct capacity. Outdoor services are allowed subject to State guidance for gatherings, so coded as 50. Continues limits for public gatherings, which are restricted to the lesser of 50 persons, or 25 pct of the listed fire code capacity. Private gatherings are limited to 10 people from no more than 2 households, both indoors and outdoors. No expiry listed.

State of Emergency declaration. Initial order does not appear to provide explicit expiry date. Prohibits scheduled gatherings of 50 or more, inclusive of faith-based gatherings. Initial expiry is 20200406.

New Hampshire department of health recommends that all Granite Staters wear cloth face coverings when outside of the home to help slow the spread of COVID-19.

Stay-at-home order is eased to a recommendation, also strongly advising vulnerable populations to stay at home Extended to 20201115 https://www.governor.nh.gov/sites/g/files/ehbemt336/files/documents/emergency-order-70.pdf. PolicyCodingNotes: Face coverings shall be required for all person who attend or are otherwise present at the following activities in New Hampshire: scheduled gatherings of 100 for social, spiritual, and recreational activities. Provides exemptions for gatherings where seating with at least 6 ft distancing occurs (and when seated), day-to-day operatins for profit and non-profit organizations (inclusive of government buildings and schools), and children under 2. Coded as a Mandate1 under PublicMaskLevel as this policy applies to very limited settings. Extended to 20201115 https://www.governor.nh.gov/sites/g/files/ehbemt336/files/documents/emergency-order-70.pdf. Extended to 20210115 https://www.governor.nh.gov/sites/g/files/ehbemt336/files/documents/emergency-order-72.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateExpiry to 20210115 and updated PolicyCodingNotes

PolicyCodingNotes: Effective 20201115, all residents and travelers in New Hampshire must comply with the following travel guidelines: Self-quarantine for 14 days following the last date of any high risk travel, which includes travel internationally, on a cruise ship, or domestically outside of the New England states of Maine, Vermont, Massachusetts, Connecticut, or Rhode Island for nonessential purposes. People meeting the criteria for high-risk travel have the option of shortening their quarantine by getting a COVID test on day 7 of their quarantine.

(quote) all persons over the age of 5 within the State of New Hampshire shall wear a mask or cloth face covering over their noses and mouths any time they are in public spaces, indoors or outdoors, where they are unable to or do not consistently maintain a physical distance of at least six feet from persons outside their own households (quote) Exemptions are for K-12 schools, individuals who are medically unable to wear a mask, eating/drinking, etc. Coded as a Mandate3 under PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly to indoor and outdoor settings.

State of Emergency declared (as well as Public Health Emergency). Recommending the cancellation of all public gatherings more than 250

(quote) The brick-and-mortar premises of all non-essential retail businesses must close to the public as long as this Order remains in effect. (quote) Also expressly closes the following: Also explicitly closes personal care services and libraries, all types of public amusement (locations with amusement parks, water parks, aquariums, zoos, arcades, fairs, childrens play centers, funplexes, theme parks, bowling alleys, family and childrens attractions), indoor malls. Expressly closes parks, golf courses, etc on 20200407: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-118.pdf Expressly halts non-essential construction on 20200408: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-122.pdf Begins easing on 20200502: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-133.pdf

(quote) All New Jersey residents shall remain home or at their place of residence unless they are…(quote) - until it is revoked or modified by governor.  Takes effect at 9 pm 20200321. Ended on 20200609 https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-153.pdf

Requires customers to wear cloth face coverings while on premises of essential retail businesses (e.g., groceries, pharmacies, among others). Exemptions are made for individuals under the age of two years and for individuals where wearing a mask would inhibit the individuals health. Coded as Mandate1 under PublicMaskLevel as it applies to limited settings.

Requires adoption business health and safety protocols for essential retail businesses, including requiring workers and customers to wear cloth face coverings while on premises. In addition: (quote) If a customer refuses to wear a cloth face covering for non-medical reasons and if such covering cannot be provided to the individual by the business at the point of entry, then the business must decline entry to the individual (quote).

Eases restrictions on golf courses (public and private) and state parks and forests, if they follow requirements (golf courses: reservations only, stagger tee times, frequent sanitation, golf carts are single occupant only, recommended facial coverings. State parks and forests: employees and visitors should wear cloth face coverings while in the State Park or Forest in all settings, available parking must be limited at all State Parks and Forests at 50 pct of the maximum capacity at one time, no picnicking). Coded as OutdoorOnly under BusinessRestrictLevel because buildings such as visitor centers and pro shops are closed. Eases on 20200519, permitting more people at golf courses (still outdoor only).

Eases previous restrictions on closed businesses, allowing for curbside pickup for previously closed non-essential retail businesses. Eased on 20200615, permitting indoor services: https://www.nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-150.pdf

Eases gathering restriction for outdoors, allowing up to 25 people to gather if they also follow appropriate social distancing practices. Continues gathering restriction of 10 people indoors. Eases gathering restrictions on 20200609: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-152.pdf
Eases restrictions to allow restaurants and bars to have outdoor service starting on 20200615: https://www.nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-150.pdf. Extended to 20200704

Eases restrictions on non-essential retail, which may now operate at no more than 50 pct capacity and must require workers and customers to wear cloth face coverings while on the premises. Also permits other types of retail and rental services (e.g., watercraft rental) to re-open for in-person sales.

Eases restrictions to allow restaurants to have outdoor service starting on 20200615: https://www.nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-150.pdf. Extended to 20200704, and eases on 20200702: https://www.nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-150.pdf

Indoor gathering restriction to no more than 50 people given any size of the room. Further stipulations are that the number of individuals cannot exceed 25 pct of the capacity of the room, with a maximum of 50 people. Still requires physical distancing (i.e., 6 ft distancing). If less than 10 people, face masks are not required (recommended). These limits do not apply to outdoor religious gatherings.

Eases restrictions to permit entertainment and recreational businesses closed under EO 107 Paragraph 9 to re-open for outdoor services, as long as they abide to gathering restrictions (i.e., no more than 100 people outdoors, maintain physical distancing of at least 6 ft). These include casinos, racetracks, gyms and fitness centers, enterainment centers (eg, movie theaters, nightclubs, performing art centers), malls, places of public amusement (aquariums, zoos, fairs, childrens play centers, bowling alleys, libraries), personal care services. Started easing on 20200622 to permit personal care services to reeopen for indoor services: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-154.pdf Continued easing to permit indoor services by sector until the last venues (indoor entertainment venues) were eased on 20200904: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-183.pdf

Eases restrictions on cosmetology shops, barber shops, beauty salons, hair braiding shops, nail salons, electrology facilities, spas, including day spas and medical spas, at which solely elective and cosmetic medical procedures are performed, massage parlors, tanning salons, and tattoo parlors, collectively referred to as personal care service facilities, which are permitted to reopen for in-person services indoors provided that the facility complies with standards issued by the Division of Consumer Affairs and DOH, as applicable. Further eases on 20200702, allowing more services to be performed on customers not wearing masks: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-157.pdf Reexpands restrictions on 20201112, requiring no more than 25 pct capacity: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-194.pdf

Eases school closures, allowing higher-education institutions to reopen, schools K-12 remain closed for instruction. High school sporting activities can begin June 30, constituting further easing. On 20200813, ends state-coordinated school closures: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-175.pdf

Indoor gathering restriction to no more than 100 people given any size of the room. Further stipulations are that the number of individuals cannot exceed 25 pct of the capacity of the room, with a maximum of 100 people. Gathering restriction for outdoor gatherings is 250 people. These limits do not apply to outdoor religious gatherings.

Quarantine advisory of 14 days for all individuals traveling from states with significant community spread of COVID-19, as operationalized by a positive test rate higher than 10 per 100,000 residents or a 10 pct or higher positivity rate over a 7-day rolling average. While New York and Connecticut issued formal EOs for the quarantine, New Jersey never had a formal issuance - currently coding as an advisory. Initial list of states are: Alabama, Arkansas, Arizona, Florida, North Carolina, South Carolina, Texas, Utah and Washington. By 20200630, list is 16 states. Alabama, Arkansas, Arizona, California, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, Idaho, Louisiana, Mississippi, Nevada, North Carolina, South Carolina, Texas, Utah. Washington state is no longer on the list https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/general-public/which-states-are-on-the-travel-advisory-list-are-there-travel-restrictions-to-or-from-new-jersey. By 20200707 list is 19 states: Alabama, Arkansas, Arizona, California, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, Idaho, Kansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, Nevada, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Utah https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/general-public/which-states-are-on-the-travel-advisory-list-are-there-travel-restrictions-to-or-from-new-jersey  On 20200714, added Minnesota, New Mexico, Ohio, Wisconsin: https://covid19.nj.gov/faqs/nj-information/general-public/which-states-are-on-the-travel-advisory-list-are-there-travel-restrictions-to-or-from-new-jersey On 20200721 the list includes 31 states, expands to include Alaska, Delaware, Indiana, Maryland, Missouri, Montana, North Dakota, Virginia and Washington. Expands mask requirement, requiring all customers to wears or cloth face coverings in all retail establishments, all of which may now re-open to the public (indoor and outdoor), restaurants (which are re-opened for indoor services on 20200702, already open for outdoor), and recreational and entertainment businesses when in the indoor portions of premises or distancing is not possible (such venues are health clubs, gyms, movie theaters). Coded as Mandate2 as this mandate now applies to broader set of indoor settings, inclusive of transportation services.

Further eases bar restrictions allowing indoor services at 25 percent capacity. quote (Effective at 6:00 a.m. on Thursday, July 2, 2020, food or beverage establishments are permitted to offer in-person service at indoor areas, provided that the establishment complies with the requirements such as patrons may only consume food or beverages while seated).

Further eases restaurant restrictions allowing indoor services at 25 percent capacity. (quote) Effective at 6:00 a.m. on Thursday, July 2, 2020, food or beverage establishments are permitted to offer in-person service at indoor areas, provided that the establishment complies with the requirements (quote)

Further eases bar restrictions allowing indoor services at 25 percent capacity. (quote) Effective at 6:00 a.m. on Thursday, July 2, 2020, food or beverage establishments are permitted to offer in-person service at indoor areas, provided that the establishment complies with the requirements such as patrons may only consume food or beverages while seated (quote)

Rescinds the easing of in-door restaurant dining that was to be implemented on July 2. (quote) Paragraph 5 of Executive Order No. 157 (2020), which allowed food or beverage establishments to offer in person service at indoor areas effective at 6:00 a.m. on Thursday, July 2, 2020, is hereby rescinded. (quote) In-person services for outdoors only remain permitted. Extended to 20200926. Eased on 20200904: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-183.pdf
Limits outdoor gathering restrictions to no more than 500 people may gather in one location, physical distancing rules are adhered to, etc. These limits do not apply to outdoor religious gatherings.

Expands mask requirement, mandating that (quote) when it is not practicable for individuals in outdoor spaces to socially distance and keep a six-foot distance from others...all individuals shall wear face coverings (quote). Previous orders focused on indoor spaces or confined areas, or specified gatherings. Clearly details that individuals must wear face coverings in indoor settings that are accessible to members of the public (e.g., retail, recreational and entertainment businsesses), government buildings open to the public, and mass transit buses, trains, and stations. Coded as a Mandate3 as it applies to both indoor and outdoor settings broadly.

Expands indoor gathering restrictions to no more than 25 people given any size of the room. Further stipulations are that the number of individuals cannot exceed 25 pct of the capacity of the room, with a maximum of 25 people. This does not apply to indoor religious gatherings, which should not exceed 25 pct of capacity, for a maximum of 100 people. Extends gathering restriction of up to 250 people outdoors. These limits do not apply to outdoor religious gatherings.

As preK-12 schools reopen, includes the mandatory use of face coverings by staff, students, and visitors except for individuals who are under 2 years old, are not medically able, when eating or drinking, etc.
Eases restrictions on bars, permitting them to re-open for indoor services up to 25 pct capacity, require at least 6 ft distancing between tables, seated service only, required mask use, etc.

Eases indoor gathering restrictions for religious indoor gatherings which should not exceed 25 pct of capacity, for a maximum of 150 people. Any other indoor meeting shall not exceed exceed 25 pct of the capacity of the room, with a maximum of 25 people. These limits do not apply to outdoor religious gatherings. All attendees at an indoor gathering must wear face coverings at all times.

Eases restrictions on indoor entertainment centers where performances are viewed or given, including movie theaters, performing arts centers, other concert venues, which are allowed to reopen at 25 pct capacity on September 4, 2020. Extended to 20201222: https://nj.gov/infobank/eo/056murphy/pdf/EO-200.pdf

Eases restrictions on restaurants, which are now allowed to offer in person service at indoor areas effective at 6:00 a.m. on September 4, 2020 subject to requirements, including 25 pct capacity. Extended to 20201123.

Extends eased restrictions for bars (25 pct capacity indoors, at least 6 ft distancing between tables, no seating at bar areas), but now requires bars to close from 10 pm to 5 am for in-person services

Extends restrictions for restaurants. Adds restrictions including prohibiting seating at bar areas and requiring restaurants to close from 10 pm to 5am. Does not change capacity restrictions (25 pct capacity) or type of services permitted.

Expands indoor gathering restrictions to no more than 10 people given any size of the room. This does not apply to indoor religious gatherings, which should not exceed 25 pct of capacity, for a maximum of 150 people. Extends gathering restriction of up to 500 people outdoors. These limits do not apply to outdoor religious gatherings.

Expands outdoor gathering restrictions to no more than 150 people. This does not apply to indoor gatherings, which should not exceed 10 people. Extends indoor religious gathering restriction of up to 150 people. These limits do not apply to outdoor religious gatherings.
New Jersey strongly discourages all non-essential interstate travel at this time.

Expands restrictions for outdoor gatherings, which are now limited to 25 people. Continues prior gathering restrictions: indoor social gatherings of no more than 10 people, religious gatherings indoors are limited to 25 pct capacity, up to 150 people, and outdoor religious gatherings remain not having any explicit capacity limit beyond maintaining 6 ft of distancing. Prohibits sporting activities more broadly in indoor settings.

Public Health Emergency declared. Extended to 20200730: https://www.governor.state.nm.us/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Executive-Order-2020-053.pdf Extended to 20200918: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/EO-2020-059.pdf Extended to 20201016 https://www.governor.state.nm.us/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Executive-Order-2020-064.pdf Extends to 20201113: https://www.governor.state.nm.us/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Executive-Order-2020-073.pdf Extended to 20201210: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/EO-2020-080.pdf
Prohibits all mass gatherings, as defined as 100 or more people.

Hotels, motels, RV parks, and other places of lodging shall not operate at more than 25 pct capacity of maximum occupancy. Prior orders required up to 50 pct capacity operations, but at present that threshold is above what triggers including a tracked policy in this dataset. Easing began on 20200601, when capacity limits permitted up to 50 pct capacity: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/060120-PHO.pdf Extended to 20201116: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/111320-PHO-1.pdf

(quote) Golf courses may open on a modified basis. They may be open for golf only and shall not provide any dine-in or retail services. they shall minimize staff and operations the greatest extent possible and follow all sanitation and social distancing protocols (quote). Applies to all counties except for Cibola County, McKinley County, and San Juan County. Starting on 20200515, permitted to reopen for all services including indoor services

Retail businesses that are not essential businesses may operate to the minimum extent necessary to provide curbside pickup and/or delivery to customers. Coding as a an eased business closure to TakeawayOnly under BusinessRestrictLevel. On 20200516, Retail businesses that are not essential businesses may operate up to 25 pct capacity of the businesses enclosed areas, https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/051520-PHO.pdf

Beginning May 6, all essential businesses that operate as a retail space that have a footprint greater than 50,000 or are operating a restaurant must wear face coverings or masks. Beginning May 11, all essential businesses operating a retail space shall require employees to wear facing coverings, irrespective of size. Also still applies to restuarants. Expanded on 20200630 to such that retail businesses now can refuse entry of patrons who are not wearing a mask or multilayer face cloth unless they have a written exemption from a health provider. Also requires employees to wear facing coverings. https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/063020-PHO-1.pdf Extended to 20201113: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/101620-PHO-1.pdf Extended to 20201201: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/111320-PHO-1.pdf Extended to 20201231: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/113020-PHO.pdf Extended to 20201231: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/113020-PHO.pdf. Extended to 20210114 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/121520-PHO_mass-gatherings.pdf.

Retail businesses that are not essential businesses may operate up to 25 pct capacity of the businesses enclosed areas. Only applicable to counties that are not Cibola, McKinley, San Juan

All individuals shall wear a mask or multilayer cloth face covering in public settings except when eating, drinking, or exercising. Coded as a Mandate3 under PublicMaskLevel as it broadly applies to public settings (and not does specify indoor versus outdoor settings). Eases restrictions on restaurants, allowing them to have dine-services in outdoor seating areas up to 50 percent capacity. No indoor dine-in services permitted. Applicable to all NM counties except for Cibola, McKinley, and San Juan Counties. Note that breweries, wineries, and distilleries are being grouped with restaurants and separate from bars in PHOs, but remain limited to take-away only. https://www.governor.state.nm.us/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/DOH-PHO-5-27.pdf

Statewide, outdoor tennis facilities may open for outdoor use only and provided they operate in accordance with relevant health and safety protocols. State parks may be open for day use only, with all indoor enclosed areas closed to the public. Extended to 20201113 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/101620-PHO-1.pdf Extended to 20201116: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/111320-PHO-1.pdf

Statewide, retail businesses that are not essential businesses may operate up to 25 pct capacity of the businesses enclosed area. In addition, gyms and fitness centers and public swimming pools (can operate up to 50 percent occupancy). Indoor shopping malls (permitting maximum of 25 pct occupancy), close contact personal services like hair salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, spas, massage parlors (permitting a maximum of 25 pct capacity). On 20200713, capacity limits were decreased to up to 25 pct for gyms and fitness centers, coding as a re-expansion: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/7.13.20-PHO-1.pdf Extended to 20201113 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/101620-PHO-1.pdf

Eases restaurant restrictions in all counties, allowing statewide eased restrictions for restaurants to provide dine-in services if they comply with the COVID-19 safe practices for restaurants and operate at no more than 50 percent capacity. Note that breweries, wineries, and distilleries are being grouped with restaurants and separate from bars in PHOs, and remain limited to only take-away. On 20200612, eases restrictions on breweries and like venues, allowing breweries to re-open for dine-in services up to 50 pct of capacity. Wineries and distilleries are still closed on-site consumption. https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/063020-PHO-1.pdf

Guidance on re-opening schools for in-person instruction. Face coverings are required for all students and staff under hybrid and full entry (yellow and green levels accordingly) Extended to 20201201: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/111320-PHO-1.pdf Extended to 20201231: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/113020-PHO.pdf. Extended to 20210114 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/121520-PHO_mass-gatherings.pdf.

Expands restrictions on restaurants and like venues, requiring them to close dine-in services in indoor areas. Outdoor dine-in service may only be provided up to 50 pct capacity. These requirements apply to restaurants and local breweries, while local wineries and distilleries must remain closed for in-person operations (they are treated separately from bars in these orders). https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/7.13.20-PHO-1.pdf. Eased on 20200730, now also includes wineries and distilleries (they were previously closed for all in-person operations), permitting them to re-open for outdoor services. https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/07.30.20-PHO.pdf

Public schools will not reopen for in-person instruction until at least after labor day https://www.newmexico.gov/2020/07/24/state-updates-school-reopening-guidance-hits-pause-on-hybrid-model-for-start-of-school-year/ Extended to 20200919: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/PHO-August-28.pdf Extended to 20201003 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/090320-PHO.pdf On 20200908, 25 counties met gating criteria for in-person K-12 school instruction and thus school districts in those counties could re-open to a hybrid model https://www.newmexico.gov/2020/09/03/schools-in-25-counties-may-launch-hybrid-model-sept-8/ Extended restrictions to private schools to 20201017 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/091820-PHO.pdf Extended to 20201113: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/101620-PHO-1.pdf Extended to 20201201: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/111320-PHO-1.pdf Extended to 20201231: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/120220-PHO.pdf

Eases previous gathering restrictions, limiting gatherings to no more than 10 people indoors and outdoors. Exempts religious gatherings, and permits houses of worship to have up to 40 pct occupancy (which is easing from the prior restrictions, up to 25 pct occupancy)  Extended to 20201003 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/090320-PHO.pdf Extended to 20201017 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/091820-PHO.pdf

Eases previous restrictions, permitting up to 25 pct occupancy for enclosed spaces at restaurants and like venues. Outdoors dine-in service is permitted with no explicit occupancy limits. These requirements apply to restaurants and local breweries, wineries and distilleries. https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/PHO-August-28.pdf. On 20200904, somewhat expands restrictions on restaurants and like venues, requiring up to 75 pct occupancy in outdoor dine-in areas. Extends previous indoor restrictions, permitting up 25 pct occupancy for enclosed spaces at restaurants and like venues. These requirements apply to restaurants and local breweries, wineries and distilleries. https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/090320-PHO.pdf. Extended to 20201017 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/091820-PHO.pdf. Extended to 20201113 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/101620-PHO-1.pdf As of 20201030, indoor dining at food and drink establishments is prohibited unless that establishment completes the New Mexico Safe Certification training program. If they do, food and drink establishments may continue to offer limited indoor dining at a maximum of 25 pct occupancy. If an establishement does not complete the training, it can operate at 75 pct outdoors. https://www.governor.state.nm.us/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/102220-PHO.pdf

Chaves, Eddy, Hidalgo, Lea, Luna, Roosevelt, and Quay counties are designated in the red color, Dona Ana in orange, and McKinley and Curry in yellow, and thus school districts in those counties are not eligible to re-open for in-person instruction. On 20200918, McKinley, Hidalgo, Dona Ana and Curry counties have moved into the green zone, they are hence cleared to begin a hybrid mode of learning that allows students from pre-K through fifth grade to come to school two days a week wearing face masks and staying at least 6 feet away from others (quote), with a maximum occupancy of 25 pct for any enclosed place. Coding as easing for this dataset: https://webnew.ped.state.nm.us/news-releases/  Extended to 20201201: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/111320-PHO-1.pdf Extended to 20201231: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/120220-PHO.pdf

Expands gathering restriction, prohibiting gatherings of 5 or more people indoors and outdoors, excludes religious gatherings which only need to adhere to 40 pct capacity rule. Extends to 20201116: https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/111320-PHO-1.pdf

As of 20201030, indoor dining at food and drink establishments is prohibited unless that establishment completes the New Mexico Safe Certification training program. Somewhat expands gathering restriction, prohibting gatherings of 5 or more people indoors and outdoors, and reduces capacity limits of houses of worship to the lesser of 25 pct or up to 75 people at a time. PolicyCodingNotes: Per Red to Green substate framework, red counties have gathering restrictions of no more than 5 people indoors and outdoors, and no more than 10 vehicles. For houses of worship, no more than 25 pct capacity. For houses of worship, no more than 25 pct capacity. As of 20201202, yellow counties are: San Miguel. Effective 20201202, close-contact businesses (e.g., barbershops, hair salons, group fitness classes, tattoo parlors, nail salons, spas, massage therapy services, esthetician clinics, tanning salons, guided raft tours, guided balloon tours, bowling alleys, ice skating rinks, and personal training services) in red and yellow counties may open for in-person services up to 25pct capacity. Places of lodging may open to 40 pct occupancy in red counties if they have completed NM Safe Certified training and 60 pct in yellow counties if they have completed NM Safe Certified training. All other businesses (e.g., non-essential retail) can operate up to 25 pct of maximum capacity (or 75 customers at one time for red counties and 125 customers at one time for yellow counties), whichever is smaller. Red counties: Bernalillo, Catron, Chaves, Cibola, Colfax, Curry, De Baca, Dona Ana, Eddy, Grant, Guadalupe, Harding, Hidalgo, Lea, Lincoln, Los Alamos, Luna, McKinley, Mora, Otero, Quay, Rio Arriba, Roosevelt, Sandoval, San Juan, Santa Fe, Sierra, Socorro, Taos, Torrance, Union, Valencia. Yellow counties: San Miguel.  Extended to 20210114 https://cv.nmhealth.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/121520-PHO_mass-gatherings.pdf.

Red level and yellow level counties can operate at a maximum of 25 pct capacity unless lower under the COVID-19 Safe Practices. Red counties: Bernalillo, Catron, Chaves, Cibola, Colfax, Curry, De Baca, Dona Ana, Eddy, Grant, Guadalupe, Harding, Hidalgo, Lea, Lincoln, Los Alamos, Luna, McKinley, Mora, Otero, Quay, Rio Arriba, Roosevelt, Sandoval, San Juan, Santa Fe, Sierra, Socorro, Taos, Torrance, Union, Valencia. Per Red to Green substate framework, restaurants in yellow counties are limited to 25 pct capacity indoors if completed NM safe certified training and 75 pct capacity outdoor otherwise. San Miguel moves to Red Level (Very High Risk), making gathering restrictions statewide. Counties can have gathering restrictions of no more than 5 people indoors and outdoors, and no more than 10 vehicles. For houses of worship, no more than 25 pct capacity but no explicit limits provided.

San Miguel moves to Red Level (Very High Risk), making restaurant restrictions statewide. Restaurants are prohibited from having indoor dining. Allowed to have 25 pct capacity outdoor. All establishments selling alcohol must close by 9 pm and cannot reopen until 4am.
