These regions are: Central New York, Finger Lakes, Mohawk Valley, North Country, Southern Tier. All regions except for New York City end up with these eased restrictions through Phase Four. Extended to 20201104: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO_202.65.pdf

Phase Three regions are permitted to have gatherings up to 25, starting 20200615. Original Phase Three regions are Central New York, Finger Lakes, Mohawk Valley, North Country, Southern Tier. Western New York region moved to Phase Three on 20200616, and Capitol Region moved to Phase Three on 20200617. Eased when Phase Four regions were permitted to have gatherings up to 50 on 20200626: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO202.45.pdf

New York City moves to Phase Two, easing restrictions to allow for the following businesses to be re-opened statewide: professional services, administrative support, information technology, real estate services (including building and property management, leasing, rental and sales services), barbershops and hair salons (limited services), motor vehicle leasing, rental, and sales. Limited operations include no more than 50 pct capacity for these businesses: https://forward.ny.gov/phase-two-industries Extended to 20201104: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO_202.65.pdf

New York City moves to Phase Two, easing restrictions to allow for in-person retail up to 50 pct. Now a statewide policy. Extended to 20201104: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO_202.65.pdf

(quote) All travelers entering New York from a state with a positive test rate higher than 10 per 100,000 residents, or higher than a 10 pct test positivity rate, over a seven day rolling average, will be required to quarantine for a period of 14 days consistent with Department of Health regulations for quarantine (quote). On 20200630, expands states under the quarantine order, adding California, Georgia, Iowa, Idaho, Louisiana, Mississippi, Nevada and Tennessee to the required quaratine list (originally, Alabama, Arkansas, Arizona, Florida, North Carolina, South Carolina, Texas, Utah). Full list is now as follows: Alabama, Arkansas, Arizona, California, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, Idaho, Louisiana, Mississippi, Nevada, North Carolina, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Utah. On 20200707, Expands states under the quarantine order, adding Delaware, Kansas, and Oklahoma: https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-individuals-traveling-new-york-three-additional-states-will-be On 20200714, expands states under the quarantine order, adding Minnesota, New Mexico, Ohio, and Wisconsin: https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-individuals-traveling-new-york-four-additional-states-will-be-required. Adds 10 states under the quarantine order, adding Alaska, Delaware, Indiana, Maryland, Missouri, Montana, North Dakota, Nebraska, Virginia and Washington to the required travel quarantine of 14 days if arriving in New York from these states as points of origin. As of 20200721, this list includes the following: Alaska, Alabama, Arkansas, Arizona, California, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, Idaho, Indiana, Kansas, Louisiana, Maryland, Missouri, Mississippi, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Mexico, North Dakota, North Carolina, Ohio, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Virginia, Washingon, Wisconsin: https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-individuals-traveling-new-york-10-additional-states-will-be-required On 20200728, adds Illinois, Kentucky, Minnesota, Puerto Rico, and District of Columbia to the quarantine order https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-individuals-traveling-new-york-three-additional-states-puerto-rico-and On 08/05 adds Rhode Island to the quarantine order, but removes DC and Delaware https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-individuals-traveling-new-york-additional-state-will-be-required On 20200811, quarantine order removes Alaska, New Mexico, Ohio, Rhode Island, and Washington but adds Hawaii, South Carolina, and the Virgin Islands https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-individuals-traveling-new-york-two-additional-states-virgin-islands On 20200818, added Alaska and Delaware: https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-two-additional-states-added-travel-advisory On 20200825, added Guam and removed Arizona, Alaska, Delaware, Maryland and Montana https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-five-states-removed-covid-19-travel-advisory-requiring-14-day On 20200901 added Alaska and Montana to the list https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-two-states-added-travel-advisory-requiring-14-day-quarantines On 20200908 removed Puerto Rico and Virgin Islands and added Delaware, Maryland, Ohio and West Virginia https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-four-states-added-travel-advisory-requiring-14-day-quarantines  On 20200915, removes California, Hawaii, Maryland, Minnesota, Nevada, and Ohio and adds Puerto Rico to the quarantine order: https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-six-states-removed-travel-advisory-requiring-14-day-quarantines. On 20200922, adds Arizona, Minnesota, Nevada, Rhode Island, and Wyoming to the quarantine order: https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-five-states-added-travel-advisory-and-10-million-covid-19-diagnostic. On 20200928 expands quarantine order to travelers entering the United States from any country with a CDC Level 2 or Level 3 health notice: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO_205.1.pdf. On 20200929 removes Arizona and Virginia and adds Colorado to the quarantine order: https://coronavirus.health.ny.gov/covid-19-travel-advisory. On 20201006 adds New Mexico to the quarantine order. governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-new-mexico-added-travel-advisory. On 20201013 adds Ohio, Michigan and Virginia to the travel quarantine requirement. https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-three-states-added-travel-advisory.  On 20201020 adds Arizona and Maryland to the travel quarantine requirement https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-travel-advisory-requiring-14-day-quarantine

Eases restrictions for the following businesses for regions in Phase 4 (Central New York, Finger Lakes, Mohawk Valley, North County, Southern Tier): low-risk outdoor arts and entertainment (e.g., outdoor zoos, botanical gardens, nature parks, grounds of historic sites and cultural institutions, outdoor museums, outdoor agritourism, local agricultural demonstrations and exhibitions; and other similar institutions/activities - must be limited to no more than 33 pct capacity/occupancy, physical distancing, mandated mask use), low-risk indoor arts and entertainment (e.g., indoor museums, historical sites, aquariums, and other related institutions or activities- must be limited to 25 pct capacity/occupancy, physical distancing, mandated mask use), media and production (i.e., all activities undertaken in motion picture, music, television, and streaming productions on set, on location, or at any production or recording site - must be at no more than 50 pct capacity, physical distancing, mask use).

(quote) Any time individuals come within 6 ft. of another person who does not reside in the same residence (e.g. roommate), acceptable face coverings must be worn (quote). Applicable to higher education only at present. On 20200827, expands requirements to include PreK-12 schools: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/Pre-K_to_Grade_12_Schools_MasterGuidance.pdf

Eases gathering restrictions for regions moving to Phase 4 (Central New York, Finger Lakes, Mohawk Valley, Southern Tier), permitting gatherings up to 50 people as long as gatherings do not exceed 50 pct capacity in an indoor area. Capacity limits also 50 pct for religious gatherings

New York City moves to Phase Four, bringing Phase 4 statewide and permitting gatherings up to 50 people as long as gatherings do not exceed 50 pct capacity in an indoor area (50 pct capacity limit for religious gatherings too). Extended to 20201104: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO_202.65.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Removed religious gathering limits, updated DateExpiry

PolicyCodingNotes: Eases restrictions on New York City, allowing museums and other low-risk cultural institutions (e.g., aquarariums, low-risk indoor cultural arts venues) to reopen. (quote) All institutions that reopen will be subject to state guidance. These institutions must obey strict safety protocols, including a 25 percent maximum occupancy limit, timed ticketing required with pre-set, staggered entry, strict enforcement of face coverings, social distancing, controlled traffic flow to avoid crowding, and enhanced cleaning and disinfection protocols. (quote) Easing of museums and other low-risk cultural institutions is now statewide, albeit at different capacity limits for New York City region versus other Phase Four regions.  Extended to 20201104: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO_202.65.pdf

Gyms and fitness centers may reopen conditional on operating at a 33 pct occupancy limit, appropriate face coverings worn at all times, social distancing of at least 6 ft, cleaning and disinfection of shared equipment after each use, must meet air handling system standards. These facilities can reopen as early as August 24 per local officials, while all gyms and fitness centers can reopen by September 2. Notes that the governor may opt for delaying indoor fitness classes until after September 2. Extended to 20201104: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO_202.65.pdf

Eases restaurant restrictions in New York City region, permitting for indoor services at 25 pct occupancy limit and strict safety protocols (e.g., temperature checks, contact information for tracing, face coverings when not seated, tables required to be to at least 6 ft apart). Bar service is not permitted and restaurants are required to close by midnight. Further detail is provided here: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/NYC_Indoor_Food_Services_Summary_Guidelines.pdf Extended to 20201104: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO_202_67.pdf

Requires bars to close for in-person services from 1000 pm to 500 am. Extends Phase Four region eased bar restrictions for all regions except New York City: allowing both indoor and outdoor in-person services conditional on following guidelines (eg, 50 pct capacity, customer-facing staff must wear masks). Phase Four regions: Capitol Region, Central New York, Finger Lakes, Long Island, Mid-Hudson, Mohawk Valley, North Country, Southern Tier, Western New York. Extended to 20210102: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO%20202.79-new.pdf

Requires bars to close for in-person services from 1000 pm to 500 am. Extends New York City modified Phase Three bar restrictions: outdoor in-person services are permitted, conditional on following guidelines (eg, 50 pct capacity, customer-facing staff must wear masks). Indoor services remain prohibited. Extended to 20210102: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO%20202.79-new.pdf

Expands gathering restrictions, limiting non-essential private residential gatherings to no more than 10 people. Continues prior restrictions (i.e., 50 pct capacity religious gatherings) as the statewide gathering restriction.

Requires gyms or fitness centers to close by 1000 pm and cannot reopen to 500 am. Extends eased restrictions on gyms and fitness centers, allowing them to operate at a 33 pct occupancy limit, appropriate face coverings worn at all times, social distancing of at least 6 ft, cleaning and disinfection of shared equipment after each use, must meet air handling system standards. Extended to 20210102: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO_202.81.pdf

Requires restaurants and like venues to close for in-person services from 1000 pm to 500 am. Indoor services permitted, but up to 25 pct for New York City Region and up to 50 pct for all other Phase Four regions. Extended to 20210102: https://www.governor.ny.gov/sites/governor.ny.gov/files/atoms/files/EO_202.81.pdf

Effective December 14, 2020, indoor dining is suspended in the New York City region. Continues to permit outdoor services but at limited time periods (1000 pm to 500 am required closure) and following guidelines from bars (eg, 50 pct capacity, customer-facing staff must wear masks).
State of Emergency declared. Extended to 20200911 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO155-Extension-of-Phase-2.pdf
Recommends the cancellation of all gatherings with 100 attendees or more.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: Prohibits gatherings of more than 100. In place for 30 days. Effective for 30 days
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

Extended to 20210108, now requiring business closure from 10pm to 5am: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO181-Modified-Stay-at-Home-Early-Closure-Order.pdf.
Prohibits gatherings of more than 50. In place for 30 days.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Closure required: bingo parlors, bowling alleys, indoor exercise facilities, health clubs, pools, live performance venues, movie theaters, spas, barber shops, hair salons, nail salons, personal care services. Effective at 5 pm on 20200325. Easing began on 20200522: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO141-Phase-2.pdf Extended to 20200717 https://governor.nc.gov/documents/executive-order-no-147 Extended to 20200807 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO151-Phase-2-Extension-1.pdf  Extended to 20200911 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO155-Extension-of-Phase-2.pdf. On 20201002, restrictions on amusement parks are eased. Parks may open at 30 pct occupancy. Outdoor attractions only. Also eases restrictions on night clubs, bingo parlors, gaming activities, movie theaters. They may open at 30 pct of outdoor capacity, or 100 guests, whichever is less. Extends eases restrictions on barber shops, massage parlors, beauty salons, tattoo parlors, nail salons, hair salons, and pools subject to guidelines. Extended to 20201023 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO169-Phase-3.pdf. Extended to 20201113 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO170-Phase-3-Extension.pdf. Expands restrictions on museums and aqauriums. They must limit guests in each room such that they do not exceed 25 individuals. Restrictions on other businesses are extended. https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO176-Phase-3-ext.pdf. All restrictions extended to 20201211: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO180-Face-Coverings-Requirements.pdf. Extended to 20210108, now requiring business closure from 10pm to 5am: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO181-Modified-Stay-at-Home-Early-Closure-Order.pdf.

Effective 5 pm on 20200330, in place for 30 days unless repealed, replaced, or rescinded. Extended to 20200717 https://governor.nc.gov/documents/executive-order-no-147  By judicial order, bowling alleys are exempted from this restriction on 20200707. Extended to 20200807 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO151-Phase-2-Extension-1.pdf

Effective 5 pm on 20200330, in place for 30 days unless repealed, replaced, or rescinded. Place of worship is exempt. Effective 20200508 retail businesses may operate subject to specific requirements. https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO138-Phase-1.pdf Extended to 20200717 https://governor.nc.gov/documents/executive-order-no-147 Extended to 20200807 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO151-Phase-2-Extension-1.pdf  Extended to 20200911 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO155-Extension-of-Phase-2.pdf. Extended to 20201204 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO176-Phase-3-ext.pdf. Extended to 20201211: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO180-Face-Coverings-Requirements.pdf. Extended to 20210108, now requiring business closure from 10pm to 5am: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO181-Modified-Stay-at-Home-Early-Closure-Order.pdf.

Effective 5 pm on 20200330, in place for 30 days unless repealed, replaced, or rescinded. Place of worship is exempt. Ended on 20200522: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO141-Phase-2.pdf
Individuals are encouraged to wear a mask or face covering when they leave the home.

Eases previous gathering restriction of up to 10 people in a gathering, allowing up to 25 people to gather outdoors (e.g., in a park, on a beach or trail). Extended to 20200717: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO147-Phase-2-Extension.pdf Extended to 20200807 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO151-Phase-2-Extension-1.pdf  Extended to 20200911 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO155-Extension-of-Phase-2.pdf Eased on 20200904 with increasing numeric limits on gatherings: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO155-Extension-of-Phase-2.pdf

(quote) People who are at high risk of severe illness from COVID-19 are very strongly encouraged to stay home and travel only for absolutely essential purposes (quote). High risk populations are defined as those 65 or older, and people of any age with a serious medical condition Extended to 20200807 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO151-Phase-2-Extension-1.pdf  Extended to 20200911 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO155-Extension-of-Phase-2.pdf. Extended to 20201023 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO169-Phase-3.pdf. Extended to 20201113 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO170-Phase-3-Extension.pdf. Extended to 20201204 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO176-Phase-3-ext.pdf. Extended to 20201211: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO180-Face-Coverings-Requirements.pdf. Extended to 20210108 and now mandates a curfew from 10pm to 5am for all individuals: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO181-Modified-Stay-at-Home-Early-Closure-Order.pdf.

(quote) People are required to wear Face Coverings in the following settings, whether they are inside or outside (quote): retail businesses, restaurants, personal care services, child care and camps, government, on transportation, high-density occupational settings (eg, manufacturing), health care settings, processing plants. Applies to customers, patrons, employees. Coded as Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel as the order approaches the mandate by listing out applicable settings rather than a more sweeping policy across indoor and outdoor settings. Extended to 20200807 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO151-Phase-2-Extension-1.pdf  Extended to 20200911 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO155-Extension-of-Phase-2.pdf.

Eases previous gathering restriction of up to 10 people in a gathering, allowing up to 25 people to gather indoor and up to 50 (from 25) outdoor.  Extended to 20201023 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO169-Phase-3.pdf. Extended to 20201113 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO170-Phase-3-Extension.pdf

Expansion of prior mask mandate. (quote) Face Coverings must be worn in any public place, business or establishment, indoor or outdoor, where it is not possible to consistently be physically distant by more than six (6) feet from non-household members. (quote) Exemptions include children under the age of 5, due to medical or behavioral conditions that may put wearers at risk, etc. Coded now as a Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it broadly applies to indoor and outdoor settings, whereas the prior mask mandate under Phases 2-2.5 were more limited (i.e., listing many settings where masks were required in public). Extended to 20201113 https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO170-Phase-3-Extension.pdf. Expanded on 20201125 to require face coverings indoors if a member of another household is present, irrespective of physical distancing: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO180-Face-Coverings-Requirements.pdf. Extended to 20210108: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO181-Modified-Stay-at-Home-Early-Closure-Order.pdf.

Expands previous restrictions on indoor gatherings, prohibits gatherings that bring together more than 10 people indoors, and more than 50 outdoors. Extended to 20201211: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO180-Face-Coverings-Requirements.pdf. Extended to 20210108: https://files.nc.gov/governor/documents/files/EO181-Modified-Stay-at-Home-Early-Closure-Order.pdf.
State of Emergency declared. No formal expiry provided.

Public school closure, extended closure on 20200322: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-10.pdf. PolicyCodingNotes: Effective at 12 pm on 20200320, all bars, breweries, and similar venues are closed to on-site patrons. Take-out, delivery, curbside, drive-through, and off-sale services are permitted. Requirement continues through 20200406, so expiry coded as 20200407. Eased as of 20200501 - must follow specific guidelines https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-06.4.pdf

Closure required: recreational facilities, health clubs, athletic facilities, and theaters. In effect 12 pm on 20200320, initial expiry is 20200406, extended to 20200430 on 20200415. As of 8 am on 20200501, allows health clubs and athletic activities to open, but must adopt and rigorously follow Fitness Center ND Smart Restart conditions. Movie theaters also may open, but must follow the movie theater specific standards  https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-06.4.pdf Ends required guidelines to be followed on 20200522: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-06.7%20FINAL.pdf

Eased as of 20200501 - must follow specific guidelines https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-06.4.pdf

PolicyCodingNotes: Closure required: personal care services (eg, cosmetologists, salons, barbers, tattoo parlors, tanning facilities, and massage therapists). In effect at 1200 am 20200328. On 20200401, extended to 20200420: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-06.2.pdf  As of 8 am on 20200501, allows salons, tattoo and piercing salons, and massage therapists to re-open, but must follow each of their industry-specific standards under the ND Smart Restart Guidelines https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-06.4.pdf Ends required guidelines to be followed on 20200522: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-06.7%20FINAL.pdf

PolicyCodingNotes: Individuals who test positive for COVID-19 must self-quarantine for 14 days, as must family or household members residing with an individual who tests positive. Extended on 2020508, no clear end date. Expanded on 20200923 to include close contacts: https://www.health.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Files/MSS/coronavirus/State%20Health%20Officer%20Orders/2020-06.1_Amended_Close_Contact.pdf Eased on 20200926, to remove close contacts:  https://www.health.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Files/MSS/coronavirus/State%20Health%20Officer%20Orders/2020-06.2_Revocation_Order.pdf Further eased on 20201109, Individuals must self-quarantine for 10 days, and healthcare workers who test positive but are asymptomatic are exempt provided that they work in a covid unit https://www.health.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Files/MSS/coronavirus/State%20Health%20Officer%20Orders/2020-05.2_isolation_health_care_excemption.pdf

Any person entering North Dakota traveling from another state or country is subject to immediate quarantine for a period of 14 days.  Extended on 2020508, no clear end date. Extended on 20200728, no clear end date https://www.health.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Files/MSS/coronavirus/State%20Health%20Officer%20Orders/2020-02.3_International_Travel.pdf Quarantine order for people traveling from another country was ended on 20200921: https://www.health.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Files/MSS/coronavirus/State%20Health%20Officer%20Orders/2020_02.4_Lifted_Travel_Order.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicyCodingNotes and added 20200921 to DateEnd to reflect the end of this order.

PolicyCodingNotes: Restrictions are eased such that bars, breweries, distilleries, and like venues can re-open for in-person service under the broader ND Smart Restart standards and must follow the specific standards set for these businesses. Per ND Smart Restart at this point, capacity will be limited to 50 pct normal operating capacity, tables are limited to no more than 10 people, physical spacing of at least 6 ft between tables, no standing at bar areas, dance floors are closed. On 20200522, moves to recommendations, ending the mandate: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-06.7%20FINAL.pdf

Requires employees to wear masks at personal care services (i.e., hair salons, barbershops, nail salons, tanning salons, waxing studios, and other cosmetology related businesses). Mask use by staff and patrons are encouraged for fitness centers, movie theaters, massage therapy. Also, more broadly (quote) Encourage use of cloth face coverings to employees and contracted workers whose duties require close contact (within six feet for ten minutes or more) with other employees and/or the public

Eases restrictions, allowing salons, tattoo and piercing salons, and massage therapists to re-open, but must follow each of their industry-specific standards under the ND Smart Restart Guidelines (i.e., employees must wear masks, no walk-in appointments). Also allows health clubs and athletic activities to open, but must adopt and rigorously follow Fitness Center ND Smart Restart conditions (limit groups to no more than 10, ensure spacing at least 1 person 100 square ft, keep certain group settings like indoor playgrounds closed). Movie theaters may open as well, but must follow the movie theater specific standards (i.e., no more than 20 pct capacity, allow for at least 6 ft spacing). All re-opened businesses the number of people occupying facilities to ensure all maintain at least 6 ft distancing. Ends on 20200522, shifting to only encouraging following Smart Restart guidelines: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-06.7%20FINAL.pdf

Restrictions are eased such that, restaurants, cafes, and like venues can re-open for in-person service under the broader ND Smart Restart standards and must follow the specific standards set for these businesses. Per ND Smart Restart at this point, capacity will be limited to 50 pct normal operating capacity, tables are limited to no more than 10 people, physical spacing of at least 6 ft between tables, no standing at bar areas. On 20200522, ends mandated restrictions, coding as ending: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-06.7%20FINAL.pdf

Summer school programs may be allowed on-site starting 20200601 provided the school district adheres to Department of Public Instructions ND K-12 Smart Restart Guidelines. Students allowed to enter school buildings to retrieve their property from 20200515 to 20200530.Coding as LimitedInPerson under SchoolRestrictLevel, as schools do not appears to be fully open for in-person instruction yet.        https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/executive-orders/Executive%20Order%202020-04.2%20Burgum%20Grants%20Access%20to%20Schools%20for%20Certain%20Programs%20and%20Testing.pdf Starting on 20200715, allows K-12 schools to choose to re-open, coding as ended at the state-level: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Executive%20Order%202020-38%20FINAL.pdf
Recommends mask use, (quote) In order to provide in-person learning, schools should require the use of masks by school-aged individuals and staff (quote)

Recommends that North Dakotans use cloth face coverings in public places where social distancing cannot be maintained. Also explicitly recommends wearing face coverings/masks when within a six foot distance of others, in particular to protect high-risk individuals. Wearing of masks or cloth face coverings is also recommended for customers/clients in various sectors under ND Smart Restart. It is likely that this recommendation was also under the original version of ND Smart Restart (announced on 20200429), but pdf documentation is not longer findable.
Strongly encourages businesses to require use of face coverings across sectors, but does not explicitly mandate mask use.

(quote) All remaining counties in the moderate risk (yellow) level under the ND Smart Restart guidelines are being moved to the high-risk (orange) level, indicating the seriousness of the situation. Businesses and events/gatherings are recommended to reduce occupancy to 25 percent, with a cap of 50 people (quote). Coded as mandate as 0 because it is a recommendation.

(quote) Burgum urged North Dakotans to try to limit gatherings to their immediate household group as much as possible for the next four weeks (quote) Coding as recommendation for 0 in terms of numeric gathering limits

(quote) Businesses must require that all persons, including workers...wear face coverings as required by this order (quote). Extended to 20210118: https://www.health.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Files/MSS/coronavirus/State%20Health%20Officer%20Orders/2020-08.1_Mask_Order.pdf.

Face coverings are required in indoor and indoor public settings, and must also be worn in outdoor business and public settings when it is not possible to maintain physical distancing, as well as public transportation or shared transportation. Exemptions are for individuals for whom conditions would make it unsafe to wear a face covering, children 4 years old and under, etc. Coded as a Mandate3 under PublicMaskLevel as it broadly applies across indoor and outdoor settings. https://www.health.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Files/MSS/coronavirus/State%20Health%20Officer%20Orders/2020-08.1_Mask_Order.pdf

Restrictions on banquets, ballrooms, wedding, and event venues. Effective 20201116, must not exceed 25 pct capacity. Tables must be 6 ft apart, dance areas are closed, face coverings must be worn by employees and patrons. Religious events are exempt. Extended to 20210108: https://www.governor.nd.gov/sites/www/files/documents/Executive%20Order%202020-43.2%20(corrected).pdf.

All extra-curricular activities for K-12 schools are suspended. Coding as InPersonAllowed under SchoolRestrictLevel as, at the state-level, this still permits in-person instruction but limits all extra-curricular activities.
State of Emergency declaration. Has no formal expiry
(quote) I [am] recommending that Ohio limits a variety of large gatherings in order to protect public health (quote)
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

Formal closure of schools ended 20200702, when DOE released guidance that said schools would be open for in-person instruction in the Fall.

(quote). PolicyCodingNotes: Mandates face coverings in any indoor location that is not a residence, outdoors and unable to maintain social distancing of at least 6 ft, and waiting for riding public transportation, taxi, ride sharing. Coded as Mandate3 as it explicitly applies across indoor settings, as well as outdoor settings where social distancing is not possible. This is applicable to all counties that are designated as a Red Alert Level 3 Public Health Emergency or a Purple Alert Level 4 Public Health Emergency. As of 20200707: Butler County, Cuyahoga County, Franklin County, Hamilton County, Huron County, Montgomery County, Trumbull County. On 20200709, Huron is downgraded to Level 2: https://governor.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/governor/media/news-and-media/covid19-update-07092020 On 20200710, more counties added, bringing the list to: Clermont, Fairfield, Lorain, Pickaway, Summit, Wood, Butler, Cuyahoga, Franklin, Hamilton, Montgomery, Trumbull. As of 20200716, Trumball is downgraded to Level 2 and in effect on 20200717, these additional counties are added: Athens, Allen, Delaware, Licking, Lucas, Richland, Scioto, Union. https://governor.ohio.gov/wps/portal/gov/governor/media/news-and-media/covid19-update-0716-2020
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicyCodingNotes to reflect changes in county alert levels

PolicyCodingNotes: Individuals entering Ohio after travel in the following states are advised to self-quarantine for 14 days upon arrival: Alabama, Arizona, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Mississippi, Nevada, South Carolina, and Texas.

Statewide mask mandate is issued and in effect at 6 pm on 20200723, requiring all individuals in Ohio to wear facial coverings in public at all times when at an indoor location that is not a residence, outdoors (but unable to maintain six-foot social distance from people who are not household members), waiting for, riding, driving, or operating public transportation, such as a taxi, a car service, or a private car used for ride-sharing. Exemptions are for individuals under the age of 10 years old, with a medical conditions or disability, etc. Coded as a Mandate 3 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly to indoor and outdoor settings. Formal PHO was signed on 20200723, so coding that date to the DateIssued versus the date announced (20200722).

(quote)  All individuals residing within the State of Ohio are ordered to stay at a place of residence during the hours of 1000 pm until 500 am except as otherwise expressly permitted in this Order (quote). Exemptions are made for work and essential activity, etc. Extended to 20201231: https://coronavirus.ohio.gov/static/publicorders/all-pers-stay-at-home-specified-hours.pdf.

Extended to 20200430 with 20200401 issuance https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1926.pdf. Extended to 20200509 with extended State of Emergency https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1929.pdf Ended on 20200424 when mandate changes to a recommendation to follow CDC guidelines.

Bars are permitted operations for takeout and curbside delivery under the non-essential business closure with in counties with community spread. Effective at 1159 pm on 20200325, so coded to 2020036. Effective until April 16, 2020, so coded as 20200416.

All non critical businesses must close. Effective at 1159 pm on 20200325, so coded to 2020036. Only applicable to counties with community spread, so coded as not statewide. Since what constitutes community spread is not clearly defined, we are not listing counties under AppliesTo. Effective until April 16, 2020, so coded as 20200416.
All non-essential businesses close per executive order but nothing shall prevent restuarants from providing takeout, curbside and delivery. Only applicable to counties with community spread.

Mandates 14-day quarantine for any individual entering Oklahoma by air from areas with (quote) substantial community spread (quote), specifically Connecticut, New Jersey, New York, Washington state, California, and Lousiana. Initial expiry is 30 days after issuance. Ends mandate and moves to recommendation on 20200512: https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/executive/1943.pdf

Bars are permitted operations for takeout and curbside delivery under the non-essential business closure. Initial expiry is until 20200430. Began easing on 20200515: https://www.okcommerce.gov/wp-content/uploads/Open-Up-and-Recover-Safely-Plan.pdf

Amends the previous non-essential business closures to all non-essential businesses, irrespective of location within Oklahoma. Initial expiry is until 20200430. Now applies statewide. Began easing on 20200424, allowing personal care services to reopen https://www.okcommerce.gov/wp-content/uploads/Open-Up-and-Recover-Safely-Plan.pdf

All non-essential businesses close per executive order but nothing shall prevent restuarants and bars from providing takeout, curbside and delivery. On-premise services to resume starting 20200501 https://www.okcommerce.gov/wp-content/uploads/Open-Up-and-Recover-Safely-Plan.pdf
State health emergency declared. Duration will be for 30 days after filing https://www.sos.ok.gov/documents/Executive/1927.pdf
(quote) individuals should follow CDC guidelines for social distancing by staying out of crowded places, not gathering in groups (quote)

State parks and otudoor recreation also may reopen. Entertainment, movie theaters, sporting venues, gyms can reopen conditional on adhering to sanitation and CDC distancing protocols. Tattoo parlors can reopen to appointment only. Bars can reopen under proper social distancing and sanitation protocols. Because it is not clear where or how the red and orange counties are updated, no counties are listed under AppliesTo at this time

(quote) all persons on property, including buildings and office space, owned or leased by the State of Oklahoma shall wear a facial covering or mask over the mouth and nose at all times where physical distancing measures may be difficult to observe. This only applies to persons while indoors or when in an outdoor space, wherever it is not feasible to maintain six feet of social distance from another person (quote) Exemptions are for children under the age of 10, when eating or drinking, when medically unable, etc. Coding as a Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as this policy only applies to buildings and office spaces owned or leased by the state of Oklahoma.

Requires closure of the following businesses: amusement parks, aquariums, arcades, art galleries (to the extent that they are open without appointment), barber shops and hair salons, bowling alleys, cosmetic stores, dance studios, esthetician practices, fraternal organization facilities, furniture stores, gyms and fitness studios (including climbing gyms), hookah bars, indoor and outdoor malls (i.e., all portions of a retail complex containing stores and restaurants in a single area), indoor party places (including jumping gyms and laser tag), jewelry shops and boutiques (unless they provide goods exclusively through pick-up or delivery service), medical spas, facial spas, day spas, and non-medical massage therapy services, museums, nail and tanning salons, non-tribal card rooms, skating rinks, senior activity centers, ski resorts, social and private clubs, tattoo/piercing parlors, tennis clubs, theaters, yoga studios, and youth clubs. Also requires all pools, skate parks, outdoor sports courts, and playground equipment areas. Private and public camp grounds also must be closed immediately.        https://www.oregon.gov/gov/Documents/executive_orders/eo_20-12.pdf On 20200505, camp grounds are permitted to reopen, representing first easing: https://govsite-assets.s3.amazonaws.com/jkAULYKcSh6DoDF8wBM0_EO%2020-12.pdf

Per EO 20-25, indicates that there was a directive effective May 5 that allows private and public campgrounds the option of reopening if they are able to complicy OHA guidances regarding outdoor recreation. Coding this policy to this executive order as the May 5 directive is not currently findable.

Statewide easing of restrictions on the following businesses, conditional on them following health and safety guidelines: ski resorts. Coding as IndoorAllowed under BusinessRestrictLevel as no stipulations closing indoor portions of ski resorts are included.

Bar restrictions eased for 31 counties approved for Phase One (all counties but Multnomah, Washington, Clackamas, Marion, Polk), conditional on meeting health and safety guidelines: in-person service at tables only, 6 ft distancing, open until 10 pm only

For baseline counties (Multnomah, Washington, Clackamas, Marion, Polk), social gatherings of more than 10 people remain prohibited. Religious gatherings up to 25 can occur. Eased when Multnomah moved to Phase One, with no more counties under this level: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=36806

For Phase One counties (all counties but Multnomah, Washington, Clackamas, Marion, Polk), all gatherings more than 25 are prohibited. For baseline counties, this gathering restriction applies for cultural, civic, and faith gatherings (otherwise a restriction of 10 for social gatherings). Easing began on 20200605 when counties could move to Phase 2: https://www.oregon.gov/gov/Documents/executive_orders/eo_20-27.pdf

PolicyCodingNotes: Statewide easing of restrictions on the following businesses, conditional on them following health and safety guidelines: art galleries, boutiques, furniture stores, jewelry shops, retail businesses may re-open to in-person services. Requires that the number of customers in the retail store enable at least 6 ft of distancing between individuals and customers. As counties move from different phases, more sectors can re-open separately. Starting on 202001118, all retail services must operate up to 75 pct: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=37702

For Phase One counties (all counties but Multnomah, Washington, Clackamas, Marion, Polk), the following businesses can have in-person services conditional on following health and safety protocols: personal care businesses and facilities (e.g., salons, gyms), all retail businesses, including malls and shopping centers. Requires at least 6 ft distancing. More counties move to Phase One through 20200619, when it becomes statewide

Restaurant restrictions eased for 31 counties approved for Phase One (all counties but Multnomah, Washington, Clackamas, Marion, Polk), conditional on meeting health and safety guidelines: in-person service at tables only, 6 ft distancing, dine in services until 10 pm only. More counties move to this level to 20200619, and some move to Phase Two, where there are the same restrictions but dine in service can operate until 12 am.
Phase Two counties have similar physical distancing requirements as Phase One counties, but can now remain open up to midnight

Phase Two counties may have gatherings up to 50 in indoor spaces and 100 on outdoor spaces, conditional on following distancing requirements. For June 5, 14 counties went to Phase 2: Benton, Curry, Douglas, Grant, Jackson, Klamath, Lake, Lane, Linn, Morrow, Union, Wallowa, Wasco, Wheeler. For June 6, 14 more counties - Baker, Deschuetes, Clatsop, Columbia, Coos, Crook, Gilliam, Harney, Jefferson, Josephine, Malheur, Sherman, Umatilla, Yamhill - were added. For June 8, Tillamook moved to phase two, bringing the total to 29 of 36 counties in Phase Two.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Phase Two counties have eased restrictions on the following businesses previously closed statewide: pools, skate parks, outdoor sports courts, playgrounds, amusement parks, social clubs, theaters. For June 5, there are 14 Phase Two counties: Benton, Curry, Douglas, Grant, Jackson, Klamath, Lake, Lane, Linn, Morrow, Union, Wallowa, Wasco, Wheeler. Continues to add (and shift back) counties. Starting on 20201118 with the Two Week Freeze, businesses that are not closed for in-person services must be limited to no more than 50: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=37679
Phase Two counties have similar physical distancing requirements as Phase One counties, but can now remain open up to midnight

Multnomah county moves to Phase One, allowing for eased restrictions on the following: personal care businesses and facilities (salons, gyms), all retail businesses, including malls and shopping centers. Now all counties (Phase One and Two) have eased restrictions on these businesses, so coding as statewide

Requires employees, contractors, volunteers, customers, and visitors to wear a mask, face shield, or face covering in businesses listed in the order (eg grocery stores, fitness organizations, personal service providers, retail, restaurants and bars and like venues, etc), as well as for ride-sharing and public transit, when they are not eating or drinking. Also does not require employees to wear them if they are not interacting with patrons and can maintain at least 6 ft of distancing. Applies to the following counties: Clackamas, Hood River, Lincoln, Marion, Multnomah, Polk, and Washington (mixture of Phase One and Phase Two counties). Starting on 20200701, Clatsop added to the list: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=36861

Requires the public to wear masks, face shield, or face covering when at a place of business (sectors listed in the order), as well as ride sharing and public transit. Requirement for individuals for 12 and over (recommended for those younger) who are medically able to so. Applies to the following counties: Clackamas, Hood River, Lincoln, Marion, Multnomah, Polk, and Washington (mixture of Phase One and Phase Two counties). Coded to Mandate2 as it applies to indoor public settings as well as shared transportation.

Expands mandate statewide, requiring employees, contractors, volunteers, customers, and visitors to wear a mask, face shield, or face covering in businesses listed in the order (eg grocery stores, fitness organizations, personal service providers, retail, restaurants and bars and like venues, etc), as well as for ride-sharing and public transit, when they are not eating or drinking. Also does not require employees to wear them if they are not interacting with patrons and can maintain at least 6 ft of distancing.

Requires the public to wear masks, face shield, or face covering indoors for all counties, expanding the previous order that was only applicable to a subset of counties. Coded to Mandate2 as it applies to indoor public settings as well as shared transportation.

Restricts social gatherings indoors to 10 or fewer, expanding restrictions for Phase One counties (Lincoln, Washington, Clackamas, Multnomah, Union). Continues previous restrictions for outdoor gatherings in general and religious gatherings.

Restricts social gatherings indoors to 10 or fewer, expanding restrictions for Phase Two counties (31 counties). Continues previous restrictions for outdoor gatherings in general and religious gatherings.

Expands requirement to wear face coverings in outdoor public spaces when 6 ft of distance cannot be maintained, and continues previous order (i.e., public to wear masks, face shield, or face covering when in indoor public spaces), as well as ride sharing and public transit. Requirement for individuals for 12 and over (recommended for those younger) who are medically able to so. Coding to Mandate3 as it applies to broadly across indoor and outdoor settings. Starting 20200724, mandate is somewhat strengthened, applying to individuals 5 years and older: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=37003

Statewide, somewhat expands restrictions, now limiting capacity no more than 100 (previously just needed to maintain at least 6 distancing). Also must close by 10 pm. No formal order has been published, so the governors press release is being used for documentation.

Statewide, somewhat expands restrictions, now limiting capacity no more than 100 (previously just needed to maintain at least 6 distancing). Also must close by 10 pm. No formal order has been published, so the governors press release is being used for documentation.

Umatilla County is moved to Baseline Stay at Home Status, requiring bars and like venues to close for in-person operations (take-out and delivery only). Ends on 20200821 as Umatilla goes back to Phase One: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=37164

Umatilla County is moved back to Baseline Stay at Home Status, wherein all indoor and outdoor social gatherings are limited to 10 people while civic, cultural, and faith-based gatherings are limited to 25. Eased on 20200821 with Umatilla going back to Phase One: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=37164

Umatilla County is moved to Baseline Stay Home status, wherein personal care businesses and facilities (salons, gyms), retail businesses such as malls and shopping centers must close. On 20200821, this was ended for Umatilla: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=37164

Umatilla County is moved to Baseline Stay at Home Status, requiring restaurants to close for in-person operations (take-out and delivery only). On 20200821, Umatilla moves back to Phase One, allowing for in-person services: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=37164

Umatilla County is moved back to Baseline Stay at Home Status, wherein (quote) all individuals should minimize all non-essential travel and stay at their home or place of residence as much as possible (quote). Coded as a recommended stay-at-home order. Ended on 20200821 when Umatilla is approved to go back to Phase One: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=37164

Malheur, Marion, Multnomah, Jackson, Umatilla go to two-week pause, reducing social gatherings to no more than 6 people. More counties are added to the Two-Week Pause on 20201111 https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=37679

Travel advisory issued, (quote) Persons arriving in Oregon from other states or countries, including returning Oregon residents, should practice self-quarantine for 14 days after arrival. These persons should limit their interactions to their immediate household. This recommendation does not apply to individuals who cross state or country borders for essential travel. (quote)

Statewide, bars and like venues must move to take-out and delivery only as part of the Two-Week Freeze. Eased starting 20201203, as counties move to color-coded tier system: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=53816

Statewide, social gatherings are limited to no more than 6 people indoors and outdoors (from no more than 2 households), and faith-based organizations can have a maximum of 25 people indoor and 50 people outdoors. Eased starting 20201203, as counties move to color-coded tier system: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=53816

The following businesses must close as part of the Two-Week Pause: gyms and fitness organizations and indoor recreational facilities, movie theaters, bowling alleys, arcades and pools, as well as recreational and youth sports. Eased starting 20201203, as counties move to color-coded tier system: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=53816

Statewide, restaurants and like venues must move to take-out and delivery only with the Two-Week Pause. Eased starting 20201203, as counties move to color-coded tier system: https://www.oregon.gov/newsroom/Pages/NewsDetail.aspx?newsid=53816

Lower risk (Green) counties can have bars re-open to 50 pct capacity maximum indoors, up to 300 people outdoors, with a maximum of 8 people per table, at least 6 ft distancing, etc. Must close by 1200 am.
Moderate risk (Yellow) and High Risk (Orange) counties can reopen to indoor services at different levels of capacity indoors and outdoors, must close at 1100 pm.

Extreme risk (Red) counties can only have bars re-open for outdoor services at a maximum of 50 people capacity, 6 people per table, limit 2 households. Take-away remains highly recommended. Must close by 1100 pm

Lower risk (Green) counties can have up to 10 people indoors (no more than 4 households recommended) and 12 maximum outdoor for social gatherings. Religious gatherings have a limit of 75 pct capacity indoors, a maximum of 300 people outdoors. On 20201218 religious gathering restrictions become recommendations https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le3465.pdf

Moderate risk (Yellow) counties can have up to 8 people indoors (no more than 2 households recommended) and 10 maximum outdoor for social gatherings. Religious gatherings have a limit of 50 pct capacity or 150 people indoors (whichever is lower), a maximum of 250 people outdoors. On 20201218 religious gathering restrictions become recommendations https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le3465.pdf

High risk (Orange) counties can have up to 6 people indoors (no more than 2 households recommended) and 8 maximum outdoor for social gatherings. Religious gatherings have a limit of 25 pct capacity or 150 people indoors (whichever is lower), a maximum of 200 people outdoors. On 20201218 religious gathering restrictions become recommendations https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le3465.pdf

Extreme risk (Red) counties can have up to 6 people indoors and outdoors (no more than 2 households recommended) for social gatherings. Religious gatherings have a limit of 25 pct capacity or 100 people indoors (whichever is lower), a maximum of 150 people outdoors. On 20201218 religious gathering restrictions become recommendations https://sharedsystems.dhsoha.state.or.us/DHSForms/Served/le3465.pdf

Lower risk (Green), Moderate risk (Yellow), and High Risk (Orange) counties can re-open entertainment and recreational establishments at 50 pct capacity indoors (varying maximum of people) and varying maximum number of people outdoors.
Extreme risk (Red counties) can only have entertainment and recreational establishments re-open to outdoor services up to 50 people

Lower risk (Green) counties can have restaurants and like venues re-open to 50 pct capacity maximum indoors, up to 300 people outdoors, with a maximum of 8 people per table, at least 6 ft distancing, etc. Must close by 1200 am.
Moderate risk (Yellow) and High Risk (Orange) counties can reopen to indoor services at different levels of capacity indoors and outdoors, must close at 1100 pm.

Extreme risk (Red) counties can only have restaurants and like venues re-open for outdoor services at a maximum of 50 people capacity, 6 people per table, limit 2 households. Take-away remains highly recommended. Must close by 1100 pm

Initial gathering restriction activated with stay-at-home order for Allegheny County, Bucks County, Chester County, Delaware County, Monroe County, Montgomery County, and Philadelphia County. Individuals ordered to stay home as much as possible, but no formal numerical restrictions or prohibitions on gatherings. Thus GathLim left blank. Additional counties were added to this order from 20200324 to 20200331.

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) All individuals residing in Allegheny County, Bucks County, Chester County, Delaware County, Monroe County, Montgomery County, and Philadelphia County are ordered to stay at home except as needed to access, support, or provide life sustaining business, emergency, or government service (quote). Initial expiry date was 20200406. From 20200323 to 20200331, counties are steadily added to the stay-at-home order, and the order is extended to 20200430: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/20200331-GOV-Stay-at-Home-Order-Amendment.pdf

Expands gathering restriction to being statewide. Takes effect 8 pm on 20200401 until 20200430. Individuals ordered to stay home as much as possible, but no formal numerical restrictions or prohibitions on gatherings. Thus GathLim left blank. Extended to 20200508: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/20200420-GOV-Stay-at-Home-Order-Amendment.pdf

Takes effect 8pm on 20200401. Exceptions include activities to access, support, or provide life-sustaining business, emergency, or government services, including child care for employees of life-sustaining businesses. This Order supersedes all previous Orders directing  (quote) Individuals to Stay at Home (quote) On 20200420, extended to 20200508: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/20200420-GOV-Stay-at-Home-Order-Amendment.pdf  24 counties moved to yellow phase, easing StayAtHome starting 20200508 https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/gov-wolf-sec-of-health-take-actions-on-stay-at-home-orders-issue-yellow-phase-orders/
Recommends that all Pennsylvanians wear a mask any time they leave their homes for life-sustaining reasons

Requires all customers to wear masks while on business premises and deny entry to individuals not wearing masks. However, individuals who cannot wear a mask due to a medical condition or are under 2 years old, per CDC guidance, may enter the premises and are not required to provide documentation of such medical condition. Coded to Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies to all essential retail in operation.

Gathering restriction on more than 25 for the 24 counties transitioned to the yellow phase: Bradford, Cameron, Centre, Clarion, Clearfield, Clinton, Crawford, Elk, Erie, Forest, Jefferson, Lawrence, Lycoming, McKean, Mercer, Montour, Northumberland, Potter, Snyder, Sullivan, Tioga, Union, Venango, and Warren. PolicyCodingNotes: Expands public mask mandate, requiring individuals to wear face coverings if they are outdoors and unable to maintain distance of six ft from others, in any indoor location, waiting for or riding on public transportation, taxi, ride share and like vehicles, etc. Provides some exemptions (i.e., medical/disability, under the age of 2 years). Coded as Mandate 3 for PublicMaskLevel as it explicitly requires masks across outdoors and indoors settings. Expanded on 20201118 to require face coverings in all indoor locations, irrespective of physical distancing. Continues outdoor requirement when physical distancing is not possible: https://www.governor.pa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/20201117-SOH-Universal-Face-Coverings-Order-Update.pdf.

PolicyCodingNotes: Re-imposes gathering restrictions on indoor gatherings, prohibiting indoor events and gatherings of more than 25 people. Outdoor gatherings continue to have a limit of no more than 250 people. Ended mandate with court ruling on 20200914: https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/dailyamerican.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/6/40/640080a6-f6c8-11ea-977f-d37f8b7ed48f/5f5fd1ffd6dbe.pdf.pdf
With court ruling ending the gathering mandate, Pennsylvania continues to recommend that gatherings are limited to no more than 25 indoors and no more than 250 outdoors
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: Expands restrictions on gatherings, making it a mandate from a recommendation. Allows the following for indoor events: 20 pct occupancy for 0-2,000 people, 15 pct occupancy for 2,001-10,000 people, 10 pct occupancy for over 10,000 people up to 3,375. Allows the following for outdoor events: 25 pct occupancy for 0-2,000 people, 20 pct occupancy for 2,001-10,000 people, 15 pct occupancy for over 10,000 people up to 7,500.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicyCodingNotes and Added gathering limits

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) I hereby strongly advise all Pennsylvanians to only leave home to go to work or school, or for essential needs of themselves or persons they are caring for (quote)

Expands previous quarantine order from a recommendation to a mandate. The quarantine order now requires all travelers to get tested 72 hours prior to entering Pennsylvania or quarantine for 14 days upon entering, and the order now applies to all states and international locations. Exemptions include those who commute to neighboring states for work or health care.

Expands non-religious gathering restrictions, now limiting indoor and outdoor occupancy of events of up to no more than 500 people for indoors (if the maximum occupancy is 10,000), with different maximums for smaller venues (10 pct capacity for venues with 0-2,000 people capacity, 5 pct capacity for venues of 2,001-10,000 people capacity indoors) and then up to 2500 people outdoors (in venues that can have up to 10000 people, 5 pct capacity up to 2500). For smaller venues, outdoor capacitys are 15 pct capacity for venues 0-2000 and 10 pct capacity for 2,001 to 10,000 people capacity venues. Religious gatherings and places of worship are exempted from these limits. Social distancing continues to be required.

Expands gathering restrictions. Regardless of capacity limits, indoor gatherings of more than 10 persons are prohibited. Indoor religious gatherings are exempt from indoor gathering restrictions but are strongly encouraged to enforce physical distancing and other mitigation measures at gatherings.  Outdoor gatherings of more than 50 persons are prohibited, which by the technical language of the EO applies to all gatherings, including religious.  A FAQ suggests gatherings at places of worship are exempt, but does not clarify whether this is only indoors.
LastUpdatedNotes: Revised religious gathering limits: EO exempts indoor religious gatherings only.

PolicyCodingNotes: Governor moved up April break to start March 16, closing schools except for food programs administered by schools. Schools are closed to in-person instruction through June https://www.ri.gov/press/view/38208. Governor announces another delay to first day of school on Aug 12, so schools will reopen on 20200914 unless there are further changes.

PolicyCodingNotes: Closure required: in-person entertainment establishments (eg, theaters, cinemas, sporting events, convert venues, museums, zoos) and (quote) close-contact businesses (quote) such as fitness centers, gyms, hair salons,. In effect at 5 pm 20200323. Initial expiry is 20200330. Extended on 20200410, pertaining to business closures. The following businesses are closed: non-critical retail businesses, in-person entertainment establishments (eg, theaters, cinemas, sporting events, convert venues, museums, zoos) and (quote) close-contact businesses (quote) such as fitness centers, gyms, hair salons. Continues closure for the following businesses: recreation and entertainment establishments (eg, theaters, cinemas, sporting events, bowling alleys, concert venues, museums, zoos), close-contact business (gymnasiums, fitness centers, hair salons and barbershops, nail salons, spas and tattoo parlors). On 20200601, continues closure for the following businesses: recreation and entertainment establishments (eg, theaters, cinemas, sporting events, bowling alleys, concert venues, museums). Nightclubs remain closed as of 20201214. Nightclub closure extended to 20201221: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-105.pdf. Nightclub closure extended to 20210120 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-108.pdf
