PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) All Rhode Island residents are required to stay home (quote). As of 20200509, Repeals the portion of the stay-at-home EO to stay at home, ending the order http://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-32.pdf

All non-critical retail businesses to cease operations as of 20200330. Easing began on 20200509, permitting non-critical retail businesses to reopen for limited services: http://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-32.pdf

Individuals who test positive for COVID-19 must self-isolate until they have had no fever for at least 72 hours, they have experienced resolution of symptoms and at least 7 days have passed since their symptoms appeared . Family or household members residing with an individual who tests positive must self-quarantine for 14 days. Extended to 20200605 http://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-31.pdf This is extended to 20200704 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-42.pdf Extended to 20200802 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-52.pdf. Extended to end of August on 20200729. Extended to 20201003. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-71.pdf Extended to 20201028 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-79.pdf. Extended to 20201102 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-81.pdf. Extended to 20201203 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-91.pdf. Extended to 20201231 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-102.pdf. Eased on 20201210. Anyone with close contact with someone diagnosed or clinically diagnosed with COVID-19 must self-isolate for 10 days from their last known exposure. Individuals may shorten self-isolation to 7 days if they have a negative result from a test taken at least 5 days after exposure: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-104.pdf.

Employees working at customer-facing businesses must wear masks, and companies must provide them at their expense. All customer-facing businesses shall also take steps to require customers to wear face coverings. Extended to 20201214: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-100.pdf. Extended to 20201221: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-105.pdf.

(quote) any person who is in a place open to the public, whether indoors or outdoors, shall cover their mouth and nose with a mask or cloth face covering (quote). Also explicitly requires masks or cloth face coverings when inside grocery stores, pharmacies, other retail stores, and on public transit, taxi, ride sharing or similar service. Coded as Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it explicitly calls for mask use across indoor and outdoor settings. Mandate3 Mask rule extended for a month on 20200803.  Extended to 20201003 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-69.pdf. Extended to 20201102 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-81.pdf. Extended to 20201203 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-91.pdf. Extended to 20201205 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-94.pdf. Extended to 20201231 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-102.pdf

Bar restrictions eased,  allowing for outdoor portions of bar venues to have limited in-person services https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-40.pdf. Eased on 20200601 to allow in-person operations.

Eases restrictions on non-critical retail businesses, permitting them to open for in-store pickup and limited browsing. Only allow 1 per customer per 300 sq ft of store area. On 20200521, extends eased restrictions on non-critical retail businesses, permitting them to open for in-store pickup and limited browsing. Only allow 1 per customer per 300 sq ft of store area. Continues to permit in-person services, extended to 20201214: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-100.pdf. Eased further on 20200629 to allow only 1 customer per 100 sq ft of store area: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-50.pdf.  Extended to 20201221: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-105.pdf. Extends restrictions on retail to 20210121 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-108.pdf

Restaurant restrictions eased, allowing for outdoor portions of venues to have limited in-person services https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-40.pdf. Eased on 20200601 to allow in-person operations.

Strongly advises vulnerable populations (eg, people 65 and older) to stay at home. Extended to 20200730 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-50.pdf. Extended to end of August on 20200729 Extended to 20201028 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-79.pdf. Extended to 20201128 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-88.pdf. Extended to 20201130 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-90.pdf Extended on 20201108 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-90.pdf. Extended to 20201130 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-98.pdf. Extended to 20201214 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-100.pdf. Extended to 20201221: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-105.pdf. Extended to 20210120 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-108.pdf

Eases bar restrictions allowing for indoor dining at 50 pct capacity. Service to standing customers is prohibited. On 20200630, further eases restrictions on bars, which can now operate at 66 percent of capacity. On 20200807, adds a minor restriction, (quote) From 11.00 p.m. until closing, a licensee must close their bar area, including but not limited to the bar counter and seating at the bar counter, and ensure that the bar area is not accessible to patrons. (quote)
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateIssued and DateEnacted, added DateEased

PolicyCodingNotes: Original easing of the 5 person gathering restrictions, now groups of 15 allowed. Eased to being 25 people gatherings indoors on 20200629
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Eases restrictions on certain personal care businesses (hair salons and barbershops, nail salons, tattoo parlors, tanning parlors, estheticians, and massage therapists ) and gyms and fitness centers allowing them to reopen subject to guidelines. For gyms and fitness centers, no more than 1 person per 150 sq ft, and maximum of 15 people with distancing for group classes.  Also eases restrictions on some recreational businesses and historical/cultural establishments, may conduct limited outdoor operations and, under certain circumstances, indoor activites that go along with them (i..e, 25 pct capacity). Examples of these operations include outdoor mini golf courses, batting cages, go-kart tracks, rail biking, bumper cars, zoos, horseback riding, and historical sites. State parks and beaches are open as well. Also permits in-person offices to re-open at limited capacity. Starting on 20200630, begain easing more, permitting higher capacity limits and opening of more sectors (though night clubs remained close): https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-50.pdf. In-person office restrictions extended to 20201221: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-105.pdf. Extends rules on office-based restrictions. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-108.pdf. On 20201221, restrictions for offices are extended to 20210120.

Eases restaurant restrictions allowing for indoor dining at 50 pct capacity. Service to standing customers is prohibited. On 20200630, further eases restrictions on restaurants, which can now operate at 66 percent of capacity. On 20200807, adds a minor restriction , (quote) From 11.00 p.m. until closing, a licensee must close their bar area, including but not limited to the bar counter and seating at the bar counter, and ensure that the bar area is not accessible to patrons. (quote)

Variable mask requirements based on re-opening scenarios, but at minimum requires students over the age of 2 on buses to wear masks under the full-reopening and partial reopening scenario, and high school students are required to wear masks if 6 ft of distancing is not possible.
Gatherings of up to 25 indoors are now permitted. Also allows gatherings of up to 50 outdoors. Religious gatherings are permitted up to 125 people indoors and 250 people outdoors.

Allows the reopening of convention hall, theaters and performance venues provided that they maintain 66 percent capacity or fewer than 125 people.  Fairs and festivals are also able to reopen provided they remain at 66 percent capacity or under 250 people. On 20201105, reduces capacity limits to 50 pct for these venues: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-95.pdf

(quote) All indoor and outdoor social gatherings of more than fifteen (15) people in any public or private space are prohibited. (quote) Includes exceptions for receptions for weddings (50 indoor and 100 outdoor under strict distancing guidelines). Indoor gatherings at religious institutions can have 125 max. (quote) religious and faithbased organizations may conduct indoor in-person activities up to 66 pct percent of worship space capacity, subject to a cap of one hundred and twenty-five (125) people and to the Phase III guidelines for religious and faith-based organizations (quote). Outdoor religious events can have 250, but distancing and masking must be in effect. All houses of worship must develop a COVID control plan.  Extended to 20201028 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-79.pdf. Extended to 20201128 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-88.pdf

(quote) All indoor and outdoor social gatherings of more than ten (10) people in any public or private space are prohibited. (quote) Includes exceptions for receptions for weddings (50 indoor and 100 outdoor under strict distancing guidelines). Indoor gatherings at religious institutions can have 125 max. (quote) religious and faithbased organizations may conduct indoor in-person activities up to 66 pct percent of worship space capacity, subject to a cap of one hundred and twenty-five (125) people and to the Phase III guidelines for religious and faith-based organizations (quote). Outdoor religious events can have 250, but distancing and masking must be in effect. All houses of worship must develop a COVID control plan.

On 20201108, Extends restrictions on bars but changes permitted hours of operation (quote) Effective Sunday, November 8th restaurants and bars may serve patrons on-site, indoors and outdoors, until 10:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday and until 10:30 p.m. Friday and Saturday, after which times restaurants and bars shall only offer pickup, delivery and drive-through service. (quote) Including 22h30 in CurfewStart because we are not distinguing between different curfews by day. Continues previous restrictions (can operate at 66 percent of capacity). On 20201130, Expands capacity restrictions on bars. An establishment's indoor dining capacity is limited to 33pct ( was 66pct) of an establishment regular seating capacity. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-100.pdf. Extended to 20201221: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-105.pdf. Eased on 20201221, where restaurants are allowed to have indoor dining at 50 pct capacity (up from 33 pct). Services to seated customers only, up to 8 people can be seated at an individual table indoors but must be from the same household. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-108.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateExpiry and PolicyCodingNotes, Added DateEased

PolicyCodingNotes: Effective Sunday, November 8 recreational or entertainment businesses and historical/cultural establishments shall not operate after 10:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday or after 10:30 p.m. Friday and Saturday. Extends restrictions on recreational and historical/cultural establishments. Including 22h30 in CurfewStart because we are not distinguing between different curfews by day.  (quote) Subject to strict adherence to social distancing, masking, screening and sanitation protocols, recreational or entertainment businesses and historical/cultural establishments, that are not venues of assembly, may conduct indoor and outdoor operations subject to a capacity limit of up to 66 pct capacity or 1 per 100 sq ft.

On 20201108, extends restrictions on restaurants but changes permitted hours of operation (quote) Effective Sunday, November 8th restaurants and bars may serve patrons on-site, indoors and outdoors, until 10:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday and until 10:30 p.m. Friday and Saturday, after which times restaurants and bars shall only offer pickup, delivery and drive-through service. (quote) Including 22h30 in CurfewStart because we are not distinguing between different curfews by day. Continues previous restrictions (can operate at 66 percent of capacity). On 20201130, Expands capacity restrictions on restaurants. An establishment's indoor dining capacity is limited to 33pct ( was 66pct) of an establishment regular seating capacity. https//governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-100.pdf. Extended to 20201221: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-105.pdf. Eased on 20201221, where restaurants are allowed to have indoor service at 50 pct capacity (up from 33 pct). Services to seated customers only, up to 8 people can be seated at an individual table indoors but must be from the same household. https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-108.pdf
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated DateExpiry and PolicyCodingNotes, Added DateEased

PolicyCodingNotes: Effective Sunday, November 8, all Rhode Island residents are advised to stay home from 10 pm to 5 am Sunday through Thursday unless traveling to or from work or school, traveling for medical treatment or obtaining necessities (food, medicine, gas, etc.). For Friday and Saturday, residents are advised to stay home from 1030 pm to 5 am.  Including 22h30 in CurfewStart because we are not distinguing between different curfews by day. Extended to 20201214. Extended to 20201221: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-105.pdf. Extended to 20210120 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-108.pdf

Effective 20201119, expands gathering restrictions. (quote) attendance at all indoor public and private social gatherings, including holiday gatherings, parties and celebrations shall be limited to members of a single household (quote), so numeric limitations coded as 0. Religious gatherings are limited to 125 people indoors and 150 outdoors.

Personal service businesses and gyms shall not operate after 10:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday or after 10:30 p.m. Friday and Saturday. Including 22h30 in CurfewStart because we are not distinguing between different curfews by day. (quote)Personal care services can have 1 customer per 100 sq ft. (quote) Personal services businesses and operations, including, but not limited to, hair salons and barbershops, nail salons, tattoo parlors, tanning parlors, estheticians, and massage therapists may open subject to all of the requirements of their professional or facility licensing, the requirements of the Phase III guidelines for personal services at https://ReopeningRI.com and regulations set forth by RIDOH. Such personal service businesses may allow up to one customer per 100 square feet. (quote). For gyms, Phase III rules continue. (quote) Outdoor group fitness activities are preferred but are limited to one person per 100 square feet, with all physical distancing guidelines to be observed. (quote). Extended to 20201221: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-105.pdf. Restrictions for personal care services are extended. Restrictions on gyms are eased: Capcity limits: one (1) person per 150 square feet with individuals remaining fourteen (14) feet apart indoors and six (6) feet apart outdoors, subject to Phase III guidance. (quote). Masks must be worn at all times.https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-108.pdf

Effective 20201130, expands gathering restrictions for outdoor gatherings, which is now 150 people (from 250 people).  (quote) attendance at all indoor public and private social gatherings, including holiday gatherings, parties and celebrations shall be limited to members of a single household (quote), so numeric limitations coded as 0. Extended to 20201221: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-105.pdf. Extended to 20210120 https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-108.pdf

Expands restrictions on gyms and fitness centers. Must close all indoor operations. Outdoor gym and fitness activities may continue but outdoor group fitness classes are not permitted. Extended to 20201221: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-105.pdf.

Expands restrictions on convention halls, theaters, concert halls, performances venues, requiring them to close during the Pause. Extended to 20201221: https://governor.ri.gov/documents/orders/Executive-Order-20-105.pdf.
Eases restrictions on convention halls, theaters, concert halls, allowing for indoor occupancy up to 25 pct capcity, up to 125 people.

State of Emergency Declaration. PolicyCodingNotes: Announcement from gov, not EO: (quote) I urge every school district in Tennessee to close as soon as practically possible, with all schools expected to close by Friday, March 20, 2020 at the latest. Schools should remain closed through March 31, 2020 to further mitigate the spread of this infectious disease and we will issue further guidance prior to March 31. (quote) On 20200325 governor continues to urge public school closures, but still no apparent issuance of a mandate. Confirmed by state education site: https://www.tn.gov/education/health-and-safety/update-on-coronavirus.html. Governor on 20200415 (quote) called on (quote) all schools to remain closed through the end of the school year, but continued to be a recommendation https://www.tn.gov/governor/covid-19/covid-19-daily-bulletin/2020/4/15/covid-19-bulletin--9---april-15--2020.html. Announcement on July 28 indicates that governor encourages in-person instruction, thus ending recommendation to keep schools closed. All decisions about schools now made at district and individual level.

PolicyCodingNotes: (quote) every person in Texas shall wear a face covering over the nose and mouth when inside a commercial entity or other building or space open to public, or when in a outdoor public space, wherever it is not feasible to maintain six feet of social distancing (quote). Lists exemptions (e.g., person younger than 10, persons with medical conditions or disabilities that would prevent wearing a face covering). Technically does not apply to any county that has met some minimum of COVID-19 cases and that a county judge as permitted opt-out per the TDEM form. Treating as a statewide mandate since these counties are not detailed. Coded as Mandate3 as it explicitly applies across indoor and outdoor settings. Exemption for religious gatherings.

(quote) for any outdoor gathering in excess of 10 people...the gathering is prohibited (quote). Allows for mayor of the city or county judge to approve of the gathering as long it is not inconsistent with other portions of EO-28

PolicyCodingNotes: Individuals over the age of 60 and individuals who are immunocompromised should avoid contact with other individuals. Also recommends that all individuals avoid discretionary travel, shopping trips (other than shopping for food and essentials), and social visits. In combination, coding as a stay-at-home recommendation for vulnerable populations.

Social distancing directives include (quote) Do not attend any in-person gathering of any number of people who are not of the same household or residence (quote). Restriction ended, replaced with a recommendation when the state moved to orange risk phase: https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-19.pdf

(quote) I expect all residents...to follow these directives (quote) self--quarantine for 14 days after traveling. Ends when state goes to public health risk orange: https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-19.pdf

All individuals to stay home as much as possible, but does not involve a formal mandate. (quote) these directives are not to be confused with a shelter-in-place order (quote). In effect until 1159pm on 20200413, so coded as an expiry of 20200414.

Stipulates self-isolation or quarantine for anyone who tests positive for COVID-19, exposed to someone who tests positive, or is a member of a household who tests positive. On 20200501, rescinds the prior order: https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-19.pdf

Urges individuals to wear a cloth face covering in grocery stores, in retail, and in public when not able to social distance. Continues recommendations for mask use through Phases Orange and Yellow https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/Phased%20Health%20Guidelines%20V4.0.1.pdf   Extended to 20200704 https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-32.pdf

In-person services in bars, taverns, saloons, and like venues are allowed (quote) with extreme caution (quote) upon the designation of the COVID19 public health risk being downgraded to orange. Coding as IndoorAllowed under BusinessRestrictLevel. Eased on 20200612, as counties begin moving to Public Health Green and thus the requirements around maintaining 6 ft distancing at bars become recommendations: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Governor/Exectuive_Order_Updating_Health_Risk_Status_in_Certain_Areas_and_Adopting_Updated_Guidelines.pdf With the adoption of the new transmission phase system, some level of bar restrictions continue (75 pct capacity for Moderate transmission counties and required at least 6 ft distancing among tables/groups in High transmission counties): https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-19-COVID-19-Transmission-Index.pdf Extended to 20201218: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-26-Updated-Statewide-COVID-19-Restrictions.pdf. Extended to 20210122 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2020-27_Updated%20Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf

Under Public Health Orange, service providers and customers must wear face coverings during services. Recommendations for employee mask use are listed under hotels and tourism businesses. On 20200516, expands businesses and sectors were employees are required to wear face coverings: restaurants and bars, gyms and fitness centers (patrons are encouraged to wear face coverings), presonal service providers and patrons (previously required). It is strongly recommended that customers and employees wear face coverings at retail, including grocery stores (does not use must like in other sectors): https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-22.pdf Eases on 20200612 as some counties move to Public Health Risk Green and thus those are recommendations: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Governor/Exectuive_Order_Updating_Health_Risk_Status_in_Certain_Areas_and_Adopting_Updated_Guidelines.pdf. Extended to 20210122 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2020-27_Updated%20Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf

PolicyCodingNotes: For yellow phase locations, (quote) Beginning 1200pm noon on Wednesday, May 27, school activities, including sports, may resume under jurisdiction of district and school authorities in adherence to indoor and outdoor guidelines (quote) Instruction remains remote until the 2020-2021 academic year. On 20200626, green and yellow phase counties can re-open for in-person schooling:  https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-33.pdf Ended on 20200717, with Phased 4.8 guidelines allowing in-person instruction at all risk levels: https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-44.pdf

Requires use of a face covering in state facilities (i.e., any building or structure that is owned or leased by the state or a state governmental entity - any department, board, commission, institution, agency or instition of a higher education of the state). State issued clarifying orders on 20200629 (EO 35: https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-35.pdf) and 20200630 (EO 36: https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-36.pdf) but did not change the policy substantively, or its timing. Coded as Mandate1 as it applies to limited settings (i.e., state facilities). Extended to 20200808: https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-45.pdf Extended to 20200821 https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-48.pdf Extended on 20200904 with no expiry date https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-59.pdf Extended to 20201021 https://rules.utah.gov/wp-content/uploads/Utah-Executive-Order-No.-2020-63.pdf

(quote) Each individual, including an employee, student, or visitor, on school property or on a school bus shall wear a face covering (quote) unless they can maintain physical distance of at least 6 from other individuals outdoors, when eating or drinking and maintaining at least 6 ft between individuals, children who are younger than 3, and for various medical exemptions. Applies to K-12 schools. Extended to 20210122 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-28_Updated_School_Face_Mask_Order.pdf
Declares a public health emergency without clear expiry. Treating as separate from the original state of emergency declaration as this is a public health emergency declaration

With the adoption of the new transmission phase system, counties in Low levels are strongly encouraged to have people wear masks or face coverings in public but do not require them beyond very specific settings (i.e., gatherings of more than 50). Coding as a Mandate1 under PublicMaskLevel, but treating as a an easing from the previous order (i.e., requirement to wear at state-owned buildings). Applies to Daggett, Kane, Piute, Rich, Wayne. A (quote) circuit breaker (quote) phase will occur where both Moderate and High transmission levels will be required to wear masks in public indoors and outdoors. Beyond 20201029, this applies to both Moderate and Low transmission counties (with requirements to wear masks in gatherings more than 25 for moderate transmission levels) https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-20-UPDATING-COVID-19-Transmission-Index.pdf

With the adoption of the new transmission phase system, counties in High transmission level have a mask mandate wherein masks or face coverings are required in all public places indoors and outdoors where at least 6 ft distancing cannot occur. Exempts children under 3 years old, due to medical conditions, etc. Coded as Mandate3 under PublicMaskLevel as it is widely applicable across settings (indoors and outdoors). Applies to Beaver, Box Elder, Cache, Carbon, Davis, Emery, Garfield, Grand, Juab, Millard, Morgan, Salt Lake, San Juan, Sanpete, Sevier, Summit, Tooele, Utah, Wasatch, Washington, Weber. For 20201014 to 20201029, a (quote) circuit breaker (quote) this applies to Moderate transmission counties as well: Duchesne, Iron, Uintah. Starting 20201029, only applies to High transmission locations, so coding as easing: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-20-UPDATING-COVID-19-Transmission-Index.pdf

With the adoption of the new transmission phase system, counties in the high level of transmission require all employees to wear masks in public indoor settings and outdoors when physical distancing is not feasible. Businesses in moderate and low transmission levels are encouraged to have employees wear masks or individual businesses can determine requirements. Extended to 20201113: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-20-UPDATING-COVID-19-Transmission-Index.pdf

With the adoption of the new transmission phase system, for counties in the low transmission risk level, gatherings of more than 50 cannot occur unless people are wearing masks or face coverings. Coding as a gathering restriction of up to 50 being permitted. Applicable to Daggett, Kane, Piute, Rich, Wayne. Extended to 20201113: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-20-UPDATING-COVID-19-Transmission-Index.pdf

WIth the adoption of the new transmission phase system, counties in Moderate and High transmission levels are not permitted to have gatherings more than 10 and face masks are required. Initially applicable to Duchesne, Iron, Uintah, Beaver, Box Elder, Cache, Carbon, Davis, Emery, Garfield, Grand, Juab, Millard, Morgan, Salt Lake, San Juan, Sanpete, Sevier, Summit, Tooele, Utah, Wasatch, Washington, Weber. Starting 20201029, Moderate transmission level counties can have gatherings up to 25 people, coding as easing. Also extends to 20201113: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-20-UPDATING-COVID-19-Transmission-Index.pdf

Following the (quote) circuit breaker (quote) period, counties in Moderate transmission level can gatherings of more than 25 cannot occur unless people are wearing masks or face coverings. Coding as a gathering restriction of up to 25 being permitted. Applicable to Iron only on 20201029 and Millard starting 20201105: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/Transmission_index_by_county.pdf

Statewide, employees in business settings are required to wear masks and can ask patrons to wear masks or require them to leave if they refuse. Extended to 20201209: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2020-25_Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf Extended to 20201218: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-26-Updated-Statewide-COVID-19-Restrictions.pdf. Extended to 20210122 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2020-27_Updated%20Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf
State of emergency declared through December 8, 2020 (so coded to 20201209). Coded separately from the public health emergency

Statewide, requires social gatherings to be within households only. Coding as gathering of 0 at present. https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/State_of_Emergency.pdf Ended on 20201124: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2020-25_Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf

Statewide, all individuals shall wear a face mask while within 6 ft of any individual from a separate household. Exemptions are for children under the age of 3 years old, individuals whose medical conditions would otherwise put wearing a mask unsafe, while eating/drinking, etc. Coding as a Mandate3 under PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly across settings (indoors and outdoors). Extended to 20201209: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2020-25_Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf Extended to 20201218: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-26-Updated-Statewide-COVID-19-Restrictions.pdf. Extended to 20210122 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2020-27_Updated%20Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf

For Low risk transmission counties, social gatherings are recommended to be no more than 50. Religious gatherings are exempt. In public gatherings at venues, at least 6 ft distancing is required, but this is being coded under business restrictions Extended to 20201218: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-26-Updated-Statewide-COVID-19-Restrictions.pdf. As of 20201210, applicable to following counties: Daggett, Piute, Rich, Wayne. https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/Transmission_index_by_county.pdf. County levels updated every Thursday. Extended to 20210122 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2020-27_Updated%20Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf

For High risk transmission counties, social gatherings are recommended to be no more than 10. Religious gatherings are exempt. In public gatherings at venues, at least 6 ft distancing is required, but this is being coded under business restrictions Extended to 20201218: https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO-2020-26-Updated-Statewide-COVID-19-Restrictions.pdf. As of 20201210, applicable to following counties: Beaver, Box Elder, Cache, Carbon, Davis, Duchesne, Emery, Garfield, Grand, Iron, Juab, Kane, Millard, Morgan, Salt Lake, San Juan, Sanpete, Sevier, Summit, Tooele, Uintah, Utah, Wasatch, Washington, Weber. https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/Transmission_index_by_county.pdf. County levels updated every Thursday. Extended to 20210122 https://coronavirus-download.utah.gov/Health/UPHO_2020-27_Updated%20Statewide_COVID-19_Restrictions.pdf

Will close in 3 days time (i.e., 20200318). Extended to the end of the school year, ie 20200612. Prohibits gatherings of more than 50 people or 50 percent of permitted occupancy (whichever is less). Expands original rule by making it more restrictive.

Micro-crews, or no more than 2 people persons per location/job, to perform outdoor work and construction work in unoccupied structures (indoors). Businesses with a single worker (such as appraisers, realtors, municipal clerks, attorneys, property managers, pet care operators and others) may open as long as only two people (worker and customer) in business at once. Eased on 20200427 to permit 5 people, and then on 20200504 to permit 10 people, and broader reopening over time with requirements to maintain at least 6 ft distancing and limited occupancy. Extended to 20210116: https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/ADDENDUM%209%20TO%20AMENDED%20AND%20RESTATED%20EXECUTIVE%20ORDER%2001-20%20.pdf.
People are encouraged to wear masks whenever interacting with people outside their household, or in public-facing businesses

Further eases restrictions on retail, permitting outdoor retail shopping allowed (e.g., garden centers and greenhouses). These operations shall not permit any more than a maximum of 10 total people including customers and staff. Eased on 20200518 to permit limited in-person services: https://web.archive.org/web/20200529045646/https://accd.vermont.gov/news/update-new-work-safe-additions-stay-home-stay-safe-order

Farmers markets are allowed to reopen subject to adherence to safety conditions, (quote) must significantly alter their business practices to eliminate crowds and reduce contact between vendors and customers, including a transition away from shopping and social events to primarily a food distribution system (quote). Extended to 20210116: https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/ADDENDUM%209%20TO%20AMENDED%20AND%20RESTATED%20EXECUTIVE%20ORDER%2001-20%20.pdf.

Wearing a mask or face covering is mandatory on public transportation services (buses, trains and ride services, and when in a mass transportation station or terminal, including airports) for those who are medically able. Coded as a Mandate1 for PublicMaskLevel as it is for very limited settings (i.e., transportation services). Extended to 20200715: https://governor.vermont.gov/sites/scott/files/documents/Amended%20and%20Restated%20Executive%20Order%20No.%2001-20.pdf

Businesses which support outdoor recreation are allowed to reopen if they follow safety protocols. Vermonters shall wear masks or cloth facial gatherings over their nose and mouth any time they are in public spaces, indoors or outdoors, where they come in contact with others from outside their households, especially in congregate settings, and where it is not possible to maintain a physical distance of at least 6 ft. Exemptions are for children under the age of 2 years old, individuals with medical or developmental conditions that make wearing a facial covering not possible, during strenuous exercise or activity. In effect 20200801. Coded as a Mandate3 for PublicMaskLevel as it applies broadly to indoor and outdoor settings. All individuals in Virginia shall remain at their place of residence. Ended on 20200605 by allowing EO-55 to expire then https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/governor-of-virginia/pdf/eo/EO-65-Phase-Two.pdf

All public and private in-person gatherings of more than 10 individuals are prohibited. As of 12 am on 20200515, individuals may attend religious services if they are at no more than 50 percent capacity, 6 ft apart, strongly consider wearing a mask during attendance, no passing of items. This applied to Virginia excluding Northern Virginia Region and City of Richmond and County of Accomack, which still had gathering restrictions of 10 across settings beyond 20200515 after they were moved back to Phase Zero https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-62-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Four-AMENDED.pdf

Requirement for all patrons 10 years and older to wear face coverings while inside public buildings and businesses. Explicitly lists personal care services, brick and mortal retail (essential and non-essential businesses), food and beverage establishments, entertainment and recreation businesses (also required in outdoor settings for these businesses if distancing cannot be maintained), shared transportation, and any indoor place shared by groups of people in close proximity to each other outside of personal residences. Coded as Mandate2 as it applies widely across indoor spaces. On 20201116, expanded to all individuals 5 years and over: https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-63-AMENDED-and-Order-Of-Public-Health-Emergency-Five---Requirement-To-Wear-Face-Covering-While-Inside-Buildings.pdf.

All Virginia locations are now at Phase 1 for gatherings, such that gatherings of 10 or more are still prohibited, but with the exception that individuals may attend religious services if they are at no more than 50 percent capacity, 6 ft apart, strongly consider wearing a mask during attendance, no passing of items.

Eases gathering restrictions to no more than 50 people in public and private in-person gatherings. Religious services continue to have the exception wherein they can be attended with no more than 50 percent capacity, physical distancing occurs, etc

Northern Virginia Region and Richmond move to Phase 2, bringing the full state to Phase 2 eased restrictions for gatherings. No more than 50 people in public and private in-person gatherings. Religious services continue to have the exception wherein they can be attended with no more than 50 percent capacity, physical distancing occurs, etc
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: With Phase 3, (quote) All public and private in-person gatherings of more than 250 individuals are prohibited. (quote)

Expands prior gathering restrictions for the Eastern Region (Cities of Virginia Beach, Chesapeake, Norfolk, Suffolk, Portsmouth, Hampton, Williamsburg, Newport News, Poquoson, James City County, and York County): all gatherings are now limited to no more than 50 individuals (indoors and outdoors). Does not apply to religious services, though physical distancing of at least 6 ft is required for religious services. The Eastern Region join the rest of the state for Phase 3 on 20200911https://www.governor.virginia.gov/media/governorvirginiagov/executive-actions/EO-67-THIRD-AMENDED-and-Order-of-Public-Health-Emergency-Seven---Phase-Three-Easing-of-Certain-Temporary-Restrictions-Due-to-Novel-Coronavirus-(COVID-19).pdf

Expands statewide gathering restrictions. All indoor and outdoor gatherings are now limited to no more than 25 individuals (from 250). Does not apply to religious services, though physical distancing of at least 6 ft and face coverings are required for religious services.

Expands statewide gathering restrictions. All indoor and outdoor gatherings are now limited to no more than 10 individuals. Does not apply to religious services, though physical distancing of at least 6 ft and face coverings are required for religious services.

Expands mask mandate, now requiring all Virginians 5 years and older (from 10 years) to wear face coverings in indoor public spaces and outdoors where 6 ft distance cannot be maintained.This requirement applies to state and local government settings, train stations, bus stations, and intrastate public transportation, including buses, rideshares, trains, taxis, and cars for hire, as well as any waiting or congregating areas associated with boarding public transportation. This mandate also applies outdoors  when unable to maintain at least six feet of physical distance from other individuals who are not Family members. Coded as Mandate3 as it applies widely across indoor and outdoor spaces.
(quote) All individuals in Virginia should remain at their place of residence between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m.(quote), with exceptions for permitted activities
State of Emergency. Does not include a formal expiry date
Only applicable to King, Pierce, and Snohomish Counties. Initial expiry was midnight on 20200331, so formal expiry would have been 20200401 per coding criteria
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Closes all schools K-12 (public, private, and charter) for King, Pierce, and Snohomish counties. Goes in effect 1201 am 20200317, through 20200424 at 12 pm (unless extended). Eased for summer school on: _source=govdelivery.
Applies 250 gathering limit to all Washington state counties. Initial expiry was midnight on 20200331, so formal expiry would have been 20200401 per coding criteria
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated entry to new gathering system and added numeric variables

PolicyCodingNotes: Statewide closure of all public, private, and charter schools comes into effect 1201 am on 20200317, through 20200424 at 12 pm for initial expiry. Eases restrictions on K-12 summer operations starting 202000620: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/20.09.2%20COVID19%20Phased%20Reopening%20of%20K12%20Schools.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery

Statewide closure of all private, public, and private-public universities, colleges, technical schools, etc. to in-person instruction. Treating separately from the K-12 closures. A 20200624 order declared that (quote) beginning on August 1, 2020, public and private universities, colleges, technical schools, apprenticeship programs, and similar schools and programs may resume general instruction, to include in-person classroom instruction, lectures and similar educational gatherings, only if they implement, follow, and enforce the requirements specified below (quote). Coding as ending the statewide closure of higher education on 20200801

Limited operations required (onsite consumption banned): bars and taverns. Initial expiry is through midnight on 20200331, so formal expiry would have been 20200401. Began easing restrictions on 20200511, when restaurant and bar guidance was published for Phase 2 counties: https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-issues-guidance-partially-resuming-dine-restaurant-and-tavern-industry-phase-2
Expands gathering restriction to no more than 50

Closure required: public venues in which people congregate for entertainment, social or recreational purposes, including but not limited to theaters, bowling alleys, gyms, fitness centers, non-tribal card rooms, barbershops and hair/nail salons, tattoo parlors, pool halls, and other similar venues. Also closes all retail businesses except groceries and pharmacy. Easing began on 20200508 with takeaway for non-essential retail: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/20-25.3%20-%20COVID-19%20Stay%20Home%20Stay%20Healthy%20-%20Reopening%20%28tmp%29.pdf

Limited operations required (onsite consumption banned): restaurants, coffee shops, any social club, etc. Initial expiry is through midnight on 20200331, so formal expiry would have been 20200401. Easing begain on 20200511, with first counties moving to Phase 2:

(quote) All people in Washington state shall immediately cease participating in all public and private gatherings and multi-preson activities for social, spiritual and recreational purposes, regardles of the number people of involved (quote). Began easing on 20200508 with Phase 2 counties being able to have up to 5 people in a single gathering

State-wide immediate stay-at-home, effective immediately: https://mynorthwest.com/1782819/inslee-washington-stay-at-home-order/ Easing began with transition to Safe Start WA, no longer mandating statewide stay-at-home orders for all populations (high risk in Phase 1 counties) https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/20-25.4%20-%20COVID-19%20Safe%20Start.pdf Fully ended mandate on 20200703 as all populations are no longer mandate https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/benton-franklin-and-yakima-counties-approved-move-modified-phase-1

(quote) Effective midnight on March 25, 2020, all non-essential businesses in Washington State shall cease operations except for performing basic minimum operations (quote) Coding DateEnacted as 20200326.

With initial business restrictions being eased for Phase 1, requirements for employees to wear masks or face coverings being (e.g., vehicle and vessel sales under Phase 1). The May 4 Safe Start Washington also stipulates the following: (quote) Identify personal protective equipment (PPE) and cloth facial coverings in accordance with L and I requirements on facial coverings and industry specific COVID-19 standards. (quote) On June 8, this was substantially expanded, (quote) (quote) Beginning on June 8, 2020, when on the job, all employees must wear a facial covering except when working alone or when the job has no in-person interaction as detailed in the Safe Start Washington Phased Reopening Plan, and, further, that employers must provide cloth facial coverings to employees, unless their exposure dictates a higher level of protection (quote). Coding as an expanded business mask mandate: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/20-25.4%20-%20COVID-19%20Safe%20Start.pdf
Recommends that all individuals should wear cloth face coverings in public places when not eating or drinking

Eases restrictions on vehicle and vessel sales, permitting these businesses to resume in-person indoor services with limited capacity (50 pct capacity maximum, maintain social distancing of at least 6 ft). Permitted to re-open upon the release of guidelines for vehicle and vessal sales
Eases restrictions on retail, allowing for curbside pick-up orders only (no-onsite service)
Eases restrictions on the following outdoor businesses: landscaping and lawn care, pet walking

Once counties move to Phase 2, gatherings of 5 or fewer can occur. Eased on 20200527, with religious gatherings permitting more people: https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-religious-and-faith-based-services-guidance

Per issuance of Phase 2 guidelines, bar restrictions are eased such that in-person services can resume conditional on guidelines being followed (no more than 50 percent occupancy, 5 or fewer people per table, distancing, sanitation, no bar area seating). Though Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pend Oreille moved to Phase 2 on 20200508, bar and restaurant guidelines were issued on 20200511 and thus could not re-open for in-person services until then. As of 20200511, applies to the following counties: Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pend Oreille, Skamania, Stevens, Wahkiakum. Continues to add more Phase 2 and then Phase 1.5 counties over time. Eased on 20200605 permitting for Phase 3 counties to have bar areas open: https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/14-counties-approved-move-next-phase-gov-jay-inslees-safe-start-plan

Per issuance of Phase 2 guidelines, restaurant restrictions are eased such that in-person services can resume conditional on guidelines being followed (no more than 50 percent occupancy, 5 or fewer people per table, distancing, sanitation, no bar area seating). Though Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pend Oreille moved to Phase 2 on 20200508, bar and restaurant guidelines were issued on 20200511 and thus could not re-open for in-person services until then. As of 20200511, applies to the following counties: Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pend Oreille, Skamania, Stevens, Wahkiakum

Per issuance of Phase 2 guidelines, retail businesses may resume in-person services at limited capacity, at least 6 ft distancing, etc. Counties currently in Phase 2 moved there prior to 20200512, but they could not re-open retail for in-person services until the guideline were issued. Applies to: Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pend Oreille, Skamania, Stevens, Wahkiakum. From May through July, more counties move to this level of restriction until it is statewide

Gathering restrictions are eased for Phase 2 counties, allowing up to 50 individuals or 25 pct capacity for indoor religious gatherings. No limit provided for indoor religious gatherings. Eased when counties could move to Phase on 20200605: https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/14-counties-approved-move-next-phase-gov-jay-inslees-safe-start-plan

Gathering restrictions are eased for Phase 1 counties, allowing up to 100 individuals for outdoor religious gatherings. No indoor gatherings permitted. Eased when counties could start moving to Phase 1.5 (King) on 20200605: https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/14-counties-approved-move-next-phase-gov-jay-inslees-safe-start-plan

For Phase 1 counties, stay-at-home order remains a mandate but only for high-risk populations (i.e., individuals 65 and older, those with underlying medical conditions that put them at higher risk for complications from COVID-19, persons living in nursing homes and long-term care facilities). Phase 1 counties as of Safe Start enactment are 13 in total (i.e., not Adams, Asotin, Clallam, Columbia, Cowlitz, Ferry, Garfield, Grant, Grays Harbor, Island, Jefferson, Kitsap, Kittitas, Lewis, Lincoln, Mason, Pacific, Pend Orielle, San Juan, Skamania, Spokane, Stevens, Thurston, Wahkiakum, Walla Walla, and Whitman) From 20200605 to 20200703, increasingly more counties moved out of Phase 1 and thus eased this policy. Ended on 20200703 when all counties moved out of Phase 1: https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/benton-franklin-and-yakima-counties-approved-move-modified-phase-1

For Phase 2 counties, stay-at-home recommendation for high risk individuals (i.e., individuals 65 and older, those with underlying medical conditions that put them at higher risk for complications from COVID-19, persons living in nursing homes and long-term care facilities). Phase 2 counties as of Safe Start enactment are 26 in total (i.e.,  Adams, Asotin, Clallam, Columbia, Cowlitz, Ferry, Garfield, Grant, Grays Harbor, Island, Jefferson, Kitsap, Kittitas, Lewis, Lincoln, Mason, Pacific, Pend Orielle, San Juan, Skamania, Spokane, Stevens, Thurston, Wahkiakum, Walla Walla, and Whitman). From 20200605 to 20200703, increasingly more counties move to this policy to eventually become statewide https://coronavirus.wa.gov/news/benton-franklin-and-yakima-counties-approved-move-modified-phase-1. Extended without expiry starting on 20200727: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/proc_20-25.7.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery

Once counties move to Phase 3, gatherings of 50 or fewer can occur. When the first set of counties moved to Phase 3, it applied to 7 countes (Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pend Oreille, Stevens and Wahkiakum). By 20200611, this applies to 10 counties. On 20200618, eased for religious and faith-based services, allowing for indoor services at 50 pct capacity or 400 people, whichever is less: https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-updated-religious-and-faith-based-services-guidance
King County is moved to Phase 1.5, where up to 5 people in a gathering may occur outside. Continues prior Phase 1 restrictions for religious gatherings

Requires staff and students to wear cloth face coverings with the resumption of limited summer school services (quote) All students, volunteers, or guests must wear cloth face coverings at school. (quote)

Eases restrictions on in-person instruction in K-12 schools, allowing schools to re-open starting June 20 for summer services subject to the requirements under school guidance documents. School reopening decisions now made at the local or district level. On 20200804, devolves authority to reopen schools to local authorities: https://www.doh.wa.gov/Portals/1/Documents/1600/coronavirus/FallGuidanceK-12.pdf

For Phase 1.5 counties, gatherings are eased specifically for religious and faith-based services, allowing for indoor services at 25 pct capacity or 200 people, whichever is less. No explicit limit on outdoor services. Otherwise, full gathering restrictions for Phase 1.5 are in place: 5 people in a gathering may occur outside. Phase 1.5 counties now total 3 on 20200618: Chelan, Douglas, and King. By 20200725, the following counties were in Phase 1.5: Chelan, Douglas, Benton, Franklin, and Yakima.

For Phase 2 counties, gatherings are eased specifically for religious and faith-based services, allowing for indoor services at 25 pct capacity or 200 people, whichever is less. No explicit limit on outdoor services. Otherwise, full gathering restrictions for Phase 2 are in place: gathering restriction of more than 5 for Phase 2 counties, which are now 21 on 20200618: Adams, Clallam, Cowlitz, Grant, Island, Jefferson, Kitsap, Kittitas, Klickitat, Lewis, Mason, San Juan, Spokane, Thurston, Walla Walla, Clark, Okanogan, Pierce, Skagit, Snohomish and Whatcom. By 20200725, the following counties were in Phase 2: Adams, Clallam, Cowlitz, Grant, Jefferson, King, Kitsap, Klickitat, San Juan, Spokane, Walla Walla, Clark, Okanogan, Pierce, Skagit, Snohomish and Whatcom.

For Phase 3 counties, gatherings are eased specifically for religious and faith-based services, allowing for indoor services at 50 pct capacity or 400 people, whichever is less. No explicit limit on outdoor services. Otherwise, full gathering restrictions for Phase 3 are in place: gathering restriction of more than 50 for Phase 3 counties, which are now 12 in Phase 3 on 20200618:  Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pacific, Pend Oreille, Stevens, Wahkiakum, Whitman, Asotin, Skamania, Grays Harbor.  By 20200725, the following counties were in Phase 3: Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pacific, Pend Oreille, Stevens, Wahkiakum, Whitman, Asotin, Skamania, Grays Harbor, Island, Lewis, Mason, Kittitas, Thurston.

(quote) Every person in Washington State must wear a face covering that covers their nose and mouth when in any indoor or outdoor setting (quote) Exemptions are for children younger than 5 or persons whose medical condition, mental health condition, or disability that would prevent earing a face covering. Expands prior recommendation to a full mandate. Coded as Mandate3 as it explicitly applies across indoor and outdoor settings. Extended to 20200807: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/20-25.6%20-%20COVID-19%20Safe%20Start-Stay%20Healthy%20%28tmp%29.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery Effective 20200725, this mandate is somewhat expanded, explicitly requiring face coverings in public and non-public indoor and outdoor settings with few exemptions: https://www.doh.wa.gov/Portals/1/Documents/1600/coronavirus/Secretary_of_Health_Order_20-03_Statewide_Face_Coverings.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery  Extended on 20200724 without expiry: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/proc_20-25.7.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated PolicyCodingNotes, removed DateExpiry as latest extension has no expiry date

PolicyCodingNotes: Statewide, bars can reopen for indoor and outdoor services across counties (though at different capacity levels across phases)

Benton, Franklin, Yakima move to Phase 1.5, allowing eased restrictions on retail to be statewide, though with variable occupancy limits by Phase (15 pct for Phase 1.5, 25 pct for Phase 2, and higher occupancy limits for Phase 3). On 20201117, indoor restrictions expanded, no more than 25 pct capacity and closed congregate areas https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/proc_20-25.8.pdf

Statewide, restaurants can reopen for indoor and outdoor services across counties (though at different capacity levels across phases). From July to October, some changes in capacity and table size occurred across phases, and then were eased by 20201006: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/COVID19%20Phase%202%20and%203%20Restaurant%20and%20Tavern%20Guidance.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery

Expands gathering restriction for Phase 3 counties, now limiting gatherings to no more than 10 people. Funerals, weddings, and religious activities are exempt from the new restrictions, which means the following continues: for religious and faith-based services, allowing for indoor services at 50 pct capacity or 400 people, whichever is less. Phase 3 counties are 17: Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pacific, Pend Oreille, Stevens, Wahkiakum, Whitman, Asotin, Skamania, Grays Harbor, Island, Lewis, Mason, Kittitas, Thurston.  Extended on 20200724 without expiry: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/proc_20-25.7.pdf?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery

Statwide, bars had to close indoor services unless some minimum food services were provided. Further expanded on 20201118, without the food service provision: https://www.governor.wa.gov/sites/default/files/proclamations/proc_20-25.8.pdf Extended to 20210104: https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-new-economic-supports-and-extension-restrictions

Amends (and expands) gathering restrictions for Phase 1.5 counties, clarifying that up to 200 people may gather for a religious gathering outside, conditional on 6 ft of physical distancing, mask use, etc. Previous gathering requirements continue:  up to 5 people can gather outside, for religious and faith-based services, indoor services can be at 25 pct capacity or 200 people, whichever is less. Phase 1.5 counties are now 5: Chelan, Douglas, Benton, Franklin, and Yakima. Note that as of 20200806, wedding and funeral receptions are prohibited and ceremonies have a maximum indoor capacity of 20 pct, or up to 30 people, whichever is less, conditional social distancing being observed. Eased on 20201013 as Phase 1.5 counties move to Phase 2: https://twitter.com/GovInslee/status/1316143263309422592?s=20.

Amends (and expands) gathering restrictions for Phase 2 counties, clarifying that up to 200 people may gather for a religious gathering outside, conditional on 6 ft of physical distancing, mask use, etc. Previous gathering requirements continue: gatherings of no more than 5 people, indoors and outdoors, for indoor services at 25 pct capacity or 200 people, whichever is less. Phase 2 counties are 17: Adams, Clallam, Cowlitz, Grant, Jefferson, King, Kitsap, Klickitat, San Juan, Spokane, Walla Walla, Clark, Okanogan, Pierce, Skagit, Snohomish and Whatcom.  Note that as of 20200806, wedding and funeral receptions are prohibited and ceremonies have a maximum indoor capacity of 20 pct, or up to 30 people, whichever is less, conditional social distancing being observed. On 20201013, Phase 1.5 counties move to Phase 2, which now has 22 counties: Adams, Benton, Chelan, Clallam, Clark, Cowlitz, Douglas, Franklin, Grant, Jefferson, King, Kitsap, Klickitat, Okanogan, Pierce, San Juan, Skagit, Snohomish, Spokane, Walla Walla, Whatcom, Yakima. https://twitter.com/GovInslee/status/1316143263309422592?s=20.

Amends (and expands) gathering restrictions for Phase 3 counties, clarifying that up to 400 people may gather for a religious gathering outside, conditional on 6 ft of physical distancing, mask use, etc. Previous gathering requirements continue: gatherings of no more than 10 people, indoors and outdoors, for religious and faith-based services, allowing for indoor services at 50 pct capacity or 400 people. Phase 3 counties are 17: Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pacific, Pend Oreille, Stevens, Wahkiakum, Whitman, Asotin, Skamania, Grays Harbor, Island, Lewis, Mason, Kittitas, Thurston. Note that as of 20200806, wedding and funeral receptions are prohibited and ceremonies have a maximum indoor capacity of 20 pct, or up to 30 people, whichever is less, conditional social distancing being observed.

Amends (and expands) gathering restrictions for Phase 1.5 counties, clarifying that up to 50 people may gather for a religious gathering indoors (or 25 pct capacity of venues, whichever is less). Previous gathering requirements continue: up to 5 people can gather outside, for religious and faith-based services, outdoor services can be at 25 pct capacity or 200 people, whichever is less. Phase 1.5 counties are now 5: Chelan, Douglas, Benton, Franklin, and Yakima.

Persons arriving in Washington from other states or countries, including returning Washington residents, should practice self-quarantine for 14 days after arrival. Coded as Mandate 0 because this is a recommendation.

Expands gathering restrictions, prohibiting indoor social gatherings from outside ones home unless very specific conditions are met (i.e., quarantine for fourteen days (14) prior to the social gathering, or quarantine for seven (7) days prior to the social gathering and receive a negative COVID-19 test result no more than 48-hours prior to the gathering) and limiting outdoor social gatherings to no more than 5 people outside ones home. Indoor religious gatherings are limited to no more than 200 or 25 pct capacity, while outdoor gatherings follow phase requirements (Phase 3 permits 400)

Expands gathering restrictions, prohibiting indoor social gatherings from outside ones home unless very specific conditions are met (i.e., quarantine for fourteen days (14) prior to the social gathering, or quarantine for seven (7) days prior to the social gathering and receive a negative COVID-19 test result no more than 48-hours prior to the gathering) and limiting outdoor social gatherings to no more than 5 people outside ones home. Indoor religious gatherings are limited to no more than 200 or 25 pct capacity, while outdoor gatherings follow phase requirements (Phase 2 permits 200)

Statewide, zoos and aquariums must close indoor services, as do gyms and fitness centers.  Outdoor fitness classes may occur at no more than 5 people at a time. Extends to 20210104: https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-new-economic-supports-and-extension-restrictions

Statewide, indoor movie theaters must close. Drive-in movie theaters can remain open. Extends to 20210104: https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-new-economic-supports-and-extension-restrictions

Statewide, restaurants must close for indoor services. Outdoor services and to-go services permitted, with no more than 5 people at a table and proper distancing between tables. Extends to 20210104: https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-new-economic-supports-and-extension-restrictions

Expands gathering restrictions for outdoor religious gatherings, now permitting 200 people maximum or 25 percent capacity. Continues prohibiting indoor social gatherings from outside ones home unless very specific conditions are met (i.e., quarantine for fourteen days (14) prior to the social gathering, or quarantine for seven (7) days prior to the social gathering and receive a negative COVID-19 test result no more than 48-hours prior to the gathering) and limiting outdoor social gatherings to no more than 5 people outside ones home. Indoor and outdoor religious gatherings are limited to no more than 200 or 25 pct capacity. Joins phase 3 to phases 1 and 2, gathering restrictions are now the same across the state. Extends to 20210104: https://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/inslee-announces-new-economic-supports-and-extension-restrictions

Governor issues a recommendation that all West Virginians who are at the highest risk of having complications related to COVID – including seniors and those with chronic health conditions like heart disease, diabetes, and lung disease – avoid large crowds.
LastUpdatedNotes: Updated StatePolicy to GathRestrict with a Mandate of 0

PolicyCodingNotes: Closure of all public pre-K to 12th grade schools, in effect on (quote) at the conclusion of the school day on Friday, March 13 (quote), and thus coded as enacted on 20200314 Community and private schools are recommended to follow this closure, but not mandated. Schools closed until the end of the year on 20200422. School closure is eased to permit school-based athletics and band training starting 20200608 https://governor.wv.gov/Pages/The-Comeback.aspx.  On 20200708, the governor announces 20200908 as a target reopening date for schools: https://governor.wv.gov/News/press-releases/2020/Pages/COVID-19-UPDATE-Gov.-Justice-announces-reopening-date-for-West-Virginia-schools.aspx. Color-coded system for school re-opening at the county level requires counties that are orange or red designated to remain closed, and are updated weekly (Saturdays) for the next week unless designated red (at which halting in-person instruction has to occur immediately): https://wvde.us/school-reentry-metrics-protocols/
State of emergency declared for all 55 counties, no expiry provided.

Limited operations required (limited to take-away services): bars. In effect at 1200 am 20200318 per executive order, signed on 20200318. Easing began on 20200526: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-May-26-Reopenings.pdf

Closure required: casinos. In effect at 1200 am 20200318 per executive order, signed on 20200318. Note that order announcement occurred on 20200317 via press release. Eased restrictions starting on 20200605 https://governor.wv.gov/Pages/The-Comeback.aspx

Limited operations required (limited to take-away services): restaurants. In effect at 1200 am 20200318 per executive order, signed on 20200318. Note that order announcement occurred on 20200317 via press release. Began easing on 20200504, allowing outdoor services: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/Executive-Order-April-30-2020-Safer-At-Home-Order.pdf

Closure required: fitness centers, gymnasiums, recreation centers, and similar recreation locations. In effect at 1200 am 20200319. Eased on 20200518, Gyms and fitness centers can reopen using social distancing guidelines https://apps.sos.wv.gov/adlaw/executivejournal/readpdf.aspx?DocID=89852

Closure required: barbershops, hair salons, and nail salon. In effect at 1200 am 20200320 per exeuctive order. Included under StayAtHome order. Page 10, point 5 (quote) Any gathering of more than 10 people is prohibited unless exempted by this Order (quote).

Colleges and universities are only open for distance learning, but higher ed can continue critical research provided that 6 feet of distance is maintained to the greatest extent possible. Enacted as of 8 pm 20200324. No formal expiry provided. Going to and from place of worship is included under essential services. All bars in Monongalia County shall not allow on-premises consumption of food or drink, and thus bars are limited to take-away or delivery only.  https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/EO-65-20-September-2-2020-Mon-County-Bars-6.pdf On 20201013, restrictions are eased to 50 pct capcity, joining state-level restrictions: https://governor.wv.gov/Documents/2020%20Executive%20Orders/EO-75-20-October-13-2020-Mon-County-Bars-7.pdf

Public Health Emergency declaration, which designates Department of Health Services as the lead agency to respond. No formal expiry included in order

in effect at 1201 am on 20200317. Explicitly includes places of worship and religious gatherings under this order. In effect for as long as the public health emergency is in effect

Coding as a closure with indoor services permitted, requiring no more than 10 people on premises at a time (and thus substantially affecting business operations)

Effective as of 5 pm 20200317 all restaurants shall close for in-person services. Take out or delivery service is allowed. Extended to 20200526. WI supreme court ruling ended EO 28 and thus restaurant restrictions on 20200513. Currently coding as ended for 20200513.

Eases restrictions on bars, wineries, and breweries to allow for take away services. Appears to be a clarification that had the effect of changing the level of BusinessRestrictLevel, rather than an intentional easing. No seating or consumption of food/drinks indoor or outdoor is allowed. Extended to 20200526 but restrictions on bars ended with the WI supreme court ruling on 20200513.
Requires the following to close: close-contact personal services: hair salons, day spas, nail salons, barber shops, tattoo parlors, body art establishments, and tanning facilities

Expands gathering restrictions. (quote) All public and private gatherings of any number of people that are not part of a single household or living unit are prohibited (quote). Exception provided for religious facilities, which allow up to 10 people to gather. Ended by WI Supreme Court Ruling on 20200513: https://www.wpr.org/sites/default/files/wi_legislature_v._andrea_palm_-_decision.pdf

In effect at 8am on 20200325 non-essential business and operations must cease.Began easing on 20200424: https://evers.wi.gov/Documents/COVID19/EMO28-SaferAtHome.pdf WI Supreme court ruling ended EO 28 and thus NE business closure on 20200513.

Eases business closures for library. Curb-side pick-up of books and other library materials is allowed. On 20200427, eases restrictions on what constitues minimum basic operations for non-essential businesses: allows for curbside drop-off and pick-up of good and animals, outdoor rental of recreational equipment. WI supreme court ruling ended EO28 and thus restrictions on NE businesses. Currently coding as ended for 20200513.

Eases restrictions on some businesses, allowing standalone or strip mall-based retail stores with an entrance or entrances to the outside may offer in-person shopping for up to five customers at a time. WI supreme court ruling ended EO28 and thus restrictions on NE businesses. Currently coding as ended for 20200513.
Governor encourages Wisconsinites to wear masks via radio address

Declares Public Health Emergency, effective for 60 days. On 20200922, extended for 60 days until 20201121. https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/WIGOV/2020/09/22/file_attachments/1552234/EO090-DeclaringPublicHealthEmergency.pdf Extended to 20210119: https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/WIGOV/2020/11/20/file_attachments/1607583/EO095-DeclaringPublicHealthEmergencyNov2020.pdf

Every individual aged 5 years and older shall wear a face covering if the individual is indoors or in an enclosed space, other than a private residence. Face coverings are strongly recommended in all other settings, including outdoors when it is not possible to maintain physical distancing. Exemptions for individuals with conditions that would prohibit safe mask use, during speech (including religious) when at least 6 ft distancing can occur. Coded as Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel due to its broad applications indoors but only recommendation outdoors. On 20200922, extended for 60 days until 20201121. https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/WIGOV/2020/09/22/file_attachments/1552176/EmO01-SeptFaceCoverings.pdf Extends to 20210119: https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/WIGOV/2020/11/20/file_attachments/1607585/EmO01-NovFaceCovering.pdf

Restrictions on bars are imposed at the state level, requiring no more than 25 pct capacity for indoor services. Supreme Court ruling on 20201023 ends EO3, and thus bar restrictions at the state-level are also ended.

Indoor public gatherings are limited to no more than 25 pct of the total occupancy for the room or building, and for indoor spaces without an occupancy limit for the room or building, public gatherings are limited to more than 10 people. Exemptions are child care settings, schools, healthcare settings, churches and places of worship, political rallies, etc. Ended on 20201023 with Supreme Court ruling against gathering restrictions put in place by EO3: https://acefiling.wicourts.gov/document/uploaded/2020AP001742/299350.

Restrictions are imposed on businesses at the state level, requiring no more than 25 pct capacity for indoor in-person services. Supreme Court ruling on 20201023 ends EO3, and thus business restrictions at the state-level are also ended. https://acefiling.wicourts.gov/document/uploaded/2020AP001742/299350

Restrictions on restaurants are imposed at the state level, requiring no more than 25 pct capacity for indoor services. Supreme Court ruling on 20201023 ends EO3, and thus restaurant restrictions at the state level are also ended https://acefiling.wicourts.gov/document/uploaded/2020AP001742/299350

Recommendation on staying home. (quote) The best way you can help support our frontline healthcare workers and providers is by staying home as much as possible (quote). On 20201105, On a radio address, governor recommends the following: (quote) I know everyone is tired of all the court decisions whiplash, so here s the bottom line: stay home...Don t have people at your home who are outside of your immediate family or household. Don t host or go to gatherings with people outside of your immediate family or household. Limit your social interactions to a circle of 5, and start planning your holidays to happen virtually (quote): https://content.govdelivery.com/accounts/WIGOV/bulletins/2aa3b4c On 20201111, Governor issues executive order with the following recommendation: (quote) All individuals should stay home as much as possible and only make trips when necessary, such as to go to work, pick up groceries, or refill prescriptions (quote) https://evers.wi.gov/Documents/COVID19/EO094-COVIDRecommendations.pdf

On a radio address, governor recommends the following: (quote) Don t have people at your home who are outside of your immediate family or household. Limit your social interactions to a circle of 5, and start planning your holidays to happen virtually (quote). Coding as a recommendation for no more than 5 people at gathering.

PolicyCodingNotes: Gatherings of more than 25 people prohibited. Does not include religious gatherings. The following and similar events can allow groups of up to 100 indoors and 250 outdoors under strict guidelines. (quote) These events include by way of example but are not limited to rodeos, speedway races, outdoor concerts, sporting events, fair, track and field races, farmers markets (quote), etc.

Expands restrictions on bars. The permitted number of persons at a table is now 6 persons (from 8). Distancing between tables must continue (at least 6 ft), and all patrons must remain seated at tables or booths for service. Bars are prohibited from operating from 10pm to 5am.

Expands gatherings rules, defines gathering as 10 people gathered (from 25). Gatherings of more than 10 are prohibited, but long list of exceptions provided. Includes all religious gatherings. However, events not specified in this order may allow indoor gatherings of more than 10 but no more than 25 pct capacity with a maximum of 100 people, and outdoor gatherings of more than 10 but no more than 50 pct of venue capacity with a maximum of 250 people. Allows for events like rodeos, farmers markets, fireworks shows, etc. of venue

Issues statewide mask mandate. All individuals shall wear a face covering when any person is inside, or in line to enter, any business or any goverment facility open to the general public, when any person is obtaining services at, or visiting healthcare operations, when any person is waiting for or riding on public transportation. Exceptions include children under 12, people with medical conditions, and people eating at a restaruant while seated. Coded as Mandate2 for PublicMaskLevel due to its broad applications indoors.

Expands restrictions on restaurants. The permitted number of persons at a table is now 6 persons (from 8). Distancing between tables must continue (at least 6 ft), and all patrons must remain seated at tables or booths for service. Restaurants are prohibited from operating from 10 pm to 5 am.
